summary: This paper proposes to decompose joint action spaces into restricted role action spaces by clustering actions according to their effects on the environment and other agents. Learning a role selector based on action effects makes role discovery much easier because it forms a bi - level learning hierarchy : the role selector searches in a smaller role space and at a lower temporal resolution, while role policies learn in significantly reduced primitive action - observation spaces. The proposed method ( 1 ) outperforms the current state - of - the - art MARL algorithms on 9 of the 14 scenarios that comprise the challenging StarCraft II benchmark and ( 2 ) achieves rapid transfer to new environments with three times the number of agents.

This paper studies the behaviour of the stochastic subgradient descent ( SSGD ) method applied to over - parameterized nonsmooth optimization problems that satisfy an interpolation condition. By leveraging the composite structure of the empirical risk minimization problems, the authors prove that SSGD converges, respectively, with rates O(1 / ) and O(log(1/ ) for convex and strongly - convex objectives when interpolation holds. These rates coincide with established rates for the stoChastic gradient descent ( SGD ) algorithm applied to smooth problems. The analysis provides a partial explanation for the empirical observation that sometimes SGD and SSGD behave similarly for training smooth   machine learning models.

This paper presents a method for training transformers for machine translation and language modelling. The method is based on the idea of " reservoir layers ", which are non - linear layers that are interspersed with regular transformer layers. The main contribution of the paper is that the authors propose to use random initialization of the reservoir layers to improve the computation time until convergence of the transformers. The experiments are conducted on a number of machine translation tasks and language modeling tasks.

This paper studies steerable kernels constructed by filter transform. The authors show that the kernel constructed by the filter transform can be interpreted in the group representation theory. They also show that filter transformed kernels can be used to convolve input / output features in different group representation. This interpretation help complete the puzzle of steerable CNN theory and provides a novel and simple approach to implement steerable convolution operators.

This paper proposes an optimal neural synthesis approach for multimodal program synthesis, where the goal is to find a program that satisfies user - provided constraints while also maximizing the program ’s score with respect to a neural model. Specifically, the user intent is expressed using combination of natural language ( NL ) and input - output examples. The paper proposes a top - down recurrent neural model that places distributions over abstract syntax trees conditioned on the NL input. The experimental results show that the proposed method substantially outperforms prior state - of - the - art techniques in terms of accuracy and explores fewer states during search.

This paper presents a protein graph convolutional neural network ( PGCN ) to predict the substrate specificity landscape of a protease enzyme, which is the set of all sequence motifs that are recognized / cut by the enzyme. The method is based on a structure - based molecular interaction graph generated using the Rosetta energy function that describes the topology and energetic features, to determine substrate specificity. The proposed method also readily lends itself to the design of novel enzymes with tailored specificity against disease targets.

This paper studies the double Q - learning problem, which is a classical method for reducing overestimation bias caused by taking maximum estimated values in the Bellman operation. The authors show that such underestimation bias may lead to multiple non - optimal fixed points under an approximate Bellman operator. To address the concerns of converging to non - optimal stationary solutions, the authors propose a simple but effective approach as a partial fix for the underestimation biases in double Q learning. The proposed approach leverages an approximate dynamic programming to bound the target value. Experiments on the Atari benchmark tasks demonstrate its significant improvement over baseline algorithms.

This paper presents a simple yet cost - effective two - step training framework for deep generative models ( DGMs ) of high - dimensional natural images. The training is done by training a sampler in the wavelet domain and a decoder network in the low - frequency band. The sampler and decoder can be trained in parallel and operate on much lower dimensional spaces than end - to - end models. As a result, the training cost is substantially reduced. On ImageNet 512×512, our model achieves a Fréchet Inception Distance ( FID ) of 10.59 – beating the baseline BigGAN model – at half the compute ( 256 TPU - v3 cores ).

This paper studies the fewshot learning ( FSL ) setting, where the task is to distill transferable knowledge on existing classes with large - scale labeled data to cope with novel classes for which only a few labeled data are available. The authors first summarized the supervised FSL methods and explained why SSL is suitable for FSL. They further analyzed the main difference between supervised training and self - supervised training on FSL and obtained the bound for the gap between self - supervised loss and supervised loss. Finally, the authors proposed potential ways to improve the test accuracy under the setting.

This paper studies the convergence properties of neural networks with finite width. The authors prove that under the most basic settings, all student neurons must align with the teacher neuron at any local minima. The proof is based on analyzing the properties of a special class of functions that the authors call angular distance functions ( AD functions ).   The authors also show that these properties can be easily verified numerically. The paper is well - written and easy to follow.

This paper introduces Deep Adaptive Semantic Logic ( DASL ), a framework for automating the generation of deep neural networks that incorporates user - provided formal knowledge to improve learning from data. The authors provide formal semantics that demonstrate that our knowledge representation captures all of first order logic and that finite sampling from infinite domains converges to correct truth values. They also demonstrate the effectiveness of their framework through a toy problem in which they add structure to an image classification task and demonstrate that knowledge of that structure reduces data requirements by a factor of 1000.

This paper studies the iterative convergence of feedforward residual neural networks ( ResNets ). The authors define three indices of iteration and convergence of the networks and introduce regularizations to encourage the networks to learn iterative solutions. They also introduce a Lipschitz constraint on the residual functions using spectral normalization to make the networks more iterative and convergent. Experiments are conducted on standard visual recognition tasks ( MNIST, CIFAR-10, CifAR-100 ) and on challenging recognition tasks with partial occlusions ( Digitclutter ) to show the effectiveness of the proposed methods.

This paper proposes two new normalization techniques for out - of - distribution generalization ( OOD generalization ). The first method, SelfNorm, uses attention to recalibrate statistics ( channel - wise mean and variance ), while the second method, CrossNorm, exchanges the statistics between feature maps. Extensive experiments on different domains ( vision and language ), tasks ( classification and segmentation ), and settings ( supervised and semi - supervised ) show the effectiveness of the proposed methods.

This paper proposes to use attention mechanisms to improve the performance of reinforcement learning agents. Specifically, the authors propose to use a simple attention module in the convolutional encoder of an RL agent to extract task - relevant information such as agent locations and movements without the need for data augmentations or contrastive losses. Experiments on the DeepMind Control Suite environments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed module.

This paper proposes an extension to the GradNorm method for multi - task learning. The main idea is to add a task - specific rotation matrix that aligns the gradients of all tasks with the overall gradient of the overall gradients. Experiments on several real - world datasets and network architectures show that the proposed method outperforms previous approaches for multitask learning.

This paper proposes a new I2I translation constraint, called Minimal Geometry - distortion Constraint ( MGC ), which promotes the consistency of geometry structures and reduce the unwanted distortions in translation by reducing the randomness of color transformation in the translation process. The paper also proposes an approximate representation of mutual information called relative Squared - Loss to facilitate estimation and maximization of the mutual information. The effectiveness of the proposed MGC is demonstrated on several benchmark datasets.

This paper studies the long - neglected yet important effects of point sampling patterns in point cloud GANs. Through extensive experiments, the authors show that sampling - insensitive discriminators produce shape point clouds with point clustering artifacts while sampling - oversensitive discriminators ( e.g. PointNet++, DGCNN, PointConv, KPConv ) fail to guide valid shape generation. The authors further study how different evaluation metrics weigh the sampling pattern against the geometry and propose several perceptual metrics forming a sampling spectrum of metrics. Guided by the proposed sampling spectrum, the proposed PointNet - Mix baseline discriminator improves all existing point cloud generators by a large margin on sampling - related metrics.

This paper studies the robustness of Capsule Networks ( CapsNets ) against white - box attacks. The authors claim that adversarial examples can manipulate the votes from the primary capsules and the output capsules. They then propose a novel vote attack to attack the votes of the primary capsule directly. Extensive experiments demonstrate the superior attack performance of the proposed attack method.

This paper considers the problem of meta - reinforcement learning in the online adaptation setting where the agent needs to trade - off between two types of behaviour within the same episode. The authors propose a new algorithm that uses privileged information in the form of a task descriptor at train time to improve the learning of recurrent policies. The proposed method learns an informed policy by using parameters sharing and an auxiliary objective. Experiments are conducted in a variety of environments that require sophisticated exploration / exploitation strategies and show that it outperforms vanilla RNNs, Thompson sampling and task - inference approaches to meta - RL.

This paper proposes a new paradigm to learn an RL policy from offline data in the real - world sequential recommendation system ( SRS ). Instead of increasing the fidelity of models for policy learning, the authors propose to handle the distortion issue via learning to adapt to diverse simulators generated by the offline dataset. Experiments are conducted in synthetic environments and a real-world ride - hailing platform. The results show that the method overcomes the distortion problem and produces robust recommendations in the unseen real world.

This paper proposes a reinforcement learning algorithm that uses imitation learning to acquire goal - reaching policies from scratch without the need for expert demonstrations or a value function. The main idea is to leverage the property that any trajectory is a successful demonstration for reaching the final state in that same trajectory. The authors propose a simple algorithm in which an agent continually relabels and imitates the trajectories it generates to progressively learn goal reaching behaviors from scratch. The agent collects new trajectories using the latest policy, and maximizes the likelihood of the actions along these trajectories under the goal that was actually reached, and formally show that this iterated supervised learning procedure optimizes a bound on the RL objective.

This paper studies the one - to - many mapping problem in non - autoregressive text to speech ( TTS ). In particular, this paper proposes a new model named FastSpeech 2, which directly generates speech waveform from text in parallel, enjoying the benefit of fully end - to end inference. The proposed model achieves a 3x training speed - up over the previous fastspeech model and achieves even faster inference speed. Experiments are conducted on a number of datasets to validate the effectiveness of the proposed model.

This paper studies the minimization of the unsupervised dimension reduction problem ( UDR ) in the language of tempered distributions, i.e., the problem of approximating an empirical density function pemp(x ) by another tempered distribution q(x) whose support is in a k - dimensional subspace. The paper proposes an algorithm for minimization the distance between q and pemp, D(q, pemp ) over a set of generalized functions. This formulation allows to establish a connection with another classical problem of data science — the sufficient dimension reduction ( SDR ). An algorithm for the first problem induces an algorithm to solve the second and vice versa. Experiments are conducted on synthetic data and standard datasets.

This paper studies the trade - off between robustness and sensitivity in contrastive learning. The authors introduce two notions : contextual feature utility and contextual feature sensitivity. They propose Feature Contrastive Learning ( FCL ) that encourages the model to be more sensitive to the features that have higher contextual utility. Empirical results demonstrate that models trained with FCL achieve a better balance of robusts and sensitivity.

This paper proposes a new method for imitation learning based on generative adversarial learning. The key idea is to regularize the discriminator network with a latent representation of the optimal state and actions taken by the expert. This representation is regularized through mutual information constraints to incentivize learning only features that encode information about the completion levels of the task being demonstrated. This allows the agent to learn directly from high dimensional observations of an expert performing a task, by making use of the latent representation inside the discriminators network.

This paper studies the generalization of the lottery ticket hypothesis ( LTH ), which states that learning on a properly pruned neural network ( the winning ticket ) improves test accuracy over the original unpruned network. The paper characterizes the performance of training a pruned network by analyzing the geometric structure of the objective function and the sample complexity to achieve zero generalization error. The convex region near a desirable model with guaranteed generalization enlarges as the neural network model is pruned, indicating the structural importance of a winning ticket. The theoretical results are acquired from learning a pruning neural network of one hidden layer, while experimental results are further provided to justify the implications in pruning multi - layer neural networks.

This paper proposes a method to automatically learn the labels for augmented data, based on the distance between the clean distribution and augmented distribution. The proposed method is based on label smoothing and is guided by the calibration - performance over a hold - out validation set. Experiments on CIFAR-10, AugMix, mixup, and adversarial training show that the proposed method can improve models ’ accuracy and calibration performance.

This paper proposes a novel self - supervised representation learning method that enforces invariant prediction of proxy targets across augmentations through an invariance regularizer which yields improved generalization guarantees. The authors also provide an alternative theoretical explanation for the success of the proposed method. The paper is well - written and easy to follow.

This paper introduces a visual transformer network ( VTNet ) for learning informative visual representation in navigation. The main contribution of the paper is to introduce a pre - training scheme to associate the visual representations with navigation signals, and thus facilitate navigation policy learning. Experiments in the artificial environment AI2 - Thor demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms state - of - the - art methods.

This paper proposes a communication - centric secure aggregation method for federated learning. The key idea is to design the topology of the secret - sharing graph as sparse random graphs instead of the complete graph corresponding to the existing solution. The authors also provide theoretical guarantees on the reliability / privacy of the proposed scheme. Extensive experiments are conducted to demonstrate the effectiveness of the method.

This paper studies the problem of designing an incentive compatible auction that maximizes expected revenue. The authors propose two conceptual deviations from the work of Duetting et al. ( 2019 ). First, the authors introduce a time - independent Lagrangian, which can be used to compare the performance of two auctions. Second, the optimization procedure in previous work uses an inner maximization loop to compute optimal misreports. Experiments are conducted to show the effectiveness of the proposed framework.

This paper proposes a general learning approach to finetune both supervised and unsupervised pre - trained representations to downstream tasks. The authors propose a classifier head with a newly - designed categorical contrastive learning loss to fully exploit the intrinsic structure of data in a category - agnostic way. The proposed method achieves state - of - the - art results for fine - tuning tasks of both supervised    models by large margins ( e.g. 10.7 % absolute rise in accuracy on CUB in low - data regime ).

This paper proposes a new measure for robustness of classifiers called genuine adversarial accuracy ( GAI ), which measures the adversarial robustness without trading off accuracy on clean data and accuracy on adversarially perturbed samples. The proposed measure is based on the standard GAI, which is a trade - off between the accuracy of the classifier and the accuracy on the perturbed data. The authors show that the new measure is more robust to generalization than the standard one, which does not favor models with invariance - based adversarial examples, samples whose predicted classes are unchanged even if the perceptual classes are changed.

This paper studies the problem of disparate impact on graph - structured data. Specifically, the authors focus on dyadic fairness, which articulates a fairness concept that a predictive relationship between two instances should be independent of the sensitive attributes. The authors theoretically relate the graph connections to dyadic fair on link predictive scores in learning graph neural networks, and show that regulating weights on existing edges in a graph contributes to Dyadic fairness conditionally.

This paper proposes a new method for generative generative autoencoders. The proposed method is based on disentangled representation and regularization to guarantee the validity of exploration in latent space and achieve controllable synthesis. Experiments demonstrate that the proposed method can improve the performance of downstream tasks by synthesizing attribute - controlled augmented samples and can help to eliminate dataset bias.

This paper presents a new principled Bayesian memory allocation scheme that bridges the gap between episodic and semantic memory via a hierarchical latent variable model. The paper proposes a novel differentiable block allocated latent memory for episodic memory. Experiments are conducted on CIFAR-10, ImageNet32, CelebNet32 and ImageNet-32 to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the sample complexity and landscape of attention - based neural networks. Theoretical results show that, under mild assumptions, every local minimum of the attention model has low prediction error, and attention models require lower sample complexity than models without attention. Experiments on various datasets validate the theoretical findings.

This paper extends the concept of expected free energy ( EFE ), which is a core quantity in active inference, to a negative value function and claims that EFE can be treated as a function of prior preference. The authors then propose a simple but novel method to learn a prior preference from experts using EFE. Experimental results show the possibility of active inference with EFE - based rewards and its application to an inverse RL problem.

This paper proposes a data augmentation method to improve generalization in both adversarial and standard learning by using out - of - distribution ( OOD ) data that are devoid of the abovementioned issues. The proposed method theoretically improves generalization theoretically using OOD data in each learning scenario and complement their theoretical analysis with experiments on CIFAR - 10, CifAR - 100, and a subset of ImageNet. The results indicate that undesirable features are shared even among image data that seem to have little correlation from a human point of view.

This paper introduces Fast Linearized Adaptive Policy ( FLAP ), a new metareinforcement learning ( meta - RL ) method that is able to extrapolate well to out - of - distribution tasks without the need to reuse data from training, and adapt almost instantaneously with the need of only a few samples during testing. FLAP builds upon the idea of learning a shared linear representation of the policy so that when adapting to a new task, it suffices to predict a set of linear weights. A separate adapter network is trained simultaneously with the policy such that during adaptation, it can directly use the adapter network to predict these linear weights instead of updating a meta - policy via gradient descent. The application of the separate feed - forward network not only speeds up the adaptation run - time significantly, but also generalizes extremely well to very different tasks that prior Meta - RL methods fail to generalize to.

This paper proposes a distributed stochastic proximal gradient descent ( DSPGD ) algorithm to solve the optimization problem of kernel k - means under federated settings. A communication efficient mech - anism ( CEM ) is also proposed to reduce the communication cost of the algorithm. The proposed algorithm is evaluated on both synthetic and real - world datasets. The experimental results show that the proposed algorithm achieves the highest clustering quality while reducing communication cost by more than 60%.

This paper proposes to reduce the size of the training space and training budget of Once - For - All ( OFA ) by constraining the search space to models close to the accuracy - latency Pareto frontier. The proposed method reduces the training and subsequent extraction time by several orders of magnitude. Experiments on ImageNet show that the proposed method can achieve a 2x reduction in training time compared to the state of the art.

This paper studies the general meta - learning with adversarial samples in the context of image classification. The authors propose an algorithm, ADML ( ADversarial Meta - Learner ), which leverages both clean and adversarial data to optimize the initialization of a learning model in an adversarial manner. The proposed method is evaluated on two widely - used image datasets, MiniImageNet and CIFAR100, in terms of both accuracy and robustness.

This paper presents a data - driven framework for permutation selection in the context of Bose Chaudhuri Hocquenghem ( BCH ) code decoders. The authors propose to use node embedding and self - attention to improve the bit error rate of BCH code decoder. The proposed framework combines domain knowledge with machine learning concepts to select the best permutation for BCH decoder from a set of existing permutation - based decoder algorithms. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms the existing baselines in terms of bit error and bit complexity.

This paper proposes to perform an unsupervised clustering task prior to finetuning BERT for a target text classification task. Specifically, as such an intermediate task, the authors perform clustering, training BERT on predicting the cluster labels. The authors test this hypothesis on various data sets and show that this additional classification step can significantly reduce the demand for labeled examples mainly for topical classification tasks.

This paper studies the problem of model - based reinforcement learning ( MBRL ) from the perspective of mixture density nets ( MDPs ). The authors evaluate the performance of several popular generative models using a fixed ( random shooting ) control agent. They find that on an environment that requires multimodal posterior predictives, mixture density net outperform all other models by a large margin. They also find that heteroscedasticity at training time, perhaps acting as a regularizer, improves predictions at longer horizons. Finally, they design metrics and an experimental protocol to evaluate the various models.

This paper proposes a method to disentangle affine transformations in a self - supervised and rigorous manner. The main idea is to decompose the affine matrix into separate transformation matrices and infer the transformation parameters by maximum likelihood estimation. Experiments are conducted on the MNIST, CelebA, and dSprites datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of unsupervised representation learning in the context of instance discrimination - based contrastive learning. In particular, the authors propose to leverage the distributions of weakly augmented images over the representation bank to supervise the retrieval of strongly augmented queries from a pool of candidates. The proposed method achieves top - 1 accuracy of 76.2 % on ImageNet with a standard ResNet - 50 architecture with a single - layer classifier fine - tuned. This is almost the same as 76.5 % accuracy with a fully supervised ResNet-50. Moreover, it outperforms the previous self - supervised and supervised methods on both the transfer learning and object detection tasks.

This paper proposes a new method for the de - identification of the face in MRI scans. The proposed method is based on the 3D GAN architecture that takes a patient ’s MRI scan as input and generates a 3D volume in which the brain is not modified but the face has been de - identified. Compared to the classical removal - based techniques, the proposed method does not adversely affect downstream medical analyses on the brain.

Graph pooling is an important problem in graph neural networks ( GNNs ). The authors propose a method for graph pooling based on multiset encoding. The main idea is to consider the interaction between nodes according to their structural dependencies among them. The proposed method is evaluated on graph classification and generation tasks.

This paper studies the problem of over - squashing in graph neural networks ( GNNs ). The authors propose a new explanation for this problem, which is based on the observation that the GNN is susceptible to a bottleneck when aggregating messages across a long path. This bottleneck causes the over - sqashing of exponentially growing information into fixed - size vectors, and as a result, the network is unable to propagate messages originating from distant nodes and perform poorly when the prediction task depends on long - range interaction. The paper shows that the bottleneck hinders the popular GNN from fitting long range signals in the training data, and further show that the more popular GAT and GIN networks are more susceptible to over - Squashing than the more common GNN.

This paper proposes a domain adaptation method for sentiment sentiment analysis. The proposed method is based on domain - agnostic representations that are invariant with respect to both the source and the target domains. The main idea is to train a classifier that is trained using annotated data in a source domain, would generalize well in a related target domain. Theoretical and empirical analysis are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a challenge task to evaluate the performance of NLI models trained on MNLI and SNLI data - sets with respect to the presence of gender stereotypes. The challenge task is based on the pairing gender neutral premise against gender - specific hypothesis. The authors evaluate three models ( BERT, RoBERTa, BART ) trained on the data - set and find that three models are significantly prone to gender - induced prediction errors. They also find that augmenting the training dataset to ensure a gender - balanced dataset can help reduce such bias in certain cases.

This paper studies the problem of maximizing the empowerment of VIC, an unsupervised reinforcement learning method for finding the largest set of intrinsic options available to an agent. The paper proposes two methods based on the transitional probability model and Gaussian mixture model to achieve the maximal empowerment. The main claim of the paper is that the intrinsic reward used in the latter is subject to bias in stochastic environments, causing convergence to suboptimal solutions. This claim is supported by rigorous mathematical derivations and experimental analyses.

This paper studies the problem of ensembling deep neural networks for image classification. The authors propose to ensemble a small number of deep neural network layers for the task of image classification, where there are only a few labeled examples per class and the goal is to improve the sample efficiency of the model. The paper is well - written and well - organized, and the experiments are well - done. However, the paper suffers from a lack of novelty and there are many details missing that would be helpful for the reader.

This paper proposes a method to improve the performance of binary neural networks ( BNNs ) by using positive 0 / 1 binary weights, instead of the - 1 / - 1 weights used by state - of - the - art binary networks. The proposed method is based on sparsity, which is a technique to reduce the number of operations and parameters at inference time. Experiments are conducted on CIFAR-10 and MNIST datasets to validate the effectiveness of the method.

This paper proposes a post hoc calibration method for estimating the probability that a model prediction is correct for out - of - distribution ( OOD ) data. The method uses outlier exposure to properly calibrate the model probabilities. The baseline method for predictive uncertainty is to simply use the softmax probabilities of the model, p(p(x ) = softmax ( f(f(f ) ) ), as a surrogate for class membership probabilities ( Hendrycks & Gimpel, 2017 ). The proposed method significantly improves on benchmark results ( Ovadia et al., 2019 ) on a wide range of corrupted data.

Graph neural networks and graph kernels have achieved great success in solving machine learning problems on graphs. This paper studies the expressive power of graph neural networks from an empirical perspective. The authors compare the graph representations and similarities produced by these algorithms against those generated by a wellaccepted, but intractable graph similarity function. The results reveal interesting findings.

This paper proposes a new image generation method for self - supervised image animation. The proposed method first warps the source image according to the motion of the driving video and recovers the warping artifacts by inpainting. The authors use the occlusion information in image animation to regularize discriminator predictions on the in -painting process. The augmented image has smooth transitions without loss or mixture of context.

This paper considers the problem of learning independent causal mechanisms ( ICM ), which directly model multiple data generation processes ( mechanisms ) in a coarse granularity. The authors propose to learn a model that disentangles each mechanism and approximates the groundtruth mechanisms from observational data using a single self - supervised generative model with an unconventional mixture prior, simplifying previous methods. They prove the identifiability of their model w.r.t the mechanisms in the self - supervised scenario. They compare their approach to disentangled representations on various downstream tasks, showing that their approach is more robust to intervention.

This paper studies the problem of predicting chemical compound graphs from 2D images. The authors propose a graph aligning approach that generates rich or detailed labels given normal labels in the target domain. The proposed method is evaluated on the Maybridge data set and achieves higher performance than the current state - of - the - art.

This paper studies the problem of energy optimization in the context of chiller systems. The authors propose to use a domain knowledge based deep learning framework to solve the chiller plants energy optimization problems. The main contribution of this paper is to design a neural network with monotonic constraints to mimic the physical behavior of the system. The proposed method is evaluated on a cooling system of a data center, and the experimental results show the superiority of the proposed framework in energy optimization compared to the existing ones.

This paper proposes a causal spatio - temporal fusion transformer method for multi - task multi - horizon forecasting. The proposed method is based on the Conditional Average Treatment Effect ( CATE ) estimation method in causal inference. The authors conduct a wide range of experiments to demonstrate the interpretability of causal attention, the effectiveness of various components, and the time efficiency of the proposed CausalTrans framework. The experimental results show that the proposed framework can achieve up to 15 % error reduction compared with various baseline methods.

This paper proposes a method to identify a mixture of discrete and continuous factors of variability that can help unravel complex phenomena. The authors propose an unsupervised framework called coupled mixture VAE ( cpl - mixVAE ), which utilizes multiple interacting autoencoding agents. The individual agents operate on augmented copies of training samples to learn mixture representations, while being encouraged to reach consensus on the categorical assignments. The paper provides theoretical justification to motivate the use of the multi - agent framework, and formulate it as a variational inference problem. Experiments are conducted on MNIST and dSprites datasets to demonstrate the utility of the proposed method.

This paper provides a general characterization of steerable kernel spaces for any compact group of equivariant convolutional networks ( GCNNs ). In particular, the authors show that kernels that satisfy an equivariance constraint are steerable kernels, which is a generalization of the G - steerability constraint that has only been derived for specific use cases. The authors also provide a characterization for the practically relevant case of G being a compact group. The generalization is motivated by a striking analogy between the underlying steerability kernels on one hand and spherical tensor operators from quantum mechanics on the other hand.

This paper studies the effect of selective classification on accuracy disparities between different groups in the presence of spurious correlations. The authors study the margin distribution, which captures the model ’s confidences over all predictions, and show that increasing abstentions can even decrease accuracies on some groups. They also show that selective classification uniformly improves each group on these models.   The paper is well - written and easy to follow.

This paper proposes a hierarchical non - negative CANDECOMP / PARAFAC decomposition ( Hierarchical NCPD ) model and a training method, Neural NCPD, for performing hierarchical topic modeling on multi - modal tensor data. The proposed method utilizes a neural network architecture and backpropagation to mitigate error propagation through hierarchical NCPD. The paper is well - written and easy to follow.

This paper proposes a new adversarial robustness certificate for graph neural networks ( GNNs ). The key idea is to fuse multiple single - node certificates into a drastically stronger collective certificate, which computes the number of predictions that are simultaneously guaranteed to remain stable under perturbation, i.e. can not be attacked. The proposed method is based on Graph Neural Networks and leverage their locality property – perturbations only affect the predictions in a close neighborhood – to improve the robustness of the proposed method. Experiments are conducted on node classification, image segmentation, and named - entity recognition.

This paper studies the problem of training generative adversarial networks ( GANs ) in the presence of non - convergence problem, mode collapse, gradient explosion and vanishing. The authors propose a novel approach in modification of loss functions for the improvement of GAN training. The proposed method is based on Quantile Regression GAN ( QRGAN ). Experiments are conducted to evaluate the discriminator and discriminator space of discriminator.

This paper studies relevance metrics for explaining the predictions made by machine learning models. Several relevance metrics are used in machine learning explanations, including cosine similarity of the gradients of the loss. The authors conduct a set of experiments to evaluate whether the relevance metrics satisfy the minimal requirements for similarity - based explanation. The results show that cosine - similarity is the best choice, which would be a recommended choice in practice. Some metrics perform poorly in the experiments and the authors analyze the reasons of their failure.

This paper proposes to add a low - rank global attention module to Graph Neural Networks ( GNNs ) for improving their generalization power. The proposed module is a computation and memory efficient variant of the dot - product attention ( DPA ) module. The paper theoretically evaluates the generalization properties of the proposed module on the graph isomorphism test, namely the 2 - FWL algorithm. Experimental results show that augmenting various GNN architectures with LRGA often closes the performance gap between different models.

This paper proposes a novel approach to classification that combines the idea of objectness and label smoothing during training to improve the calibration performance of convolutional neural networks ( CNNs ). The authors propose to compute a smoothing factor that is adaptive based on the relative object size within an image, instead of relying on the context to make the correct predictions. They show qualitative results using class activation maps and quantitative results using classification and transfer learning tasks using ImageNet.

This paper proposes a two - layer ReLU denoising network that is amenable to convex optimization. The convex dual network not only offers the optimum training with convex solvers, but also facilitates interpreting training and prediction. A range of experiments with MNIST and fastMRI datasets confirm the efficacy of the dual network optimization problem.

This paper presents an end - to - end speech synthesis pipeline that synthesizes speech from normalised text or phonemes in an end to end manner, resulting in models which operate directly on character or phoneme input sequences and produce raw speech audio outputs. The proposed generator is feed - forward and thus efficient for both training and inference, using a differentiable alignment scheme based on token length prediction. It learns to produce high fidelity audio through a combination of adversarial feedback and prediction losses constraining the generated audio to roughly match the ground truth in terms of its total duration and mel - spectrogram - based prediction loss. The resulting model achieves a mean - expectation score exceeding 4 on a 5 - point scale, which is comparable to the state - of - the - art models.

This paper proposes a general non - parametric framework to address the problem of node representation learning in real - world graphs with missing attributes. The key idea is to decompose the attribute matrix into discrete distributions in a lower - dimensional space equipped with the Wasserstein metric. On this space, a graph diffusion method is proposed to smooth the distribution representations of nodes with information from their local neighborhoods. This allows to reduce the distortion caused by missing attributes and obtain integrated representations expressing information of both topology structure and attributes. To show the power of the proposed representation method, the authors designed two algorithms : one for node classification ( missing attributes ) and matrix completion respectively, and demonstrate their effectiveness in experiments.

This paper proposes a method for reinforcement learning in environments with sparse extrinsic rewards in the absence of ( or alongside ) environment reward. The teacher is a goal - generating teacher that proposes Adversarially Motivated Intrinsic GOals ( AMIGO ) to train the goal - conditioned “ student policy ”. The proposed method learns to propose increasingly challenging ( yet achievable ) GOALS that allow the student to learn general skills for acting in a new environment, independent of the task to be solved. The experiments show that the proposed method generates a natural curriculum of self - -proposed GOALS which ultimately allows the agent to solve challenging procedurally - generated tasks.

This paper studies the problem of information retrieval from a dataset of files stored on a single server under both a user distortion and a user privacy constraint. Specifically, a user requesting a file from the dataset should be able to reconstruct the requested file with a prescribed distortion, and in addition, the identity of the user should be kept private from the server. The proposed model can be seen as an extension of the well - known concept of private information retrieval by allowing for distortion in the retrieval process and relaxing the perfect privacy requirement. The paper evaluates the performance of the proposed model on a synthetic Gaussian dataset as well as on the MNIST and CIFAR - 10 datasets.

This paper proposes a method to accelerate the training of graph neural networks ( GNNs ). The main idea is to decompose the GNN into smaller modules and associate each module with a greedy auxiliary objective. The proposed method is evaluated on a number of benchmark datasets and compared to other sampling - based GNN training methods. The authors also propose a lazy update scheme during training to further improve its efficiency.

This paper proposes a framework for efficiently answering complex queries on incomplete Knowledge Graphs. The authors translate each query into an end - to - end differentiable objective, where the truth value of each atom is computed by a pre - trained neural link predictor. They then analyse two solutions to the optimisation problem, including gradient - based and combinatorial search. The proposed approach produces more accurate results than state - of - the - art methods without the need of training.

This paper proposes a fast procedure for checking local robustness in neural networks with piecewise - linear activation functions. The key idea is to partition the input space into a set of convex polyhedral regions in which the network ’s behavior is linear, and a systematic search for decision boundaries within the regions around a given input is sufficient for assessing robustness. The authors show how the region around a point can be analyzed using simple geometric projections, thus admitting an efficient, highly - parallel GPU implementation that excels particularly for the `2 norm.

This paper presents an approach to embedding objects in an affordance space, in which each dimension corresponds to an aspect of meaning shared by many actions, using text corpora. This embedding makes it possible to predict which verbs will be applicable to a given object, as captured in human judgments of affordance, better than a variety of alternative approaches. The dimensions learned are interpretable, and that they correspond to typical patterns of interaction with objects, derived purely from human judgements. Finally, the dimensions can be used to predict a state - of - the - art ability to interact with objects.

This paper proposes a method for the emergence of individualism in multi - agent reinforcement learning ( MARL ). The proposed method is based on a classifier that predicts a probability distribution over agents given their observation and gives each agent an intrinsic reward of being correctly predicted by the classifier. Two regularizers are also proposed to increase the discriminability of the classifiers. Empirically, the authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods in a variety of MARL scenarios.

This paper proposes an ensembling - based randomized smoothing method to improve the certified robustness of classifiers against adversarial attacks. The proposed method is based on an ensemble of models that are trained to be the base classifier for the smoothed classifier. The authors also propose an adaptive prediction algorithm to reduce the prediction and certification cost of the proposed SWEEN models. Extensive experiments show that the proposed method outperforms the upper envelope of their corresponding candidate models by a large margin.

This paper proposes a method to discover subtask hierarchy by learning from demonstration data. The method is based on the inductive bias of learning from demonstrations. The proposed method can be applied to task decomposition to recover the subtask boundaries in an unstructured demonstration. Experiments on Craft and Dial datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a causal semantic generative model for out - of - distribution ( OOD ) prediction. The proposed model is based on the causal invariance principle, with a novel design in variational Bayes for both efficient learning and easy prediction. Under certain conditions, the proposed model can identify the semantic factor by fitting training data, and this semantic - identification guarantees the boundedness of OOD performance over prevailing baselines.

This paper studies the problem of robustness of online learning algorithms to adversarially corrupted rewards in the stochastic multi - armed bandits setting. In particular, the authors consider the setting where an online algorithm makes a prediction at each time step, and receives a reward from the environment that can be arbitrarily corrupted with probability $ \mathcal{O}(\sqrt{0,12 } \in [ 0,0]$. The authors propose to design robust online algorithms with near optimal regret in three different scenarios. The proposed algorithms are evaluated on synthetic and real - world datasets.

This paper proposes a novel framework for neural machine translation ( NMT ). The proposed framework consists of a rewriter and an evaluator. The rewriter produces a new translation to improve the past translation and the evaluators estimates the translation quality to decide whether to terminate the rewriting process. The authors also propose a prioritized gradient descent ( PGD ) method to train the rewriter. The experiments on two translation tasks, Chinese - English and English - German show that the proposed framework notably improves the performances of NMT models and significantly outperforms previous baselines.

This paper proposes a two - stage approach to learn a multimodal predictive distribution for semantic segmentation. In the first stage, the authors explicitly model the data with a categorical likelihood, and in the second stage, they train an adversarial network to sample from it an arbitrary number of coherent predictions. The empirical frequency of the sampled predictions closely reflects that of the corresponding labels in the training set. Experiments are conducted on the multigrader LIDC dataset and a modified Cityscapes dataset to show the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

This paper proposes a new and theoretically and practically better alternative to error feedback ( EF ) for dealing with contractive compressors. The authors propose a construction which can transform any contractive compressor into an induced unbiased compressor. They further extend their results to federated learning with partial participation following an arbitrary distribution over the nodes, and demonstrate the benefits thereof.

This paper studies the problem of hyperparameter transfer across adjustments ( HT - AA ) in machine learning ( ML ) algorithms. In particular, the authors propose a new research framework, HT - AAA, to leverage knowledge from previous development steps to speed up a new HPO. They provide four simple baseline algorithms and eight benchmarks to evaluate the performance of existing HPO algorithms. They also provide python packages for their baselines and benchmarks.

This paper studies the effect of label representation on the performance of image classifiers. The authors propose to use constant matrices, spectrograms, shuffled spectrogram, Gaussian mixtures, and uniform random matrices of various dimensionalities to represent data labels. They show that high dimensional, high entropy label representations are generally more useful because they provide a stronger error signal. The experiments are conducted on the standard image classification task, but also on various adversarial attacks and better effectiveness with a limited amount of training data.

This paper proposes a new method for ensemble neural network prediction. The main idea is to use a multi - input multi - output ( MIMO ) configuration to train multiple subnetworks that independently learn the task at hand. By ensembling the predictions made by the sub - networks, the proposed method improves model robustness and uncertainty performance without increasing computational cost. The proposed method is evaluated on a number of datasets, including CIFAR-10, ImageNet, and calibration error.

This paper proposes a method to transfer intermediate knowledge obtained from one Convolutional Neural Network ( CNN ) to another by utilizing sparse representation learning. The proposed method first extracts sparse representations of the hidden features of the teacher CNN, which are then used to generate both pixellevel and image - level labels for training intermediate feature maps of the student network. The experiments demonstrate that SRM is robust to architectural differences between the teacher and student networks, and outperforms other KD techniques across several datasets.

This paper proposes a method for learning policies that generalize to unseen environments. The authors introduce a theoretically motivated policy similarity metric ( PSM ) for measuring behavioral similarity between states. They also present a contrastive representation learning procedure to embed any state similarity metric to obtain policy similarity embeddings ( PSEs1 ). They demonstrate that PSEs improve generalization on diverse benchmarks, including LQR with spurious correlations, a jumping task from pixels, and Distracting DM Control.

This paper studies the problem of disentangling natural factors of variation in data ( e.g. object shape vs pose ) from the latent space of a model ’s latent representation. The authors propose a distributed equivariant approach to disentanglement based on affine transformations. They show that this approach is more flexible than previous methods that map each of these factors to distinct subspaces of the model's latent space. They also demonstrate the effectiveness of their approach on a wide range of image transformations.

This paper proposes a framework for estimating the interaction of neurons in the Hawkes process. The framework is based on the nonlinear Hawkes Process, which allows for a more flexible influence pattern with excitatory or inhibitory interactions. Three sets of auxiliary latent variables ( Pólya - Gamma variables, latent marked Poisson processes and sparsity variables ) are augmented to make functional connection weights in a Gaussian form. An efficient expectationmaximization ( EM ) algorithm is derived to obtain the maximum a posteriori ( MAP ) estimate. Experiments are conducted on synthetic and real neural recordings.

This paper studies the gradient descent ( GD ) algorithm for training two - layer neural network models in the under - parameterized regime. It finds that there are two distinctive phases in the GD dynamics in this regime : An early phase in which the dynamics follows closely that of the corresponding random feature model, followed by a late phase when the neurons are divided into two groups : a group of a few “ activated ” neurons that dominate the dynamics and another group of “ quenched “ neurons that support the continued activation and deactivation process. In particular, when the target function can be accurately approximated by a relatively small number of neurons, this quenching - activation process biases GD to picking sparse solutions.

This paper proposes to decompose the constrained Markov decision process ( CMDP ) problem into a pair of MDPs : reconnaissance MDP and planning MDP. In R - MDP, the authors train threat function, the Q - function analogue of danger that can determine whether a given state - action pair is safe or not. In P - PDP, they train a reward - seeking policy while using a fixed threat function to determine the safeness of each action. The authors also present an efficient approximation method for the threat function that can greatly reduce the difficulty of solving R - RDP. The proposed method is evaluated on benchmark dataset and complex collision - free navigation tasks.

This paper studies the effect of training neural architectures for classification tasks on cross - entropy loss and square loss. It shows that the square loss outperforms the cross - entropy loss in the dominant majority of NLP and ASR experiments. The paper also shows that training with square loss for classification needs to be a part of best practices of modern deep learning on equal footing.

This paper proposes a self - supervised reinforcement learning method for deep reinforcement learning ( RL ). The proposed method is based on self - predictive representation learning ( SPR ), which trains an agent to predict its own latent state representations multiple steps into the future using an encoder which is an exponential moving average of the agent ’s parameters and a learned transition model. The method achieves a median human - humanized score of 0.415 on Atari in a setting limited to 100k steps of environment interaction, which represents a 55 % relative improvement over the previous state - of - the - art methods.

This paper studies the problem of local node embedding, i.e., learning compact representations of graphs using local PageRank computations. In particular, the paper proposes a new method, called InstantEmbedding, to compute the embedding vector for each node in a given graph in sublinear time. The paper provides theoretical guarantees on the locality of the computation, as well as the proof of the global consistency of the generated embeddings. Empirical results on real - world datasets with over a billion edges are provided to show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

Graph coarsening is a popular technique to reduce the size of a graph while maintaining its properties. This paper proposes a framework for measuring the quality of graph coarsing algorithms and shows that depending on the goal, we need to carefully choose the Laplace operator on the coarse graph and associated projection / lift operators. Motivated by the observation that the current choice of edge weight for the coarse graphs may be suboptimal, the authors propose to parametrize the weight assignment map with graph neural networks and train it to improve the coarsened quality in an unsupervised way. Extensive experiments on both synthetic and real networks are conducted to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper presents a geometric deep learning algorithm for estimating the scattering properties of 3D objects. The authors use a point cloud approximation of each object, and each point is encoded in a high - dimensional latent space. The proposed method can accurately estimate these acoustic properties for arbitrary topologies and takes less than 1ms per object on a NVIDIA GeForce 2080 Ti GPU.   The authors also prove that their learning method is permutation and rotation invariant and demonstrate high accuracy on objects that are quite different from the training data.

This paper studies the problem of distributional shift in machine learning. The authors propose a new method, Risk Extrapolation ( REx ), to address distributional shifts in the real world. They show that reducing differences in risk across training domains can reduce a model ’s sensitivity to a wide range of distributionsal shifts. They motivate this approach as a form of robust optimization over a perturbation set of extrapolated domains ( MMREx ). They also propose a penalty on the variance of training risks as a simpler variant.

This paper proposes a neural operator for solving the Burgers equation, the Darcy flow, and the Navier - Stokes equation. The Fourier neural operator is the first ML - based method to successfully model turbulent flows with zero - shot super - resolution. It is up to three orders of magnitude faster compared to traditional PDE solvers and achieves superior accuracy compared to previous learning - based solvers under fixed resolution.

This paper studies the implicit bias of gradient flow ( gradient descent with infinitesimal step size ) on linear neural network training. The authors propose a tensor formulation of neural networks that includes fully - connected, diagonal, and convolutional networks as special cases. For L - layer linear tensor networks that are orthogonally decomposable, the authors show that gradient flow on separable classification finds a stationary point of the `2 / L max - margin problem in a “ transformed input space ” defined by the network. For underdetermined regression, the paper proves that the gradient flow finds a global minimum which minimizes a norm - like function that minimizes between weighted `1 and `2 norms in the transformed input space.

This paper studies the problem of optimizing the width - multipliers across different layers of a slimmable neural network for mobile devices. The authors propose to optimize the width multipliers of different layers jointly with the weights of the weights for the network weights. The proposed method is evaluated on the ImageNet dataset and the MobileNetV2 dataset. The results show that the proposed method can improve the performance of the network up to 1.7 % and 8 % in top - 1 accuracy and memory footprint, respectively.

This paper studies the problem of federated semi - supervised learning ( FSSL ), where data obtained at the client - side often comes without any accompanying labels. The authors study two essential scenarios of FSSL based on the location of the labeled data. The first scenario considers a conventional case where clients have both labeled and unlabeled data ( labels - at - client ), and the second scenario is a more challenging case, where labeled data is only available at the server. Experiments are conducted to validate the proposed method in the two different scenarios.

This paper proposes a method for self - supervised learning on discrete event sequences generated by real - world users. The key idea is to use contrastive learning, previously used for audio and computer vision domains, to the discrete event sequence domain in a self - supervision setting. Unlike most previous studies, the authors theoretically justify under mild conditions that the augmentation method underlying CoLES provides representative samples of discrete events sequences. The authors evaluate CoLES on several public datasets and show that the representations consistently outperform other methods on different downstream tasks.

This paper proposes a method for unsupervised parsing of natural language. The authors introduce a new model, StructFormer, that can induce dependency and constituency structure at the same time. They integrate the induced dependency relations into transformer, in a differentiable manner, through a dependency - constrained self - attention mechanism. The experimental results show that the proposed method can achieve strong results on un - supervised constituency parsing, un - supervision dependency parsing, and masked language modeling.

This paper proposes a method for learning the mapping between scene graph nodes and visual objects under weak supervision. The proposed method learns a metric among visual objects and scene graph node by incorporating information from both object features and relational features. Extensive experiments on Visual Genome ( VG ) and Visual Relation Detection ( VRD ) datasets verify that the proposed method achieves an improvement on scene graph grounding task over current state - of - the - art approaches. Further experiments on scene graphs parsing task verify the grounding found by the method can reinforce the performance of the existing method.

This paper proposes two variants of the RAE framework to improve its performance. The first variant, named mixture spherical fused sliced fused Gromov Wasserstein ( PSSFG ) replaces the v - mises - fisher distribution by a mixture of von Mises - Fisher distributions to capture multiple important areas of directions that are far from each other. The second variant is a power spherical spherical distribution to improve the sampling time in high dimension settings. The authors conduct extensive experiments to show that the new proposed autoencoders have favorable performance in learning latent manifold structure, image generation, and reconstruction.

This paper proposes a simple approach to speed up training for a particular kind of deep networks which contain repeated structures, such as the transformer module. The authors first train such a deep network with the weights shared across all the repeated layers till some point, then stop weight sharing and continue training until convergence. The untying point is automatically determined by monitoring gradient statistics. The adaptive untying criterion is obtained from a theoretic analysis over deep linear networks. Empirical results show that the proposed method is able to reduce the training time of BERT by 50 %.

This paper studies the interaction inside adversarial perturbations to explain and boost the adversarial transferability. The authors prove a negative correlation between the transferability and interaction inside perturbation. They further prove that some classic methods of enhancing the transferable transferability essentially decease interactions inside adversarially perturbated data. Based on this, the authors propose to directly penalize interactions during the attacking process, which significantly improves the adversarian transferability by directly penalizing interactions.

This paper studies the role of different layers of deep neural networks in the problem of catastrophic forgetting. The authors find that the deeper layers are disproportionately responsible for forgetting, with sequential training resulting in an erasure of earlier task representational subspaces. They then propose several methods to mitigate forgetting stabilize these deeper layers, but show diversity on precise effects, with some increasing feature reuse while others store task representations orthogonally, preventing interference. They also provide an analytic argument and empirical picture relating forgetting to task semantic similarity, and show that maximal forgetting occurs for task sequences with intermediate similarity.

This paper proposes a new training algorithm for BERT language models. The main contribution of the paper is a general computationally - efficient training algorithm applicable to both pre - training and fine - tuning of large - scale language models, which is inspired by the Early - Bird Lottery Tickets recently studied for computer vision tasks. The proposed method is evaluated on GLUE and SQuAD downstream tasks and achieves comparable performance to standard BERT, with 35 % less training time.

This paper studies the robustness of f - divergence measures in the presence of label noise. The authors derive a nice decoupling property for f - divergence measures when label noise presents, where the divergence is shown to be a linear combination of the variational difference defined on the clean distribution and a bias term introduced due to the noise. This property is then used to analyze different f - Divergence functions for the problem of learning with noisy labels. When they are possibly not robust, the authors propose fixes to make them so.

This paper proposes a method for off - policy deep reinforcement learning ( RL ) based on weighted ensemble - based weighted Bellman backups, which re - weights target Q - values based on uncertainty estimates from a Q - ensemble. The proposed method stabilizes and improves learning on both continuous and discrete control benchmarks. The authors also investigate the signal - to - noise aspect by studying environments with noisy rewards, and find that the weighted bellman backups significantly outperform standard Bellman backup methods.

This paper studies the problem of few - shot classification in the context of meta - learning. The authors propose a simple yet effective method to predict the uncertainty of the task uncertainty. The method is algorithm - agnostic and can be extended to include a range of models. Experiments show that the proposed method can produce calibrated classification results without the loss of accuracy.

This paper proposes a novel method for learning video - text - to - video representation learning. The key idea is to use a generative model to naturally push the related samples together. Each sample ’s caption must be reconstructed as a weighted combination of other support samples ’ visual representations. This simple idea ensures that representations are not overly - specialized to individual samples, are reusable across the dataset, and results in representations that explicitly encode semantics shared between samples.

This paper studies the problem of pre - training a pre - trained language model ( PLMs ) for Chinese natural language processing ( NLP ) tasks, where the vocabulary for these Chinese PLMs remains to be the one provided by Google Chinese Bert Devlin et al. ( 2018 ), which is based on Chinese characters. The authors propose a novel method, seg tok, to form the vocabulary of Chinese BERT, with the help of Chinese word segmentation ( CWS ) and subword tokenization. They also propose three versions of multi - vocabulary pretraining ( MVP ) to improve the models expressiveness. Experiments show that the proposed method does not only improve the performances of PLMs on sentence level tasks, but also improve the downstream task performance.

This paper proposes a method for distributed training of graph convolutional networks ( GCNs ). The proposed method is based on the idea of partitioning the GCN into subgraphs, where each subgraph is partitioned into a set of boundary nodes. Each boundary node is sampled according to its similarity to the previous boundary node in the subgraph. The authors claim that the proposed method can increase the throughput by up to 500 % and reduce the memory usage by up - to 58 % for distributed GCN training, while maintaining the full - graph accuracy.

This paper presents a graph neural network ( GNN ) based machine learning ( ML ) model for atomic chemistry simulations. The main contribution of the paper is the use of graph neural networks to estimate per - atom forces, which is a central capability for performing atomic simulations. Experiments are conducted on the large - scale catalyst dataset, where the proposed model is able to achieve 4x higher success rate than existing ML models.

This paper presents a generalization bound for deep neural networks based on Rademacher complexity. This bound has no direct dependence on the number of weights and compares favourably to other generalization bounds when applied to convolutional networks. Based on this bound, the authors propose a simple yet effective fine - tuning algorithm that constrains the hypothesis class to a small sphere centred on the initial pre - trained weights, thus obtaining provably better generalisation performance than conventional transfer learning. Empirical evaluation shows that the proposed algorithm works well.

This paper studies the phenomenon of decoupling the hyperparameters for mask discovery ( Hfind ) and mask evaluation ( Heval ) in the context of unstructured magnitude pruning. The authors claim that the decoupled find - evaluate phenomenon is a counterintuitive phenomenon, in which certain Hfind values lead to models which have lower performance, but generate masks with substantially higher eventual performance compared to using the same hyperparameter for both stages. The paper also provides clear insights into the mechanisms underlying this counterintuitive effect.

This paper proposes a new metric, called m - coherence, to study the alignment of per - example gradients during training. The metric is based on the observation that the number of examples that benefit from a small step along the gradient of any one example on average is higher than the average of all the examples. The authors show that the metric is more interpretable, cheaper to compute, and mathematically cleaner than other commonly used metrics. The paper also provides a detailed analysis of this phenomenon and provides a deeper confirmation of generalization.

This paper studies the problem of constructing summary statistics for implicit generative models where the evaluation of the likelihood function is intractable but sampling data from the model is possible. The authors frame the task of constructing sufficient statistics as learning mutual information maximizing representations of the data with the help of deep neural networks. They apply their approach to both approximate Bayesian computation and recent neural likelihood methods, boosting their performance on a range of tasks.

This paper proposes a new image - to - image translation model that is fully unsupervised, i.e., neither paired images nor domain labels are used in the task of image to image translation. The proposed model simultaneously learns to separate image domains and translate input images into the estimated domains. The experimental results show that the proposed model achieves comparable or better performance than the set - level supervised model trained with full labels, generalizes well on various datasets, and is robust against the choice of hyperparameters.

This paper studies gradient descent training of wide neural networks and the corresponding implicit bias in function space. For 1D regression, the authors show that the solution of training a width - n shallow ReLU network is within n-1 / 2 of the function which fits the training data and whose difference from initialization has smallest 2 - norm of the weighted second derivative with respect to the input. The curvature penalty function 1/ζ is expressed in terms of the probability distribution that is utilized to initialize the network parameters and the authors compute it explicitly for various common initialization procedures. Moreover, the training trajectories are captured by trajectories of spatially adaptive smoothing splines with decreasing regularization strength.

This paper studies the problem of weight decay in deep neural network training. The authors argue that the L2 regularization is unstable for all gradient - descent methods, and that the decoupled weight decay is highly unstable for adaptive gradient methods. They propose a new method to fix the unstable weight decay problem, and show that the proposed method achieves significant improvements over the existing methods.

This paper proposes a novel method to combine the strengths of both Translation Memory ( TM ) and Neural Machine Translation ( NMT ). The authors treat the matched sentence pair of TM as the additional signal and apply one encoder enhanced by the pre - trained language model ( PLM ) to encode the TM information and source sentence together. Additionally, the authors extend the sentence level retrieval method to the n - gram retrieval method. The proposed methods are validated on a mixed test set of multiple domains.

This paper studies the problem of learning deep convolutional networks from the perspective of rate reduction and shift invariant classification. The authors show that the basic iterative gradient ascent scheme for maximizing the rate reduction of learned features naturally leads to a deep network, one iteration per layer. The architectures, operators ( linear or non - linear ), and parameters of the network are all explicitly constructed layer - by - layer in a forward propagation fashion. The experiments show that such a network can already learn a good discriminative deep representation without any back propagation training.

This paper studies the implicit acceleration of gradient flow in two - layer linear models. The authors show that implicit acceleration emerges from a conservation law that constrains the dynamics to follow certain trajectories. More precisely, gradient flow preserves the difference of the Gramian matrices of the input and output weights and the amount of acceleration depends on both the magnitude of that difference ( which is fixed at initialization ) and the spectrum of the data.

This paper studies the problem of explainable machine learning ( ML ) models. The authors propose a framework called CLIME to improve the quality of the explanations generated by LIME. The proposed framework is based on uniform sampling of user - defined subspaces. The main contribution of the paper is an estimation algorithm to measure the true value of metrics such as fidelity up to any desired degree of accuracy, which can help in building trust in the generated explanations. Extensive experiments demonstrate its versatility on real - world problems.

This paper proposes a multi - grained language model ( AMBERT ) for natural language understanding ( NLU ). The proposed model is based on fine - grain tokenization and uses a sequence of contextualized representations of the words and phrases. Experiments are conducted on benchmark datasets for Chinese and English, including CLUE, GLUE, SQuAD and RACE. The results show that the proposed model outperforms the existing best performing models in almost all cases.

This paper proposes a new Transformer architecture for semantic parsing. The main idea is to incorporate Long Short - Term Memory ( LSTM ) into the Self - Attention mechanism of the original Transformer to capture more local context of phrases. Experimental results show that the proposed model captures the detailed meaning better than Transformer and raises local context awareness.

This paper proposes a method for improving the robustness of deep neural networks ( DNNs ) against the combinations of multiple adversarial perturbations. The authors propose a method called composite adversarial training ( CAT ), which integrates and optimizes multiple perturbation losses, leading to significant robustness improvement with respect to individual perturbated models as well as their “ compositions ”. The method is evaluated on benchmark datasets and models, and the results show that CAT outperforms existing adversarial learning methods by large margins in defending against the compositions of pixel perturbedations and spatial transformations.

This paper presents a method for learning rules using a recurrent network augmented with an external memory that enables a form of variable - binding and indirection. This binding mechanism allows symbol - like representations to emerge through the learning process without the need to explicitly incorporate symbol - processing machinery, enabling the ESBN to learn rules in a manner that is abstracted away from the particular entities to which those rules apply. Experiments are conducted on a small number of domains to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new framework, Translation between Augmented Natural Languages ( TANL ), to solve many structured prediction language tasks including joint entity and relation extraction, nested named entity recognition, relation classification, semantic role labeling, event extraction, coreference resolution, and dialogue state tracking. Instead of tackling the problem by training task - specific discriminative classifiers, this paper frames it as a translation task between augmented natural languages, from which the task - relevant information can be easily extracted. The proposed framework can match or outperform task specific models on all tasks, and in particular, achieves new state - of - the - art results on joint entity extraction ( CoNLL04, ADE, NYT, and ACE2005 datasets ), relation classifications ( FewRel and TACRED ), and semantic roles labeling (CoNLL-2005 and CoNILL2012 ).

This paper studies the problem of unlabeled entity problem in the NER model, where the entities of a sentence may not be fully annotated. The authors propose a general approach, which can almost eliminate the misguidance brought by unlabeling entities. The key idea is to use negative sampling that, to a large extent, avoids training NER models. Experiments on synthetic datasets and real - world datasets show that the proposed approach is competitive with the state - of - the - art method.

This paper proposes a novel acoustic word embedding called Acoustic Neighbor Embeddings where speech or text of arbitrary length are mapped to a vector space of fixed, reduced dimensions by adapting stochastic neighbor embedding (SNE ) to sequential inputs. The Euclidean distance between coordinates in the embedding space reflects the phonetic confusability between their corresponding sequences.
