Two encoder neural networks are trained : an acoustic encoder that accepts speech signals in the form of frame - wise subword posterior probabilities obtained from an acoustic model and a text encoders that accepts text in the forms of subword transcriptions. The proposed method is shown to have more effective gradients for neural network training and also gives more accurate results with low - dimensional embeddings.

This paper proposes a reinforcement learning algorithm for stationary mean - field games, where the goal is to learn a pair of means - field state and stationary policy that constitutes the Nash equilibrium. The authors propose a fictitious play algorithm which alternatively updates the mean - fields state and the policy via gradient - centred and proximal policy optimization, respectively. The proposed algorithm is in stark contrast with previous literature which solves each single - agent reinforcement learning problem induced by the iterates mean -field states to the optimum. Furthermore, the authors prove that the proposed algorithm converges to the Nash - equilibrium at a sublinear rate.

This paper proposes a framework for approximate probabilistic inference on joint distribution defined by a normalizing flow model. The framework trains a new generative model with the property that its composition with the given model approximates the target conditional distribution. By parametrizing this new distribution as another flow model, the authors can efficiently train it using variational inference and also handle conditioning under arbitrary differentiable transformations. The authors provide an extensive empirical evidence showcasing the flexibility of their method on a variety of inference tasks with applications to inverse problems.

This paper introduces a new dataset for cell membrane segmentation. The dataset is the largest annotated Electron Microscopy ( EM ) dataset for the Cell membrane with multiple iterative annotations and uncompressed high - resolution raw data. During the analysis process of the U - RISC, the authors found that the current popular segmentation evaluation criteria are inconsistent with human perception. To resolve this inconsistency, they propose a new evaluation criterion called Per Per Percahd Distance ( P - PHD ) to measure the quality of the segmentation results.

This paper proposes a new benchmark for continual learning ( CL ). The benchmark is based on the Benchmarking Benchmark for Continual Learning ( BCL ) dataset. The paper also proposes a modular architecture for continuous learning, where modules represent atomic skills that can be composed to perform a certain task. The learning algorithm leverages a task - driven prior over the exponential search space of all possible ways to combine modules, enabling efficient learning on long streams of tasks. The experiments show that this modular architecture and learning algorithm perform competitively on widely used CL benchmarks while yielding superior performance on the more challenging benchmarks.

This paper proposes a generative generative model - based unsupervised meta - learning method for few - shot classification tasks. The proposed method generates pairs of in - class and out - of - class samples from the latent space in a principled way, allowing it to create synthetic classes to form the training and validation data of a meta - task. The authors evaluate the proposed method on several benchmark datasets and show that it outperforms or is competitive with existing un - supervised learning baselines on the most widely used benchmark datasets.

This paper studies the injectivity of neural networks in the context of inverse and inference problems.   The authors show that injectivity is a function of the depth of the network and the width of the layerwise weight matrix. They show that injecting a network requires a margin of injectivity between 3.4 and 10.5. They also show that an injective network can be inverted using the worst - case Lipschitz constant of the inverse problem. Finally, they show that the weight matrices of a neural network with iid Gaussian matrices are injective when the width is between 3 and 10.

This paper proposes the continuous conditional generative adversarial network ( CcGAN ), the first generative model for image generation conditional on continuous, scalar conditions ( regression labels ). The paper proposes a new benchmark dataset, RC - 49, is also proposed for generative image modeling conditional on regression labels. The experiments on the Circular 2 - D Gaussians, RC-49, and UTKFace datasets show that the proposed model is able to generate diverse, high - quality samples from the image distribution conditional on a given regression label.

This paper studies the problem of active learning ( AL ) and semi - supervised learning ( SSL ) in the context of deep learning. The authors propose an active learning algorithm that actively queries instances to improve the convergence rate of a classification network by actively querying instances to increase the rate of convergence upon inclusion to the labeled set. The proposed method is a combination of Active Learning and Semisupervised Learning methods. The experiments show that a deep neural network trained using the combination of the proposed method and a recently proposed SSL algorithm can quickly achieve high performance using far less labeled samples than the original deep learning methods.

This paper proposes a novel federated learning method for distributively training neural network models, where the server orchestrates cooperation between a subset of randomly chosen devices in each round. The authors point out a fundamental dilemma, in that the minima of the local - device level empirical loss are inconsistent with those of the global empirical loss. To resolve this, the authors propose a dynamic regularizer for each device at each round, so that in the limit the global and device solutions are aligned. Empirical results are provided on real and synthetic data as well as analytical results that the proposed scheme leads to efficient training.

This paper proposes a method to accelerate contrastive learning with little or no loss of accuracy. The authors observe that the intermediate loss is a good surrogate of the final similarity between two pairs of images and propose to use it to truncate the backpropagation and update only a part of the parameters for each gradient descent update. Additionally, the authors propose to filter easy regions for each image based on the intermediate losses to filter the easy regions of each image, which further reduces the computational cost. The proposed method is evaluated on ImageNet linear classification and other downstream tasks.

This paper studies the global convergence and global optimality of actor - critic RL algorithms. The main contribution of this paper is to study the single - timestep updates of the actor and critic in the linear function approximation setting, where the critic update is obtained by applying the Bellman evaluation operator only once while the actor is updated in the policy gradient direction computed using the critic. The authors also consider two function approximation settings where both the critic and the actor are represented by linear or deep neural networks.    The authors prove that the actor sequence converges to a globally optimal policy at a sublinear O(K+1/2 ) rate, where K is the number of iterations, for the first time in linear function - approximation settings. The author also prove that under the broader scope of policy optimization with nonlinear function approximation, the actor with deep neural network finds the global optimal policy with sublinear rate.

This paper proposes to represent log files at a few levels of abstraction including field level, log level, and log sequence level. These representations are in vector format and serve as interfaces to downstream applications. The authors use a version of Transformer Networks (TNs ) to encode numerical and textual information that is suitable for log embeddings. The paper shows how a number of log processing applications can be readily solved with their representation.

This paper studies the problem of decomposing deep convolutional neural networks into a sequence of wavelet decompositions. The paper is motivated by the similarities between trained CNN kernels and oriented Gabor filters for addressing this problem. The core idea is to constrain the behavior of convolutionAL layers by splitting them into a succession of wavelets, which are modulated by freely - trained mixture weights. The authors evaluate their approach with three variants of the wavelets decomposition with the AlexNet architecture for image classification as an example.

This paper proposes a coach - player framework to tackle the problem of dynamic team composition in multi - agent teams where agents with different capabilities may join or leave “ on the fly ” without altering the team ’s overarching goals. The authors assume that the players only have a partial view of the environment, while the coach has a complete view. They propose an attention mechanism for both the players and the coach and incorporate a variational objective to regularize learning. They also propose an adaptive communication method to let the coach decide when to communicate with different players. They validate their methods on resource collection tasks in the multi -agent particle environment.

This paper studies the effect of influence functions in deep neural network models on the accuracy of their estimates. The authors conduct extensive experiments on a number of popular datasets, including MNIST, CIFAR-10, and ImageNet. They find that for shallow networks, influence estimates are fairly accurate, while for deeper networks the estimates are often erroneous. They also find that influence estimates can vary significantly depending on the test points, and that influence functions are fragile in general.

This paper studies the connection between pretraining task of next word prediction and downstream task of text classification. The authors hypothesize, and verify empirically, that classification tasks of interest can be reformulated as sentence completion tasks, thus making language modeling a meaningful pre - training task. Theoretical results are provided to show that language models that are pretrained using large text corpora can linearly solve such classification tasks with O( √ ) error, thus demonstrating that doing well on language modeling can be beneficial for downstream tasks. Experiments are conducted to verify various assumptions and theoretical findings.

This paper studies the problem of detecting if data samples are used to train a neural network model. The authors propose to use a novel difficulty score that can be computed for each image, and its computation does not require a training set. The proposed method is shown to achieve high MIA accuracy on an extensive number of benchmarks.

This paper proposes a novel differentiable architecture search method by formulating the continuously relaxed architecture mixing weight as random variables, modeled by Dirichlet distribution. This formulation improves the generalization ability and induces stochasticity that naturally encourages exploration in the search space. The authors also propose a simple yet effective progressive learning scheme that enables searching directly on large - scale tasks, eliminating the gap between search and evaluation phases. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new class of function approximators for low - dimensional but complex functions : multiplicative filter networks. The authors propose and empirically demonstrate that the multiplicative filters work just as well for such problems as ReLU networks or sinusoidal activation networks. In particular, the authors show that these networks avoid traditional compositional depth altogether, and simply multiply together ( linear functions of ) sinusoids or Gabor wavelet functions applied to the input. The experiments are conducted on two datasets : CIFAR-10 and ImageNet.

This paper proposes an intuitive teacher - student scheme to enable gradient - based meta - learning algorithms to explore long horizons by the inner loop. The key idea is to employ a student network to adequately explore the search space of task - specific models ( e.g., by more than ten steps ) and a teacher then takes a “ leap ” to arrive at a high - quality model but also defines a lightweight computation graph for meta - gradients. The approach is generic ; it performs well when applied to four meta - learner algorithms over three tasks : few - shot learning, long - tailed classification, and meta - attack.

This paper proposes a behavior regularization method to tackle the limitations of standard off - policy RL algorithms. The proposed method is based on an analytical upper bound on KL divergence as the behavior regularizor to reduce variance associated with sample based estimations. The paper also proposes a gradient penalty term to the policy evaluation objective to penalize the gradient of the Q value w.r.t the out - of - distribution actions. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms the existing model - free and model - based approaches on offline RL benchmarks.

This paper studies the problem of regularizing and compressing deep neural networks. The authors propose to train both the original and smaller networks together, where the parameters of the smaller network are shared across both the architectures. They prove strong theoretical guarantees on the regularization behavior of the adjoint training paradigm. An extensive empirical evaluation of both the compression and regularization behaviour of adjoint networks is also provided.

This paper studies the problem of exploration in reinforcement learning ( RL ). The authors propose an extension of the greedy RL algorithm, which is a simple extension of greedy that simply repeats the sampled action for a random duration. The main hypothesis is that the main limitation of greedy exploration is its lack of temporal persistence, which limits its ability to escape local optima. To address this limitation, the authors propose a temporally extended form of - greedy. The proposed algorithm is evaluated on a class of distributions inspired by ecological models of animal foraging behaviour, and is shown to improve exploration on a large set of domains.

This paper studies the implicit regularization of gradient flow for matrix factorization. The authors provide theoretical and empirical evidence that gradient flow with infinitesimal initialization is mathematically equivalent to a simple heuristic rank minimization algorithm, Greedy Low - Rank Learning, under some reasonable assumptions. This generalizes the rank - minimization view from previous works to a much broader setting and enables them to construct counter - examples to refute the conjecture from Gunasekar et al. ( 2017 ). The paper also extends the results to the case where depth is deeper than 3.

This paper studies the problem of model patching to improve the robustness of classifiers in the presence of spurious bandages. The authors propose a two - stage framework for improving robustness that encourages the model to be invariant to subgroup differences, and focus on class information shared by subgroups. The first stage learns semantic transformations between subgroup features within a class, and then trains a classifier with data augmentations that deliberately manipulate sub group features. The second stage learns the intra - class, inter - sub - group augmentations, and balances subgroup performance using a theoretically -motivated subgroup consistency. Experiments are conducted on 3 benchmark datasets, with reductions in robust error of up to 33 % relative to the best baseline.

This paper proposes a new classifier, named Rule - based Representation Learner ( RRL ), that automatically learns interpretable non - fuzzy rules for data representation. To train the non - differentiable RRL effectively, the authors project it to a continuous space and propose a novel training method, called Gradient Grafting, that directly optimize the discrete model using gradient descent. Experiments on 9 small and 4 large data sets show that RRL outperforms the competitive approaches, has low complexity, and is rational for its main technical contributions.

This paper proposes a new regret minimization algorithm and its extension for structured environments. The proposed method is based on the invariant risk minimization ( IRM ) framework. The extension adaptively highlights variation due to complex environments via specialized domain perturbations. Experiments are conducted on three applications : molecular property prediction, protein homology and stability prediction and show that RGM significantly outperforms previous state - of - the - art methods.

This paper proposes a novel architecture for cross - modal attentions for text - vision BERT models. The proposed architecture is based on a combination of text and vision probes, where the vision probes are conducted on text and the text probes on the other hand. The authors conduct experiments on two public benchmarks to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new type of Actor, named forward - looking Actor or FORK for short, for Actor - Critic algorithms. FORK can be easily integrated into a model - free ActorCritic algorithm. Experiments on six Box2D and MuJoCo environments with continuous state and action spaces demonstrate significant performance improvement for FORK compared to the state - of - the - art algorithms.

This paper proposes a new method for federated learning ( FLEU ). The key idea is to aggregate local models into a global model, which has been shown to be challenging when users have non - i.i.d. data. The authors propose a Bayesian inference perspective by sampling higher - quality global models and combining them via Bayesian model Ensemble, leading to much robust aggregation. The empirical studies validate FEDBE ’s superior performance, especially when users ’ data are not i.d and when the neural networks go deeper.

This paper is a paper under double - blind review under the definition of “ robustness ”.   The paper is concerned with the problem of robustness of neural networks to classification errors in the task of training neural networks. The main contribution of this paper is to provide a set of metrics to measure the robustness to classification error in the setting of neural network training. The authors also provide a list of questions to be answered in the paper to help the readers understand the strength of their results.

This paper presents a priori upper bound on the settling time of deep neural networks. The authors formulate the supervised learning framework as a control problem where weights of the network are control inputs and learning translates into a tracking problem. Under the assumptions of boundedness of input and perturbation - robustness, the authors prove that the loss function is robust against input perturbations.

This paper studies the problem of disentanglement of representations, which is one of the most important topics of machine learning. The authors propose to use the mutual information between each learned latent variables and the auxiliary variable to correctly identify informative latent variables. They show the advantage of their method on various downstream tasks including classification, outlier detection and adversarial attack defence on both synthetic and real data.

This paper proposes to decompose a feature map into various downsized sub - bands, each of which contains information with different frequencies, for image - to - image translation. The proposed method is based on the classical Lifting Scheme from signal processing. Experiments show the proposed methods achieve better results on image classification and semantic segmentation.

This paper proposes a fast, distance - preserving, binary embedding algorithm to transform a high - dimensional dataset T ⊆ R into binary sequences in the cube {±1 }. When T consists of well - spread ( i.e., non - sparse ) vectors, the proposed method applies a stable noise - shaping quantization scheme to Ax where A is a sparse Gaussian random matrix. The length of the binary codes required to achieve a desired accuracy is quite small, and it can even be compressed further without compromising the accuracy. The proposed method is tested on natural images and show that it achieves strong performance.

This paper studies the generalization and robustness of recurrent neural nets ( RNNs ). The authors hypothesize that the plasticity rules for RNN weights are learned through gradient descent ( GD ). They provide both empirical and theoretical evidence for this hypothesis. In particular, they show that plasticity rule learned by GD can generalize from one type of data / classifier to others. They also show that applying GD to learning rules is biologically plausible, in the sense that it can be learned over evolutionary time.

This paper proposes a method for visual question generation ( VQG ), which aims to generate human - like questions from an image and potentially other side information ( e.g. answer type or the answer itself ). The authors propose a novel learning paradigm to generate visual questions with answer - aware and region - reference. They also propose a graph - to - graph model to generate the questions with double hints. The experiments on VQA2 and COCO - QA datasets demonstrate that the proposed model can significantly outperform existing state - of - the - art baselines.

This paper studies the phenomenon of “ double descent ”, i.e., non - monotonic generalization in the presence of a large sample size and a large model size. The authors prove that optimally - tuned linear regression models with isotropic data distribution with optimal regularization can achieve monotonicity test performance as the sample size or the model size increases. They also demonstrate empirically that the same can be done for more general models, including neural networks.

This paper proposes a spatial dependency network ( SDN ) for variational autoencoders ( VAEs ) to improve density estimation. The proposed method is based on spatial dependency networks ( SDNs ), where feature maps at each level of a deep neural net are computed in a spatially coherent way, using a sequential gating - based mechanism that distributes contextual information across 2 - D space. The authors show that the proposed method improves density estimation over baseline convolutional architectures and the state - of - the - art among the models within the same class.

This paper studies the problem of off - policy reinforcement learning ( OPL ) in the offline setting, where a fixed collection of interactions are provided and no further interactions are allowed. The authors propose EMaQ, which is a simplified version of BCQ ( Fujimoto et al., 2018a ), a prior approach for offline RL. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of a novel backup operator ( backup operator ) that is more closely related to the resulting practical algorithm. Empirical results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a batch selection algorithm for improving model fairness in machine learning. The proposed algorithm is based on batch optimization. The main idea is to use batch selection as an inner optimizer to select minibatch sizes for the purpose of model fairness. Experiments are conducted on synthetic and real data to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

This paper studies the bounds on the Lipschitz constant of the monotone deep equilibrium ( DEQ ) model, which is a recently proposed subclass of DEQs. The main contribution of this paper is to show that the monotonicity of the network can be bounded as a function of the strong monotonic parameter of the DEQ model. The paper provides bounds on both the input - output mapping and the weight - output maps defined by these networks, and derive simple - yet - tight bounds on them. The authors also highlight how to use these bounds to develop PAC - Bayes generalization bounds that do not depend on the depth of the networks and avoid the exponential depth - dependence of comparable DNN bounds.

This paper considers the problem of imitation learning and goal - conditioned reinforcement learning, where the goal is to learn to reach a specified state or a set of states. The authors propose a method to estimate the density of states in the long - term using density estimation. They show that their approach can be applied to both imitation and goal conditioned RL settings. They also show that the proposed method can be used to address the hindsight bias problem in stochastic domains.

This paper proposes a variational multi - task learning ( MTL ) framework for simultaneously learning multiple related tasks. The framework is based on the variational Bayesian inference problem, which enables task relatedness to be explored in a principled way by specifying priors. The authors introduce Gumbel - softmax priors to condition the prior of each task on related tasks, which is represented as a mixture of variational posteriors of other related tasks and the mixing weights are learned in a data - driven manner for each individual task. Experiments on four benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a systematic and unified benchmark, Long - Range Arena, for evaluating model quality under long - context scenarios. The benchmark is a suite of tasks consisting of sequences ranging from 1K to 16K tokens, encompassing a wide range of data types and modalities such as text, natural, synthetic images, and mathematical expressions requiring similarity, and visual - spatial reasoning. The paper systematically evaluates ten well - established long - range Transformer models on their newly proposed benchmark suite. The proposed benchmark facilitates more research in this direction and presents new challenging tasks to tackle.

This paper proposes a multilingual code summarization model, which jointly learns on Context and Structure of source code. The model uses only language - agnostic features, i.e., source code and features that can be computed directly from the AST tree. The proposed model achieves state - of - the - art results on all five programming languages considered in this work, and jointly training on non - parallel data from multiple programming languages improves results.

This paper presents a method for audio - visual navigation in a 3D environment using both sights and sounds to find a sound source ( e.g. a phone ringing in another room ). The key idea is to learn a set of waypoints that are dynamically set and learned end - to - end within the navigation policy, and an acoustic memory that provides a structured, spatially grounded record of what the agent has heard as it moves. Experiments on two datasets of real - world 3D scenes, Replica and Matterport3D demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the effect of weight initializations on the convergence of neural networks trained to predict the next n steps of Conway's Game of Life. The authors first show that networks of this architecture trained on this task rarely converge, and that networks require substantially more parameters to consistently converge. They also show that the initialization parameters that gradient descent converges to a solution are sensitive to small perturbations. Finally, the authors show that training minimal networks with examples in which cells are alive with probability d0 dramatically increases the chance of convergence.

This paper proposes a new objective function, BatchMean Triplet loss, for semi - supervised learning ( SSL ). The proposed objective function is based on the observation that the inputs having the same label should have the similar model outputs. The paper also provides an ablation study to prove the efficacy of the proposed objective.

This paper considers the problem of learning new tasks from a small number of examples, by meta - learning across static data from a set of previous tasks. The authors study the problem in a sequential learning setting, where tasks are presented in sequence. They show that meta learning solves the full task set with fewer overall labels and achieves greater cumulative performance, compared to standard supervised methods. The results suggest that meta -learning is an important ingredient for building learning systems that continuously learn and improve over a sequence of problems.

This paper presents a series of experiments to investigate the role of sentence - level structure in the representations of pre - trained Transformer models. The experiments are designed to test the sensitivity of Transformer representations to several kinds of syntactic structure in sentences. The authors also connect their probe results to the Transformer architecture by relating the attention mechanism to syntactic distance between two words. Results from the three probes collectively suggest that Transformers build sensitivity to larger parts of the sentence along their layers, and hierarchical phrase structure plays a role in this process.

This paper studies the few - shot image synthesis task for GAN with minimum computing cost. The authors propose a light - weight GAN structure that gains superior quality on 1024 × 1024 resolution. The model converges from scratch with just a few hours of training on a single NVIDIA GPU. Two technique designs constitute the work, a skip - layer channel - wise excitation module and a self - supervised discriminator trained as a feature - encoder. The experiments are conducted on 13 datasets covering a wide variety of image domains.

This paper proposes a dual dual solver for neural network bounding. The main idea is to use a small number of dual variables to verify the tightness of the relaxation of the employed relaxation. The proposed method recovers the strengths of the new relaxation in the dual space : tightness and a linear separation oracle. The authors demonstrate that this method results in significant formal verification speed - ups.

This paper proposes two new pre - training objectives for improving the performance of pre - trained language models ( PTLMs ). The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of generative and contrastive objectives for learning common sense from the text, and use them as intermediate self - supervised learning tasks for the PTLM. The proposed methods are evaluated on two tasks : natural language understanding ( NLU ) and generation ( NLG ) tasks. The results show that the proposed methods outperform baseline methods by a consistent margin and are comparable with some larger PTLm models.

This paper proposes a method for unsupervised physical object discovery from video. The method is based on the use of multi - scale pixel cues and physical motion cues to accurately segment observable and partially occluded objects of varying sizes, and infer the properties of those objects. The proposed method can segment objects on both synthetic and real scenes. The discovered object properties can also be used to reason about physical events.

This paper proposes a training method to improve the robustness of deep neural networks ( DNNs ) against adversarial attacks. The main idea is to increase the margins of training samples by moving the decision boundaries of the DNN model far away from the training samples to improve robustness. The IMA method is evaluated on six publicly available datasets ( including a COVID - 19 CT image dataset ) under strong 100 - PGD white - box attacks, and the results show that the proposed method significantly improved classification accuracy on noisy data while keeping a relatively high accuracy on clean data.

This paper proposes a method for knowledge distillation of deep neural networks ( DNNs ) by projecting the supervision signals of a teacher model into the student ’s parameter space by decomposing the training objective into local intermediate targets with approximate mirror descent technique. The proposed method could be less sensitive with the quirks during optimization which could result in a better local optima. Experiments on both image and text datasets show that the proposed ProKT consistently achieves the state - of - the - art performance comparing to all existing knowledge - distillation methods.

This paper proposes a new method for channel pruning in convolutional neural networks ( CNNs ). The main idea is to use a hyper - structure network to generate the architecture of the main network, which can be optimized by regular backpropagation. The paper also proposes a regularization term to specify the computational resource of the compact network. Extensive experimental results on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet show that the proposed method is competitive with state - of - the - art methods.

This paper presents a method for proving higher - order logic theorem proving in the presence of a large knowledge base of potential premises without learning from human proofs. The authors augment the exploration of premises based on a simple TF - idf ( term frequency - inverse document frequency ) based lookup in a deep reinforcement learning scenario. The experiments show that the method, DeepHOL Zero, outperforms provers that are trained only on human proofs and approaches the performance of a prover trained by a combination of imitation and reinforcement learning.

This paper proposes a method for data augmentation in the latent space. The idea is to augment data for any modality in a generic way. The proposed method is called MODALS ( Modalityagnostic Automated Data Augmentation in Latent Space ). The method is applied to four universal data transformation operations ( tabular, time - series, image, text, and image modalities ). Experiments are conducted on multiple datasets for text, tabular and image data.

This paper studies the mean field limit of neural networks with more than two layers. The authors prove a global convergence result for unregularized feedforward three - layer networks in the mean - field regime. The main contribution is a universal approximation property, natural of neural network, which is shown to hold at any finite training time ( not necessarily at convergence ) via an algebraic topology argument.

This paper studies the problem of learning explanations of expert decisions by modeling their reward function in terms of preferences with respect to “ what if ” outcomes. To learn these cost - benefit trade - offs associated with the expert ’s actions, the authors integrate counterfactual reasoning into batch inverse reinforcement learning. The authors conduct experiments in both real and simulated medical environments to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the performance of graph neural networks ( GNNs ) for continuous control. The authors propose a series of ablations on existing methods that show that morphological information encoded in the graph does not improve their performance. They also propose a transformer - based approach, AMORPHEUS, that is able to use the information in the input graph to define the message - passing scheme.

This paper studies visual counting, which aims to predict the number of occurrences given a natural image and a query ( e.g., a question or a category ). The authors propose a simple and effective alternative by revisiting modulated convolutions that fuse the query and the image locally. The method is called MoVie, short for Modulated Convolutional Bottlenecks. The paper shows that the proposed method can be integrated as a module for ‘ number ’ related questions in generic VQA tasks.

This paper proposes a model - targeted poisoning attack that can target a desired model based on online convex optimization. Unlike previous model - targeted poisoning attacks, the attack comes with provable convergence to any achievable target classifier. The distance from the induced classifier to the target classifiers is inversely proportional to the square root of the number of poisoning points. The authors also provide a lower bound on the minimum number of poisoned points needed to achieve a given target model.

This paper proposes a binarization approach for efficient deep learning on point clouds. The authors claim that the performance drop of binarized models for point clouds mainly stems from two challenges : aggregation - induced feature homogenization that leads to a degradation of information entropy and scale distortion that hinders optimization and invalidates scale - sensitive structures. To address these challenges, the authors introduce Entropy - Maximizing Aggregation ( EMA ) to modulate the distribution before aggregation for the maximum information entropy, and Layer - wise Scale Recovery ( LSR ) to efficiently restore feature representation capacity. Extensive experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes to add a memory module to the Transformer model to improve the performance of the model. The proposed method is based on the self - attention architecture, where the model is able to combine information from all elements of a sequence into context - aware representations. However, information about the context is stored mostly in the same element - wise representations. This might limit the processing of properties related to the sequence as a whole more difficult. Experiments are conducted on several tasks from question answering to language modeling, showing that adding the memory module improves the model's performance.

This paper presents a method for instance discrimination learning based on contrastive learning with clustering. The proposed method uses prototypes as latent variables to help find the maximum - likelihood estimation of the network parameters in an Expectation - Maximization framework. The paper also proposes ProtoNCE loss, a generalized version of the InfoNCE for contrastive - learning, which encourages representations to be closer to their assigned prototypes. Experiments are conducted on multiple benchmarks with substantial improvement in low - resource transfer learning.

This paper proposes a method to defend against adversarial attacks by constructing a block containing multiple paths to learn robust features and the parameters of these paths are required to be orthogonal with each other. The proposed block is called Orthogonal Multi - Path ( OMP ) block and can be posed in any layer of a neural network. Through forward learning and backward correction, one OMP block makes the neural networks learn features that are appropriate for all the paths and hence are expected to be robust. Experiments are conducted on both white - box and black - box attacks to show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a self - supervised graph attention network ( SuperGAT ) for noisy graphs. Specifically, two attention forms are used to predict edges, whose presence and absence contain the inherent information about the importance of the relationships between nodes. By encoding edges, the network learns more expressive attention in distinguishing mislinked neighbors. Two graph characteristics influence the effectiveness of attention forms and self - supervision : homophily and average degree. Experiments on 17 real - world datasets show improved performance.

This paper proposes a new method for medical automatic diagnosis ( DSMAD ), INS - DS ( Introspective Diagnosis System ). The proposed method consists of two modules, i.e. an inquiry module for proposing the most valuable symptom inquiry, and an introspective module for deciding when to inform a disease. Two evaluation metrics are proposed to validate the reliability and robustness of the proposed method. Extensive experimental results demonstrate the new state - of - the - art under various experimental settings.

This paper proposes a new method for fine - grained visual classification ( FGVC ) based on the Batch Confusion Norm ( BCN ) framework to address the long - tailed natural world distribution of visual classification. The proposed method is based on extending the confusion energy - based framework to account for long -tailed scenario and can be used to exert distribution of confusion strength over tailed and head categories to improve classification performance. The method is evaluated on several benchmark FGVC datasets and achieves state - of - the - art results.

This paper proposes a new method for inverse reinforcement learning based on Bayesian inference over the reward. The main idea is to jointly learn an approximate posterior distribution over reward that scales to arbitrarily complicated state spaces alongside an appropriate policy in a completely offline manner through a variational approach to latent reward. Experiments are conducted on real medical data alongside classic control simulations in environments beyond the scope of current methods.

This paper proposes a new method for learning counterfactuals for partially observable games. The key idea is to use an approximate auto - regressive belief distribution that is learned as a supervised task. The method is evaluated on Hanabi, a multi - agent game with partially observable environments. The results show that the proposed method obtains competitive results compared to the state - of - the - art methods.

This paper proposes a novel method to control the trade - off between depth and breadth of tree search in the context of state - action planning. The proposed method is based on an interpolation between two well - known search mechanisms : MCTS and random shooting. It also lets the user control the bias - variance trade -off, akin to TD(n ), but in the tree search context. Experiments on challenging domains show that the proposed method achieves the best of both worlds consistently achieving higher scores.

This paper proposes a method for learning inductive bias from synthetic datasets. The paper proposes three synthetic tasks that are intended to require the model to be able to deduct, inductive, and abductive reasoning abilities. The synthetic tasks are designed in a way that they are devoid of mathematical knowledge to ensure that only the fundamental reasoning biases can be learned from these tasks. This defines a new pre - training methodology called “ LIME ” ( Learning Inductive bias for Mathematical rEasoning ). Experiments are conducted on three very different large mathematical reasoning benchmarks to demonstrate the effectiveness of the method.

This paper studies the inductive bias of gradient descent for weight normalized smooth homogeneous neural nets, when trained on exponential or cross - entropy loss with exponential weight normalization ( EWN ). The paper shows that the gradient flow path with EWN is equivalent to gradient flow on standard networks with an adaptive learning rate, and hence causes the weights to be updated in a way that prefers asymptotic relative sparsity. The authors also show that the results can be extended to hold for gradient descent via an appropriate adaptive learning rates.

This paper studies the problem of catastrophic forgetting in generative adversarial networks ( GANs ). The authors claim that the mode collapse is due to the discriminator ’s inability to maintain classification accuracy on previously seen samples, a phenomenon called catastrophic forgetting. Based on this observation, the authors introduce a novel training procedure that dynamically spawns additional discriminators to remember previous modes of generation. Experiments are conducted on several datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a method to regularize BERT, a popular natural language processing ( NLP ) language modeling system, by pruning its attention heads based on a proxy score for head importance. The paper proposes to learn a pruning policy that determines which attention heads should or should not be pruned for regularization. The proposed method is based on reinforcement learning to automatically prune attention heads from BERT. Experimental results show that AUBER outperforms existing pruning methods by achieving up to 9.39 % better accuracy.

This paper studies the problem of learning correspondence between two domains, one for simulation and the other for transfer learning. The domains are different in representation, physics parameters ( mass and friction ), and morphology ( number of limbs ). The correspondence is learned using unpaired and randomly collected data from the two domains. The paper proposes dynamics cycles that align dynamic robot behavior across two domains using a cycle - consistency constraint. Once the correspondence is found, the policy trained on one domain can be transferred directly to the other domain without needing any additional fine - tuning on the second domain.

This paper studies the problem of using Shapley explainability for explainability in machine learning. The authors propose two solutions to the " uncorrelatedness " assumption made in the Shapley framework. One solution is based on generative modelling, which provides flexible access to data imputations ; the other directly learns Shapley value - function, providing performance and stability at the cost of flexibility.   The authors also provide a theoretical analysis of the drawbacks of the uncorrelation assumption.

This paper proposes a new method for modelling the behaviour of opponents in multi - agent reinforcement learning. The proposed method is based on variational autoencoders, which are trained to reconstruct the local actions and observations of the opponent based on embeddings that depend only on the local observations. The paper provides a comprehensive evaluation and ablation study in diverse multi - agents tasks, showing that the proposed method achieves comparable performance to an ideal baseline which has full access to opponent ’s information.

This paper proposes Consistent Contrastive Learning ( CO2 ), which introduces a consistency regularization term into the current contrastive learning framework for semi - supervised learning on unlabeled data. The main contribution of the paper is to address the issue of instance discrimination, where the common practice is to perform an instance discrimination task on the query image crop, which labels crops from the same image as positives and crops from other randomly sampled images as negatives. To address this issue, the paper proposes to use the similarity of the query crop to each crop from other images as a pseudo label, and encourages consistency between these two similarities. Experiments on image classification, object detection, semantic segmentation, and downstream tasks on PASCAL VOC demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the last - iterate convergence of Optimistic Multiplicative Weights Update ( OMWU ) and Optimistic Gradient Descent Ascent ( OGDA ) for saddle - point optimization. The main contribution of the paper is a theoretical analysis of the convergence rates of the two algorithms for bilinear games over the simplex over the probability simplex. Specifically, the authors show that when the equilibrium is unique, linear last -iterate convergence is achieved with a learning rate whose value is set to a universal constant, improving the result of ( Daskalakis & Panagakis, 2019b ) under the same assumption. The results are extended to more general objectives and feasible sets for the projected OGDA algorithm, by introducing a sufficient condition under which OGDA exhibits concrete last - incrementate convergence rates with a constant learning rate. Experimental results are provided to further support the theory.

This paper studies the problem of training User Verification ( UV ) models in federated setup, where the conventional loss functions are not applicable due to the constraints that each user has access to the data of only one class and user embeddings can not be shared with the server or other users. To address this problem, this paper proposes Federated User Verified ( FedUV ) framework for private and secure training of UV models. In FedUV, users jointly learn a set of vectors and maximize the correlation of their instance embedding with a secret user - defined linear combination of those vectors. The experimental results for user verification with voice, face, and handwriting data and show that FedUV is on par with existing approaches.

This paper proposes a simple technique to estimate the effective dimension of deep neural network class manifolds ( CMs ) by computing their intersection with random affine subspaces of varying dimension. The authors provide a theory for the technique and verify that their theoretical predictions agree with measurements on real neural networks. They leverage this method to show deep connections between the geometry of CMs, generalization, and robustness.

This paper studies the problem of how to balance exploration and exploitation in reinforcement learning ( RL ). The authors propose to use the curiosity mechanism to increase the entropy temperature for unfamiliar states and decrease the target entropy for familiar states. The experiments on MuJoJo benchmark show that the proposed method significantly improves the sample efficiency, outperforming the advanced model - free RL baselines.

This paper proposes a method for meta - reinforcement learning based on model identification and experience relabeling ( MIER ). The method is based on the observation that dynamics models can be adapted efficiently and consistently with off - policy data, more easily than policies and value functions for out - of - distribution tasks without using meta - re - inforcement learning at all, by generating synthetic experience for the new task.   The proposed method is evaluated on a set of benchmark tasks, where it is shown that it is both efficient and extrapolates well.

This paper proposes a method to address the few - shot learning ( FSL ) problem with label noise and sampling noise. The proposed method is based on Eigen - Reptile ( ER ) that updates the meta - parameters with the main direction of a special mechanism for the parameter ’s large size. The paper also proposes a new method called Introspective Self - paced Learning ( ISPL ) that constructs a plurality of prior models to determine which sample should be abandoned. Experiments on different tasks demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed methods theoretically and experimentally.

This paper proposes a new method for training deep learning models that are robust to distributional shifts. The proposed method is based on batch normalization, which is a variant of adversarial training. The method is evaluated on ImageNet-C, Stylized - ImageNet, and ImageNetInstagram. Results show that the proposed method significantly improves the performance of ResNet - 50 on image classification tasks.

This paper proposes Variance of Gradients ( VoG ) as a proxy metric for detecting outliers in the data distribution. The paper provides quantitative and qualitative support that VoG is a meaningful way to rank data by difficulty and to surface a tractable subset of the most challenging examples for human - in - the - loop auditing. Data points with high VoG scores are far more difficult for the model to learn and over - index on corrupted or memorized examples.

This paper proposes a new method to improve the generation quality of deep generative models. The proposed method is based on the gradient flow of entropy - regularized f - divergences between the real and the generated data distributions, which is a non - linear Fokker - Plank equation. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the state - of - the - art DOT and DDLS methods in terms of the quality of generated samples.

This paper presents a pre - training approach to unify the two mainstreams in both model architectures and pre - train tasks. It splits the standard Transformer block into several sub - modules trained with both inner - sequence and cross - sequence masked language modeling, and reorganizes certain sub - module for understanding and generation tasks during inference. The proposed approach outperforms all existing cross - lingual models and state - of - the - art Transformer variants on WMT14 English - to - German and E2French translation datasets, with gains of up to 1∼2 BLEU.

This paper proposes a novel intrinsic reward for reinforcement learning that encourages the agent to understand the causal effect of its actions through auditory event prediction. The proposed method is based on the use of multiple sensory modalities ( e.g. visual and audio ) to build a causal understanding of the physical world. The authors first conduct an in - depth analysis of their module using a set of Atari games and then apply their model to audio - visual exploration using the Habitat simulator and active learning using the ThreeDWorld ( TDW ) simulator. Experimental results demonstrate the advantages of using audio signals over vision - based models as intrinsic rewards.

This paper studies the problem of novel category discovery on single and multi - modal data with labels from different but relevant categories. The authors propose a framework to jointly learn a reliable representation and assign clusters to unlabelled data. To avoid overfitting the learnt embedding to labelled data, the authors take inspiration from self - supervised representation learning by noise - contrastive estimation and extend it to jointly handle labelled and unlabeled data. The proposed method uses category discrimination on labelled data and cross - modular discrimination on multi - modular data to augment instance discrimination used in conventional contrastive learning approaches. They further employ Winner - Take - All ( WTA ) hashing algorithm on the shared representation space to generate pairwise pseudo labels to better predict cluster assignments.

This paper studies the problem of weakly supervised segmentation, where the task is to assign a label to every pixel based on training instances with partial annotations such as image - level tags, object bounding boxes, labeled points and scribbles. This task is challenging, as coarse annotations ( tags, boxes ) lack precise pixel localization whereas sparse annotations ( points, scribbles ) lack broad region coverage. The authors propose 4 types of contrastive relationships between pixels and segments in the feature space, capturing low - level image similarity, semantic annotation, co - occurence, and feature affinity. The proposed method outperforms Pascal VOC and DensePose.

This paper proposes a simple but effective distillation strategy for unsupervised learning. The key idea is that the relationship among similar samples counts and can be seamlessly transferred to the student to boost the performance. The proposed method, BINGO, achieves new state - of - the - art performance on small scale models, i.e., ImageNet-18 and ResNet-34, surpassing baselines by a significant margin.

This paper proposes a generative adversarial inference ( GATSBI ) algorithm for simulation - based inference ( SBI ) on stochastic models for which the model can generate samples, but does not require explicit likelihoods. The paper proposes to reformulate the variational objective in an adversarial setting to learn implicit posterior distributions. Inference with GATSBI is amortised across observations, works in high - dimensional posterior spaces and supports implicit priors. Experiments are conducted on two SBI benchmark problems and on two high -dimensional simulators.

This paper considers the problem of identifying individualized treatment effects ( TEs ) under limited overlap when subjects with certain features belong to a single treatment group. The authors use a latent variable to model a prognostic score which is widely used in biostatistics and sufficient for TEs. The model is then learned as a new type of variational autoencoder ( VAE ). The TE error bounds are derived that enable representations balanced for treatment groups conditioned on individualized features. The proposed method is compared with recent methods using ( semi-)synthetic datasets.

This paper proposes a framework for Autonomous Reinforcement Learning ( ARL ) where the agent not only only learns through its own experience, but also contends with the lack of human supervision to reset between trials in reinforcement learning ( RL ). The proposed framework is based on the idea of embodied learning, which is situated in a continual, non - episodic world, where the environment resetts between trials to provide the agent with multiple attempts to learn. The paper also presents a set of benchmark tasks for ARL. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of a new benchmark task, named EARL1, that is designed to address the difficulty of RL algorithms developed for episodic simulated environments and run them on real - world platforms.

This paper investigates the reasoning capability of Graph Neural Networks ( GNN ) - based reasoning modules for knowledge - powered QA systems. The authors claim that existing knowledge - aware GNN - based modules may only carry out some simple reasoning such as counting. They also claim that even a very simple graph neural counter can outperform all the existing GNN modules on CommonsenseQA and OpenBookQA benchmark datasets which heavily rely on knowledge -aware reasoning.

This paper proposes a method for deep neural network ( DNN ) inference with near - optimal compression and much better performance during inference runtime. The key insight of the paper is the concept of Succinct Data Structures, which supports fast queries directly on compressed representation without decompression. The proposed method first transforms DNN models as their proposed formulations in either a W - wise or Block - wise manner, so that the compressed representation can be queried in a fast manner. Experiments show that the proposed method achieves at least 8.7X/11.5X speedup on AlexNet/VGG-16 inference.

This paper proposes a new training method for improving the performance of tiny neural networks. The authors argue that training tiny models is different from training large models : rather than augmenting the data, we should augment the model, since tiny models tend to suffer from under - fitting rather than over - fitting due to limited capacity. To alleviate this issue, NetAug augments the network ( reverse dropout ) instead of inserting noise into the dataset or the network. The method is evaluated on image classification and object detection datasets.

This paper proposes a method to learn the underlying temporal coherence from point cloud sequence, which in turn guides the generator to produce temporally coherent output. In addition, a learnable masking module is proposed to adapt upsampling ratio according to the point distribution. Experiments are conducted on point cloud sequences from two different domains : particles in the fluid dynamical system and human action scans.

This paper proposes a new method for pre - training object detection transformers. The main idea is to fully pre - train an encoder - only transformer and then finetune it for object detection via a task adapter. Experiments on the challenging COCO dataset demonstrate that the proposed method achieves competitive performance.

This paper studies the communication complexity of FedPAGE, a new local federated learning algorithm for convex optimization. The main contribution of the paper is to propose to use optimal PAGE method to reduce the communication cost. The authors show that the number of communication rounds is much fewer than previous local methods for both federated convex and nonconvex optimization settings. The communication cost for each round is the same in both settings.

This paper studies the decision boundary geometry of artificial neural networks ( ANNs ) in the presence of adversarial input perturbations. The authors define adversarial subspaces, which are spanned by orthogonal directions of minimal perturbation to the boundary from any given input sample in a large subspace, where the distance from the boundary to the subspace grows smoothly and sub - linearly as one increases the dimensionality of the adversary subspace.   The main contribution of this work is to further our understanding of the decision boundaries of ANN classifiers by utilizing such adversarial perturbing. The most widely used defense against test - time adversarial attacks is adversarial training, where one incorporates adversarially - perturbed input samples into the training procedure. The results of the paper provide new insight into the consequences of such training by quantifying the increase in boundary distance within adversarial subsets, the redistribution of proximal class labels and the decrease in boundary curvature.

This paper proposes a two - stage weakly - supervised contrastive learning approach for representation learning. The first stage is to cluster data according to its auxiliary information, and the second stage learns similar representations within the same cluster and dissimilar representations for data from different clusters. The proposed approach is evaluated on synthetic and real - world datasets. The results show that the proposed approach outperforms the baselines in most cases.

This paper studies the problem of estimating sparse parameters from observational data, which is a fundamental problem in machine learning with wide applications. The authors propose PLISA ( Provable Learning - based Iterative Sparse recovery Algorithm ) to learn algorithms automatically from data. The proposed method unrolls a classic path - following algorithm, with some components being more flexible and learnable. With this structure, the authors theoretically show the improved recovery accuracy achievable by PLISA. They also analyze the empirical Rademacher complexity of PLISA to characterize its generalization ability.

This paper studies the problem of learning action representations for discrete - continuous action spaces in reinforcement learning. The authors propose to learn a compact and decodable latent representation space for the original hybrid action space, and then use a VAE - based RL algorithm to learn the representation of the original action space. They evaluate HyAR in a variety of environments with discrete - continuous action spaces. The results demonstrate the superiority of HyAR when compared with previous baselines.

This paper proposes SGEM, a stochastic gradient method for non - convex optimization with energy stability and momentum. It is based on the AEGD method, which is a generalization of the work of [ Arora et al., 2010 ]. The main difference is that SGEM incorporates both energy and momentum at the same time so as to inherit their dual advantages. The paper also provides a regret bound for the online convex setting.   The paper is well - written and easy to follow.

This paper proposes a method to improve the performance of Transformer - based autoregressive ( NAR ) machine translation models. NAR models have achieved significant performance improvements, near human - level accuracy on some languages. The authors investigate possible reasons behind this performance gap, namely the indistinguishability of tokens, and mismatch between training and inference. They propose a Conditional Masked Language Model with Correction ( CMLMC ) that addresses these problems. Empirically, the proposed method achieves state - of - the - art NAR performance on multiple datasets.

This paper proposes to use spiking neural dynamics as a natural alternative to dilated temporal convolutions for keyword - based signal processing. The authors extend the WaveNet architecture to WaveSense, which uses simple neural dynamics, fixed time - constant and a simple feed - forward architecture and is particularly well suited for neuromorphic implementation. The results show that the proposed network beats the state - of - the - art of other artificial neural networks on several datasets for keyword spotting.

This paper studies the problem of fairness in machine learning for social applications. In particular, the authors consider the phenomenon of demographic shift and present a class of algorithms, called Shifty algorithms, that provide high - confidence behavioral guarantees that hold under demographic shift. They evaluate Shifty using a real - world dataset of university entrance exams and subsequent student success. They show that the learned models avoid bias under demographic shifts, unlike existing methods.

This paper proposes to extend the Stochastic Dual Dynamic Programming ( SDDP ) method for stochastic optimization. The main contribution of this paper is to extend SDDP by introducing a trainable neural model that learns to map problem instances to a piece - wise linear value function within intrinsic low - dimensional space, which is architected specifically to interact with a base SDDP solver to accelerate optimization performance on new instances. The proposed method is evaluated on a range of synthetic and real - world process optimization problems.

This paper proposes a protocol for private next - token prediction. The protocol is designed to prevent privacy violations by language models that were fine - tuned on a private corpus after pre - training on a public corpus. The authors show that the proposed protocol limits the leakage of information that is unique to any individual user in the private corpus via a relaxation of group differentially private prediction.

This paper proposes an unsupervised method to detect out - of - distribution ( OOD ) examples using a k - NN density estimation. The authors leverage a recent insight about label smoothing, which they call the Label Smoothed Embedding Hypothesis, and show that one of the implications is that the k - nN density estimator performs better as an OOD detection method both theoretically and empirically when the model is trained with label - smoothing. They also provide new finite - sample high - probability statistical results for k -NN density estimation ’s ability to detect OOD examples.

This paper proposes a new method for representation learning in a non - adversarial generative model. The proposed method is based on a new formulation of the denoising score matching objective and thus encodes information needed for denoizing. The paper also proposes to learn an infinite - dimensional latent code which achieves improvements of state - of - the - art performance on semi - supervised image classification.

This paper proposes a method for goal - conditioned reinforcement learning ( RL ). The main idea is to learn a curriculum of intermediate states to solve the distant goal - reaching task by using planning at training time to automatically generate intermediate states. The paper proposes two steps to learn the intermediate states : E - step to plan a sequence of waypoints using graph planning, M - step for learning a goal - conditioned policy to reach those waypoints, and E - M - Step for learning the policy for reaching the waypoints. The proposed method is evaluated on a number of tasks, including navigation, manipulation, and navigation tasks, where it is shown to be more sample efficient than prior methods.

This paper proposes a new regularization method for training deep neural networks called k - mixup, which is an extension of mixup to the k - batch regularization. The proposed method is based on the displacement interpolation technique, which aims to improve the generalization and robustness of the training set by perturbing training data in the direction of other randomly - chosen training instances in the original training set. The authors show that the proposed method preserves cluster and manifold structures, and extend theory studying the efficacy of standard mixup from the k-mixup case. The experiments are conducted on three synthetic datasets for binary classification, with 1 - 1 mixup through 32 - 32 mixup regularization ( alpha = 1 ).

This paper proposes to use the embeddings produced by a lightweight network more effectively with a nonlinear classification layer. The authors theoretically show that their classification layer optimizes over all possible radial kernel functions on the space of embedding vectors to learn an optimal nonlinear classifier. They then demonstrate the usefulness of this layer in learning more model - efficient classifiers in a number of computer vision and natural language processing tasks.

This paper analyzes the sources of bias in node representations obtained via Graph Neural Networks ( GNNs ). The authors claim that both nodal features and graph structure lead to bias in the obtained representations. Based on the analysis, fairness - aware data augmentation frameworks are developed to reduce the intrinsic bias. Extensive experiments on node classification and link prediction are carried out over real networks in the context of graph contrastive learning.

This paper proposes a Confounder Balanced IV Regression ( CB - IV ) algorithm to jointly remove the bias from the unmeasured confounders with IV regression and achieve better treatment effect estimation. The proposed algorithm consists of three main modules : ( 1 ) treatment regression, ( 2 ) confounder balancing, and ( 3 ) outcome regression. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the adaptability of meta - learning ( MAML ) in a linear regression setting with a mixture of easy and hard tasks, where the hardness is related to the rate that gradient descent converges on the task. The authors prove that in order for MAMl to achieve substantial gain over NAL, ( i ) there must be some discrepancy in hardness among the tasks, and ( ii ) the optimal solutions of the hard tasks must be closely packed with the center of the easy tasks optimal solutions. They also give numerical and analytical results suggesting that these insights apply to two - layer neural networks. Finally, they provide few - shot image classification experiments that support their insights for when MamiAML should be used and emphasize the importance of training MamiAmL on hard tasks in practice.

This paper proposes a novel method for semi - blind source separation ( BSS ) based on the Proximal Alternating Linearized Minimization ( PALM ) algorithm. The proposed method leverages the data - driven knowledge stemming from realistic simulations or ground - truth data by learning both PALM hyperparameters and variables. The paper further shows that the proposed LPALM algorithm outperforms other unrolled source separation methods in the semi - Blind setting.

This paper proposes a new model for language modeling based on the Legendre Memory Unit ( LPM ). The main idea of the model is to use implicit self - attention to improve the performance of transformers on the task of language modeling. The paper shows that the proposed model is able to outperform transformers in terms of both memory and computation for the same amount of training, while transformers can outperform it by a factor of three orders of magnitude. Experiments are conducted on both synthetic and real - world datasets.

This paper proposes a two - stage GAN based on LatentKeypointGAN, which is trained end - to - end on the classical GAN objective with internal conditioning on a set of space keypoints. These keypoints have associated appearance embeddings that control the position and style of the generated objects and their parts. The paper demonstrates that the latent space can be used to re - position the generated images by re - positioning the keypoints and exchanging keypoint embedding from different images.

This paper studies the phenomenon of representation shrinkage in deep neural networks with layer normalization using the mean field formalism. The authors show that increasing the depth leads to gradient explosion or to another undesirable phenomenon, represented as a gradient explosion. The appearance of at least one of these problems is not restricted to a specific initialization scheme or a choice of activation function, but rather is an inherent property of the fully - connected architecture itself.   The authors also show that many popular normalization techniques fail to mitigate these problems.

This paper proposes a line search method for finding optimal step sizes for stochastic gradient descent automatically. The authors propose a line - search method that approximates the full - batch loss with a parabola estimated over several mini - batch losses. The learning rates are derived from such parabolas during training. The experiments conducted show that the proposed method outperforms other line search approaches for Deep Learning across models, datasets, batch sizes on validation and test accuracy.

This paper presents a formal analysis of the performance of Noise - contrastive estimation ( NCE ) when the target and noise distributions are in a flat form. Specifically, the authors prove that NCE suffers from an ill - behaved loss landscape and propose a variant of NCE called eNCE which uses an exponential loss and a normalized gradient descent to address the landscape issues. The paper is well - written and easy to follow. However, the paper suffers from a lack of novelty and is difficult to understand.

This paper studies the convergence of distributed SGD with Byzantine resilience and Byzantine resilience in the context of distributed machine learning. The authors consider the setting where a fraction of the workers are malicious ( byzantine ) and the other fraction are honest and provide noisy information to the server to ensure differential privacy ( differential privacy ). They show that by carefully re - tuning the learning algorithm, they can obtain reasonable learning accuracy while simultaneously guaranteeing DP and Byzantine Resilience.

This paper considers the problem of code editing with few exemplars. The authors propose a novel deep learning approach to solve this code editing problem automatically. The proposed method combines edit representations extracted from support exemplars and compositionally generalizes them to the query code snippet editing via multi - extended similarities ensemble. The paper evaluates the proposed method on C# and Python datasets.

This paper proposes a generative model for generating sequence data with high - level structure in the form of relational constraints between different subcomponents of an example ( e.g., lines of a poem or measures of music ). The authors propose a two - stage approach : ( i ) generating a set of constraints, and ( ii ) a second model to generate realistic data satisfying these constraints. The main contribution of this paper is to propose a novel approach for incorporating global structure into the generative process. The paper also proposes a program synthesis algorithm that infers the relational constraints present in the training data, and then learns a model based on the resulting constraint data.

This paper studies the problem of set - to - hypergraph prediction, where the goal is to infer the set of relations for a given set of entities. This is a common abstraction for applications in particle physics, biological systems and combinatorial optimization. The paper proposes to predict and supervise the positive edges only, which changes the asymptotic memory scaling from exponential to linear. It also proposes a training method that encourages iterative refinement of the predicted hypergraph, which allows us to skip iterations in the backward pass.

This paper proposes a post - processing method to mitigate bias in deep learning models. The proposed method consists in learning a shallow neural network, called the Ethical Module, which transforms the deep embeddings of a pre - trained model to give more representation power to the discriminated subgroups. The training is supervised by the von Mises - Fisher loss, whose hyperparameters allow to control the space allocated to each subgroup in the latent space. The resulting methodology is more stable and faster than most current methods of bias mitigation.

This paper studies the problem of class - incremental learning ( CIL ) from the perspective of the knowledge distillation ( KD ) loss. The authors propose to compute the KD loss using the data from a free image stream ( e.g., Google Images ), which is both simple and surprisingly effective even when there is no class overlap between the placebos and the old class data. They also propose a reinforcement learning algorithm that does not require any additional supervision or memory budget, and can significantly improve a number of top - performing CIL methods.

This paper studies the problem of sampling from discrete energy - based models ( EBM ) for inference and learning. In particular, the authors propose a path auxiliary algorithm that uses a composition of local moves to efficiently explore large neighborhoods. They also give a fast version of their algorithm that only queries the evaluation of energy function twice for each proposal via linearization of the energy function. Empirically, they show that their path auxiliary algorithms considerably outperform other generic samplers on various discrete models for sampling, inference, and learning, and can also be used to train deep EBMs for high dimensional discrete data.

This paper proposes a method for hierarchical reinforcement learning based on latent representations of video features in a temporal hierarchy based on their rates of change. The proposed method is based on a neural probabilistic inference system that organizes latent representations in a hierarchical hierarchy. The method is able to dynamically adjust its internal state following changes in the observed features, promoting an optimal organisation of representations across the levels of the model ’s latent hierarchy. Experiments on several video datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new method for image retrieval that combines global and local features. The proposed method is an end - to - end and single - stage pipeline. The paper claims that the proposed method accelerates extraction speed and reduces memory consumption by removing the re - ranking process and local feature matching with convolutional neural networks. Experiments on two datasets validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

This paper proposes a new method for multi - task learning. The main idea is to homogenize the gradient magnitude and directions across tasks to avoid the negative transfer problem. The method is evaluated on the NYUv2 multi - label classification dataset. The results show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines.

This paper proposes a novel model fusion framework, named CLAFusion, to fuse neural networks with a different number of layers via cross - layer alignment.
