The proposed framework balances the number of neural networks before applying layer - wise model fusion. Experiments are conducted on the CIFAR-10 dataset to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed framework.

This paper studies the implicit regularization effect of SGD seen in supervised learning could in fact be harmful in the offline deep RL setting, leading to poor generalization and degenerate feature representations. The authors propose a simple and effective explicit regularizer, called DR3, that counteracts the undesirable effects of this implicit regularizer. DR3 substantially improves performance and stability, alleviating unlearning in Atari 2600 games, D4RL domains and robotic manipulation from images.

This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning ( RL ) exploration method, HyperDQN. The main idea is to use a probabilistic hyper - model to estimate the Q - values of the base model, which can be used to obtain the posterior samples of Q - value functions. The proposed method is evaluated on the Atari game SuperMarioBros, where it outperforms several exploration bonus and randomized exploration methods on 5 out of 9 games.

This paper proposes to learn causal representation from observational data by regularizing the learning procedure with mutual information measures according to our hypothetical causal graph. The optimization involves a counterfactual loss, based on which the authors deduce a theoretical guarantee that the causality - inspired learning is with reduced sample complexity and better generalization ability. Extensive experiments show that the models trained on causal representations learned by the proposed approach is robust under adversarial attacks and distribution shift.

This paper proposes ProgFed, a training framework for efficient and effective federated learning. The main idea is to reduce computation and two - way communication costs while maintaining the strong performance of the final models. Theoretical results show that the proposed framework converges at the same asymptotic rate as standard training on full models. Extensive results on a broad range of architectures, including CNNs ( VGG, ResNet, ConvNets ) and U - nets, and diverse tasks are provided.

This paper studies the generalization of adversarial training through the lens of the Rademacher complexity of deep neural networks ( DNNs ). The main contribution of this paper is to provide upper bounds of the adversarial Rademachers complexity of neural networks. The paper also provides experiments to show that the adversarially trained weight - norms are larger than the standard trained weight norms.

This paper proposes a kernel - based estimator for the differential entropy and mutual information. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of a new estimator that is parameterized, differentiable, and differentiable. The method is validated on synthetic data and is applied to guide the training of neural networks for real - world tasks. Experiments on visual domain adaptation, textual fair classification, and textual fine - tuning demonstrate the effectiveness of the method.

This paper proposes a simple soft - greedy operator, called resmax, that takes actions proportionally to their suboptimality gap : the residual to the estimated maximal value. It is simple to use and ensures coverage of the state - space like softmax, but focuses exploration more on potentially promising actions than softmax. It also avoids overemphasizing sub -optimal actions that appear high - valued during learning. Experiments are conducted in tabular and deep RL environments.

This paper introduces a new concept called “ learnability lock ” for controlling the model ’s learnability on a specific dataset with a special key. The authors propose an adversarial invertible transformation that can be viewed as a mapping from image to image, to slightly modify data samples so that they become “ unlearnable ” by machine learning models with negligible loss of visual features. This ensures that the learnability can be easily restored with a simple inverse transformation while remaining difficult to be detected or reverse - engineered. Empirical results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method on visual classification tasks.

This paper proposes a novel method for handling missing features in graph neural networks ( GNNs ). The proposed method is based on the minimization of the Dirichlet energy and leads to a diffusion - type differential equation on the graph. The discretization of this equation produces a simple, fast and scalable algorithm which is called Feature Propagation. Experiments show that the proposed approach outperforms previous methods on seven common node - classification benchmarks and can withstand surprisingly high rates of missing features.

This paper studies the problem of active learning in the low - budget active learning setting where less than 1 % of the data set is labeled. The authors propose a method to select a core subset of the unlabeled data set that minimizes the discrete Wasserstein distance from the labeled data set. The core set is defined as the set of latent features that are most likely to be useful for unsupervised learning. The paper proposes a Generalized Benders Decomposition ( GBC ) algorithm to solve the problem. Experiments on several data sets show that the proposed method is competitive with baselines.

This paper presents a method for genome assembly using graph neural networks. The authors propose to use geometric deep learning to untangle a large assembly graph from which a genomic sequence needs to be reconstructed. A graph convolutional network is trained on a dataset generated from human genomic data to reconstruct the genome by finding a path through the assembly graph.   The authors show that the proposed method can compute scores from the lengths of the overlaps between the sequences and the graph topology. They also show that their method reconstructs the correct path through graph in the fraction of time required for the state - of - the - art de novo genome assemblers.

This paper proposes to store the samples ’ representations, instead of the samples themselves, into the replay buffer to improve the performance of the online - aware meta - learning ( OML ) method. Experiments show that the learned representations have better clustering structures and are more discriminative. The proposed method outperforms the state - of - the - art OML method on a number of benchmark datasets.

This paper studies the multi - agent joint Q - learning problem in the context of centralized training with decentralized execution ( CTDE ). The authors propose a new method to solve the credit assignment problem where each agent gives its suggestion about how to weight individual Q - values to explicitly maximize the joint Q-value, besides guaranteeing the Bellman optimality of the joint $ Q$ - value. Theoretically, the authors give a gradient ascent solution for this problem. Extensive experiments justify that ECAQ achieves interpretable credit assignment and superior performance compared to several advanced baselines.

This paper studies the robustness of transductive - learning based defenses against adversarial attacks. The authors propose a new defense framework, called Greedy Model Space Attack ( GMSA ), to attack the model space for solving bilevel attack objectives. The main idea is to train the model to be more robust to the model - space attack. Experiments are conducted on the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets to evaluate the effectiveness of GMSA.

This paper studies the problem of batch normalization, which is an important problem in neural network training. The authors focus on the case where the entire dataset is normalized jointly, and explore other ways to approximate the gradient from this limiting case. They demonstrate an approximation that removes the need to keep more than one example in memory at any given time, at the cost of a small factor increase in the training step computation, as well as a fully per - example training procedure. They further use their insights to improve batch renormalization for very small minibatches.

This paper proposes a low - rank adaptation method to reduce the number of trainable parameters for downstream tasks in natural language processing ( NLP ). The main idea is to freeze the pretrained model weights and injects trainable rank decomposition matrices into each layer of the Transformer architecture. The authors compare the performance of the proposed method with the fine - tuning of a standard NLP fine - tuned model ( GPT - 3 175B ). They show that their method can reduce the total number of parameters by 10,000 times and the GPU memory requirement by 3 times. They also provide an empirical investigation into the efficacy of their method.

This paper presents a generalization of linear - chain conditional random fields ( CRFs ) that can enforce a broad class of constraints, including non - local ones, by specifying the space of possible output structures as a regular language L. The resulting regular - concatenated CRF ( RegCCRF ) has the same formal properties as a standard CRF, but assigns zero probability to all label sequences not in L. The paper also shows empirically that constrained training is never worse than constrained decoding, and that it can be substantially substantially better in practice.

This paper proposes two neural models for camera - based physiological measurement called EfficientPhys that remove the need for face detection, segmentation, normalization, color space transformation or any other preprocessing steps. The proposed models achieve state - of - the - art accuracy on three public datasets. The authors evaluate the latency of the proposed networks and show that most most light weight network also achieves a 33 % improvement in efficiency.

This paper proposes Hardware - Aware Latency Pruning ( HALP ) to tackle the problem of structural pruning, aiming at maximizing the accuracy while constraining the latency under a predefined budget. The paper proposes two metrics, latency table and global saliency score, to evaluate the performance of the network during the pruning process. The proposed method is evaluated on ImageNet and VOC datasets.

This paper proposes GraphEBM, a molecular graph generation method via energy - based models ( EBMs ) to perform permutation invariant and multi - objective molecule generation. The authors propose a parameterized permutation - invariant energy function and learn the energy function by contrastive divergence and generate samples by Langevin dynamics. To generate molecules with a specific desirable property, they propose a simple yet effective learning strategy, which pushes down energies with flexible degrees according to the properties of corresponding molecules. They conduct comprehensive experiments on random, single - objective, and multi-objective molecule generation tasks.

This paper proposes a neural model - based bottom - up - search method for program synthesis. The key idea is to train a neural network to predict which programs to combine from a set of previously explored programs into new programs, taking into account the search history and partial program executions. The proposed method is evaluated on two very different domains, string manipulation and logic programming. The results show that the proposed method performs better than a combinatorial search algorithm in terms of the size of the search space.

This paper proposes a new method for deep reinforcement learning ( DRL ) based on regularization of the squared Bellman error. The proposed method is different from target networks in that the regularization is explicit and enables the use of up - to - date parameters as well as control the regularisation. Experiments are conducted on a range of Atari environments to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper presents a new perspective on designing powerful graph neural networks ( GNNs ). The authors propose a new hierarchy of local isomorphism on neighborhood subgraphs and theoretically characterize how message - passing GNN can be designed to be more expressive than the Weisfeiler Lehman test in distinguishing graph structures. They also propose a novel neural model, called GraphSNN, to elaborate this characterization and prove that this model is strictly more expressive. The paper also empirically verify the strength of the proposed model on different graph learning tasks.

This paper proposes a novel prediction interval ( PI ) method for uncertainty quantification, which addresses three major issues with the state - of - the - art PI methods. The PI3NN method calculates PIs from linear combinations of three neural networks ( NNs ), each of which is independently trained using the standard mean squared error loss. The coefficients of the linear combinations are computed using root - finding algorithms to ensure tight PIs for a series of confidence levels without retraining NNs and it completely avoids the crossing issue. Furthermore, the authors address OOD identification challenge by introducing an initialization scheme which provides reasonably larger PIs of the OOD samples than those of the in - distribution samples. Benchmark and real - world experiments show the proposed method outperforms several state -    approaches with respect to predictive uncertainty quality, robustness, and OOD sample identification.

This paper studies the problem of meta - learning in the online learning setting, where the task boundaries are not known to the learner. The authors propose a new algorithm, FOML, to address this problem. They show that the proposed algorithm is able to learn new tasks faster than the state - of - the - art online learning methods on the Rainbow - MNIST and CIFAR100 datasets.   The paper is well written and easy to follow.

This paper proposes a method for molecular optimization ( MO ). The main idea is to use a learned knowledge network to convert discrete chemical structures to locally differentiable ones. This is achieved by back - propagating the derivatives from the target properties through a graph neural network ( GNN ). Empirical results show that the proposed method is effective and sample efficient.

This paper studies the problem of predicting the lab test responses of personalized medical systems ( PMS ). The authors propose a knowledge - augmented approach to predict patients ’ response for a target lab result. The proposed method takes into account the drug - lab interaction and diagnosis - lab interactions as graphs and design a knowledge augmentation approach. Experiments on real - world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed solution in reducing prediction errors by a significant margin.

This paper studies the problem of open - set single domain generalization ( OS - SDG ), where the target domains may contain unseen categories out of the source label space. The authors propose a cross - match approach to improve the performance of the existing single - domain generalisation methods on identifying unknown classes by leveraging a multi - binary classifier. They also adopt a consistency regularization on generated auxiliary samples between multibinary classifiers and the model trained by SDG methods. Experimental results on benchmark datasets prove the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

This paper proposes two trust region methods for policy optimization based on the Kullback - Leibler divergence. The main idea is to directly optimize the policy distribution and derive their close - form policy updates based on Lagrangian duality. Theoretically, they show that WPO guarantees a monotonic performance improvement, and SPO provably converges to WPO as the entropic regularizer. Experiments on tabular domains and robotic locomotion tasks demonstrate the performance improvement of both approaches.

This paper proposes a forgetting - and - re - learning framework for neural network learning. The forgetting step selectively removes undesirable information from the model, and the relearning step reinforces features that are consistently useful under different conditions. This framework unifies many existing iterative training algorithms in the image classification and language emergence literature, and allows to understand the success of these algorithms in terms of the disproportionate forgetting of undesirable information. The authors leverage this understanding to improve upon existing algorithms by designing more targeted forgetting operations.

This paper studies the offline - online setting of reinforcement learning, where the agent has access to a batch of data to train on but is also allowed to learn during the evaluation phase in an online manner. This is an extension to batch RL, allowing the agent to adapt to new situations without having to precommit to a policy. In the experiments, the authors show that standard RL agents trained in an offline - Online manner can outperform agents trained only offline or online by a large margin.

This paper studies the problem of domain generalization ( DG ) via learning to reduce domain shift with an episodic training procedure. Theoretically, the authors give a PAC - style generalization bound for discrepancyoptimal meta - learning and further make comparisons with other DG bounds including ERM and domain - invariant learning. The theoretical analyses show that there is a trade - off between classification performance and computational complexity for discrepancy - optimal meta - Learning.   The theoretical results also shed light on a bilevel optimization algorithm for DG.

This paper studies the existence of left heavy tails in PSPACE - hard planning problems and proposes an explanation for the presence of these tails. The authors provide extensive experiment data supporting their model. The experiments show the critical role of the policy network as a powerful heuristic guiding the search, which can lead to left heavy tail with polynomial scaling by avoiding exploring exponentially sized sub - trees. The results also demonstrate the importance of random restart strategies for DNN - based search to avoid left and right heavy tails.

This paper presents a method for meta - imitation learning by translating human videos into practical robot demonstrations and train the meta - policy with adaptive loss based on the quality of the translated data. The approach relies only on human videos and does not require robot demonstration, which facilitates data collection and is more in line with human imitation behavior. Experiments show that the method achieves the comparable performance to the baseline on fast learning a set of vision - based tasks through watching a single video demonstration.

This paper studies the generalization performance of deep neural networks trained using gradient - based optimizers ( GATs ). The authors argue that without appropriately tuned regularization, such networks have the tendency to make output scores ( logits ) and network weights large, causing training loss to become too small and the network to lose its adaptivity (ability to move around and escape regions of poor generalization ) in the weight space. The main contribution of this paper is an analysis of the effect of weight decay ( WOD ) on the performance of adaptive optimizers in the image classification domain.

This paper studies the problem of group equivariant neural networks ( G - CNNs ). In particular, the authors propose a method to constrain features to respect the chosen symmetries, which is called partial equivariance. The authors claim that the proposed method is able to learn partial and full equivariances from data at every layer of the network, and is better suited to represent the data. Experiments are conducted on a synthetic dataset ( MNIST ) as well as a real dataset ( CIFAR-10 ). Results show that the method outperforms the state - of - the - art in terms of generalization.

This paper proposes a new deep latent variable model named the Langevin dynamics ( ALD ) for deep latent variables. The proposed method is based on amortized Langevin ( MCMC ) dynamics, where the datapoint - wise MCMC iterations are replaced with updates of an inference model that maps observations into latent variables, which enables scalable inference from large - scale datasets. The method is evaluated on toy datasets, and it is shown that ALD can obtain samples from target distributions in both conditional and unconditional cases, and ALD converges significantly faster than traditional MCMC.

This paper studies the problem of hypergraph reasoning, i.e., predicting the relationship between several entities based on the input facts. The authors observe that in logical reasoning, logical rules usually apply locally ( e.g., my parent ’s parent is my grandparent ) and sparsely (e.g., the grandparent relationship is sparse across all pairs of people in the world ). Inspired by these observations, the authors propose Sparse and Local Neural Logic Machines ( SpaLoc ) to leverage the sparsity in hypergraph neural networks. To remedy the information loss in sampled sub - graphs, the paper proposes a novel sampling and label calibration paradigm based on an information - theoretic measure information sufficiency. The paper shows superior accuracy and efficiency on synthetic datasets compared with prior art.

This paper proposes to relax the assumption that the top - k is a positive integer, such as 1 or 5, in machine learning. The authors propose to draw k from a probability distribution for training and propose a new family of differentiable top k cross - entropy classification losses. They find that relaxing k does not only produce better top - 5 accuracies, but also makes models more robust, which leads to top - 1 accuracy improvements. They also finetune publicly available ImageNet models.

This paper proposes a method for solving large - scale optimal transport ( OT ) problems at an unprecedented combination of speed and accuracy. The proposed method is based on the Douglas - Rachford splitting technique, which tackles the original OT problem directly instead of solving an approximate regularized problem. This allows to provide sparse transport plans and avoid numerical issues of methods that use entropic regularization. The algorithm has the same cost per iteration as the popular Sinkhorn method, and each iteration can be executed efficiently, in parallel.

This paper proposes a framework for disentangling performance gaps in generalization studies in federated learning. The framework is based on the notion of performance gap that separates out - of - sample gap ( OOD gap ) from performance gap from unseen client data ( participation gap ). The paper also proposes a dataset synthesis strategy that enables realistic simulation without naturally - partitioned data. Based on the findings, the paper calls out community suggestions for future Federated Learning works.

This paper studies the performance of language models ( PLMs ) in the zero - shot setting for few - shot tasks. The authors observe that PLMs perform well on a few widely - used datasets ( e.g. Amazon, IMDB, BERT ), but there are some limitations of PLMs under the zero shot setting, particularly for the language understanding tasks. To address these limitations, the authors propose a simple multi - null prompting ( without manually / auto - auto - created prompts ) strategy, which yields promising results on the IMDB and Amazon datasets.

This paper proposes a method to improve the performance of the attention mechanism. The proposed method is based on the alignment of the input image with the target image. This is achieved by the use of an image region - based attention module. Experiments are conducted on synthetic and real - world text recognition datasets.

This paper studies the problem of vehicle routing in the context of deep reinforcement learning. The authors propose a supervised deep learning framework that constructs a complete tour plan from scratch while respecting an apriori fixed number of available vehicles. The proposed approach is not only much faster and easier to solve but also achieves competitive results that incorporate the practical aspect of vehicle costs.    The authors conduct a number of experiments to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

This paper proposes a method for graph learning based on counterfactual inference. In particular, the authors consider the question “ would the link exist or not if the observed graph structure became different? ” to answer this question. The authors leverage causal models considering the information of the node pair ( i.e., learned graph representations ) as context and global graph structural properties as treatment, and link existence as outcome. Experiments on benchmark datasets show that this novel graph learning method achieves state - of - the - art performance on link prediction.

This paper proposes a two - stage method for unsupervised feature selection using knowledge contrastive disTillation ( SOFT ). In the first stage, SOFT learns a sparse attention matrix that represents second - order relations between features, and in the second stage, it builds a relational graph based on the learned attention matrix and perform graph segmentation for feature selection. Experimental results on 12 public datasets show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new multi - modal VAE model that combines information between modalities implicitly through mutual supervision. This formulation naturally allows learning from partially - observed data where some modalities can be entirely missing. Experiments are conducted on MNIST - SVHN ( image - image ) and CUB ( image-text ) datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed model.

This paper proposes Deep Explore Options ( DOUGE ), a method for learning from multiple intrinsic rewards in the Atari suite of games. The main idea is to use an intrinsic reward as a proxy for the extrinsic reward in order to learn from interesting behaviors in the environment. The paper claims that the proposed method outperforms the baselines in 4 of the 6 tested environments, and comparable performances in the other 2.   The paper also proposes a benchmarking study to ensure fairness.

This paper proposes a new method for learning Hamiltonian dynamical systems from data. The method is based on a stiffness - aware neural network ( SANN ) that splits the training data into stiff and non - stiff portions based on the stiffness index. The authors evaluate SANN on complex physical systems including a three - body problem and a billiard model. They show that SANN is more stable and can better preserve energy when compared with the state - of - the - art methods.

This paper studies the multi - step computation capability of large pre - trained language models. The main contribution of this paper is to train Transformers to perform multi step computations by asking them to emit intermediate computation steps into a “ scratchpad ”. The paper shows that these models are able to perform complex multistep computations, even in the few - shot regime, when asked to perform the operation “ step by step ”, showing the results of intermediate computations.

This paper presents a method for generating feature - level adversarial perturbations that are both interpretable and physically - realizable. The method is based on a deep neural network architecture and a novel optimization objective. The authors show that the proposed method can generate targeted feature level attacks at the ImageNet scale that are simultaneously interpretable, universal to any source image, and physically-realizable. These attacks can also reveal spurious, semantically - describable feature / class associations that can be exploited by novel combinations of natural objects.

This paper presents a method for solving stochastic annealing ( SA ) problems. The main contribution of the paper is the use of reinforcement learning to learn a policy for the proposal distribution of the temperature - annealed solutions. The proposed method is evaluated on a number of problems, including the Rosenbrock ’s function, the Knapsack problem, the Bin Packing problem, and the Travelling Salesperson problem. The results show that the proposed method outperforms baselines with hand - selected parameters.

This paper studies the non - stationarity problem in cooperative multi - agent reinforcement learning ( MARL ). The authors introduce a novel notion, the $ \delta$-stationarity, to explicitly measure the   non -   stationarity of a policy sequence, which is bounded by the KL divergence of consecutive joint policies. They propose a trust - region decomposition ( TRD - Net ) network to estimate the joint policy divergence more accurately. They also propose a Multi - Agent Mirror - Descent Policy ( MAMT ) algorithm to control the joint policies ’ divergence. The proposed method can bring noticeable and stable performance improvement compared with baselines in cooperative tasks.

This paper presents a self - supervised representation learning framework for audio - visual speech, which masks multi - stream video input and predicts automatically discovered and iteratively refined multimodal hidden units. On the largest public lip - reading benchmark LRS3 (433 hours ), AV - HuBERT achieves 32.5% WER with only 30 hours of labeled data, outperforming the former state - of - the - art approach ( 33.6%) trained with a thousand times more transcribed video data ( 31K hours ).

This paper proposes a novel reinforcement learning algorithm for combinatorial optimisation on graphs. The main idea is to restrict the graph neural network ( GNN ) to a single pre - processing step, before entering a fast - acting exploratory phase directed by a recurrent unit. The proposed algorithm is evaluated on the Maximum Cut Problem ( MCP ), where it achieves a new SOTA for RL algorithms on the maximum cut problem.

This paper studies the problem of training VAEs with discrete latent variables. The authors propose to train discrete VAEs by directly optimizing the distribution of the latent variables, which is different from standard VAE training methods such as sampling approximation, reparameterization trick, and amortization. The proposed method is based on evolutionary algorithms, where the optimization is done in a variational setting. The paper shows that direct optimization is more efficient than sampling - based methods and is competitive in zero - shot learning, denoising.

This paper proposes a method to identify the effects of an agent ’s actions on the environment. The proposed method is based on the counterfactual measures of blame, which are used to assign blame to the actions of the agent. The method is evaluated in a wide range of environments showing that it can accurately identify controlled effects. Moreover, the method is also integrated into the state - of - the - art exploration method, achieving substantially better performance than action - prediction methods.

This paper proposes structure - regularized pruning ( SRP ), which imposes regularization on the pruned structure to make sure the locations of pruned filters are aligned across different layers. The authors conduct extensive comparisons with both lightweight and larger image super - resolution ( SR ) networks. The proposed method achieves superior performance gains over recent methods quantitatively and visually.

This paper proposes a framework for few - shot learning that tackles large domain shift between base and novel categories. The first step of the framework trains a feature extracting backbone with the contrastive loss on the base category data. The second step trains a masking module to select relevant features that are more suited to target domain classification. To evaluate the proposed framework, the authors evaluate it on a recently introduced cross - domain few - shots learning benchmark.

This paper studies the generalization performance of neural networks trained by Bayesian inference and gradient descent. The authors study the generalisation performance of the neural network - based Gaussian process ( NNGP ) under two assumptions : ( 1 ) the number of functions returned by gradient descent is large, and ( 2 ) the network architecture is different from that of the training data. The main results of the paper are as follows : ( i ) the test error of neural network generalization is lower than that of training data, ( ii ) gradient descent can further improve generalisation by selecting networks with a large margin, ( iii ) generalization can be substantially improved by selecting a function with a much larger margin than is typical under the NNGP, ( iv ) generalisation generalization generalization error is already better than chance, corroborating the findings of Valle - Pérez et al.

This paper proposes a new method for cross - lingual transfer based on the manifold mixup ( X - mixup ) method, which adaptively calibrates the representation discrepancy and gives compromised representations for target languages. Experiments on the XTREME benchmark show X -Mixup achieves 1.8 % performance gains on multiple text understanding tasks, compared with strong baselines, and reduces the cross -lingual representation discrepancy significantly.

This paper studies Byzantine robust distributed learning ( Byzantine robust learning ), where a central server wants to train a machine learning model over data distributed across multiple workers. However, a fraction of these workers may deviate from the prescribed algorithm and send arbitrary messages to the central server, leading to significant loss of performance. The authors propose a simple bucketing scheme that adapts existing robust algorithms to heterogeneous datasets at a negligible computational cost. They theoretically and experimentally validate their approach, showing that it is effective against challenging attacks.

This paper studies the relationship between disentanglement and multi - task learning based on hard parameter sharing. The authors perform a thorough empirical study of the representations obtained by neural networks trained on automatically generated supervised tasks. They show that disentangling appears naturally during the process of multi - tasks neural network training. The paper is well - written and easy to follow.

This paper proposes a framework for certifying the robustness of per - state actions and the lower bound of cumulative rewards in reinforcement learning against adversarial state perturbations. The authors propose a local smoothing algorithm that uses a policy derived from Q - functions smoothed with Gaussian noise over each encountered state to guarantee robustness. They also propose a global smoothing method to certify the upper bound of a finite - horizon cumulative reward. The proposed framework is evaluated on three Atari games : RegPGD, RegCVX, and RadialRL achieve high certified robustness among these.

This paper proposes a new approach to conformal prediction in which it aims to output a precise set of promising prediction candidates that is guaranteed to contain a limited number of incorrect answers. The authors propose to trade coverage for precision by enforcing that the presence of incorrect candidates in the predicted conformal sets is bounded according to a user - specified tolerance. They then optimizes for a generalized notion of set coverage that allows for any number of true answers for a given query ( including zero ). They demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach across a number of classification tasks in natural language processing, computer vision, and computational chemistry.

This paper studies the complexity of functions computed by ReLU networks. The authors prove that the expected length distortion does not grow with depth, and indeed shrinks slightly, for ReLU network with standard random initialization. They also generalize this result by proving upper bounds both for higher moments of the length distortion and for the distortion of higher - dimensional volumes. The theoretical results are corroborated by empirical results.

This paper proposes a new method to accelerate the learning of safety - aware policies in reinforcement learning ( RL ). The proposed method is based on the behavioral prior learning ( BLEU ) method, which is used to extract safety primitives from offline data that encodes safety requirements, as well as the safety primitive skills over abstract actions in different scenarios. The main contribution of this paper is to propose a contrastive training method to extract the safety skills from the data. The method is evaluated on several tasks from the game Operation,1, where it outperforms baseline methods in learning successful policies and enforcing safety.

This paper proposes a multi - branch image restoration model inspired from the Human Visual System ( i.e., Retinal Ganglion Cells ) which can achieve multiple restoration tasks in a general framework. The experiments show that the proposed multi branch architecture, called CMFNet, has competitive performance results on four datasets, including image dehazing, deraindrop, and deblurring, which are very common applications for autonomous cars.

This paper studies the problem of Inference - Time Federated Learning ( IT - PFL ), where a model trained on a set of clients needs to be later evaluated on novel unlabeled clients at inference time. The authors propose a novel approach to this problem, IT-PFLHN, based on a hypernetwork module and an encoder module. The proposed method generalizes better than current FL and PFL methods, especially when the novel client has a large domain shift. The novel clients do not contribute their data to training and they can potentially have better control over their data privacy.

This paper presents a method to evaluate representations learned with self - supervised learning models. The method is based on a conditional diffusion based generative model ( RDM ). The authors show how this model ’s generation quality is on par with state - of - the - art generative models while being faithful to the representation used as conditioning. They also show that the representation learned with this model is not really invariant to many data augmentation tasks like classifications they were trained on.

This paper studies the Fp sketch, a well - celebrated streaming algorithm for frequency moments estimation. The authors prove that the algorithm is differentially private as is when p \in \mathbb{R}^n ( 0,1 ). The paper also provides an evaluation code for the algorithm, which is included in the supplementary material.

This paper proposes a novel method for reward - switching policy optimization ( RSPO ) in the context of reinforcement learning ( RL ). The main idea is to find a set of policies that are both locally optimal and sufficiently different from existing policies. The novelty of these policies is measured via a trajectory - based novelty measurement, and the authors propose to use an intrinsic diversity reward to encourage the learning policy to converge towards a previously undiscovered local optimum. Experiments show that the proposed method is able to discover a wide spectrum of strategies in a variety of domains, ranging from single - agent particle - world tasks and MuJoCo continuous control to multi - agent stag - hunter games and StarCraftII challenges.

This paper proposes a new method to speed up the generation of samples for diffusion models. The proposed method is based on the Generalized Gaussian Diffusion Models ( GGDM ) sampler, which is a family of flexible non - Markovian samplers for diffusion model. The authors show that optimizing the degrees of freedom of the sampler by maximizing sample quality scores via gradient descent leads to improved sample quality. Experiments are conducted on various datasets.

This paper studies the problem of large language modeling ( LLM ), where the quality of the factual information extracted from the model depends on the prompts used to query the model. The authors introduce P - Adapters, a lightweight model that sits between the embedding layer and first attention layer of LLMs. They take LLM embeddings as input and output continuous prompts that are used for query the LLM. They also investigate Mixture of Experts ( MoE ) models that learn a set of continuous prompts ( “experts ” ) and select one to query. They require a separate classifier trained on the continuous prompts to the continuous ones.

This paper proposes a continuous classification of time series ( CCTS ) method to achieve the high - accuracy classification at every time. Time series always evolves dynamically, changing features introducing the multi - distribution form. The authors propose a novel Adaptive model training policy ( ACCTS ) to address the two main problems : catastrophic forgetting and the over fitting. The experiments on four real - world datasets show that the proposed method can classify more accurately than all baselines.

This paper presents a method to extend language models with the ability to memorize the internal representations of past inputs. The authors propose to use a kNN to calculate the weights of past representations and then use this information to update the weights during the inference of the model. The paper is well written and easy to follow. Experiments are conducted on C4, arXiv, PPG-19, and Isabelle datasets.

This paper studies the problem of sampling samples from masked language modeling ( MLM ) models that specify a principled probability distribution over the space of possible sequences. The authors interpret MLMs as energy - based sequence models and propose two energy parametrizations derived from the trained MLMs. The samples are proposed from the same masked conditionals used for training the masked language models and are accepted or rejected based on their energy values according to the target distribution. The proposed method is validated by exploring the quality of samples drawn from these energy based models for both open - ended unconditional generation and a conditional generation task of machine translation.

This paper studies the problem of data augmentation in NLP. The authors propose a learning - based augmentation method to find the best augmentation strategy for each task. The proposed method is based on the idea of learning a good augmentation policy while training the model. The paper also proposes a sample re - weighting scheme to focus on difficult augmented samples after the original ones are learned confidently for more effective learning from the augmented ones.

This paper studies the problem of meta - learning for offline reinforcement learning ( OMRL ), which is an understudied problem with tremendous potential impact by enabling RL algorithms in many real - world applications. In this paper, the authors propose to improve upon one of the SOTA OMRL algorithms, FOCAL, by incorporating intra - task attention mechanism and inter - task contrastive learning objectives, to robustify task representation learning against sparse reward and distribution shift. Theoretical analysis and experiments are presented to demonstrate the superior performance and robustness of the proposed method compared to prior algorithms across multiple meta - RL benchmarks.

This paper proposes an inference - time improvement framework for parametric sequential generative modeling methods called belief fine - tuning ( BFT ). BFT leverages approximate dynamic programming to determine the model parameters at each time step. It can improve the accuracy of the belief model at test time because it specializes the capacity of the model to the space of local observations. Experiments are conducted on large - scale variants of the benchmark game Hanabi.

This paper studies the problem of sparse training of neural networks. The authors propose to optimize over a continuous superset of sparse matrices with a fixed structure known as products of butterfly matrices. The paper uses a simple fixed sparsity pattern based on a block and flat sparsity matrices to find a sparsity mask over a discrete set of matrices for sparse training. They validate their method on the ImageNet classification and WikiText-103 language modeling tasks with no drop in accuracy.

This paper studies the problem of conditional diffusion probabilistic models for score - based generative models. The authors first study the changes of data distribution during the forward process of the Markov chain and explore the class clustering phenomenon. Then, the authors propose a conditional diffusion model by explicitly modeling the class center in the forward and reverse process and make an elegant modification to the original formulation, which enables controllable generation and interpretability. Extensive experiments on multiple tasks are conducted to verify the effectiveness of the formulated framework.

This paper proposes a method for domain generalization ( DG ) based on domain - invariant features and common hypotheses learned from a set of training domains. The authors argue that this assumption could be overly strict and sub - optimal when source domains share little information or the target domains leverages information from selective source domains in a compositional way instead of relying on a unique invariant hypothesis across all source domains. Instead of constructing a single hypothesis shared among domains, the authors propose a LAtent Sub - Space Orientation ( LASSO ) method that explores diverse latent sub - spaces and learning individual hypotheses on those sub - spaces. The proposed method is evaluated on several well - known DG benchmarks, where it achieves state - of - the - art results.

This paper studies the problem of compressing a probability distribution more effectively than independent sampling by targeting a reproducing kernel Hilbert space ( RKHS ) and leveraging a less smooth squareroot kernel. The authors provide four improvements over the original KT algorithm, including the use of a fractional power kernel and a tighter individual function guarantee for any kernel, any distribution, and any fixed function in the target kernel space. They also show that, for analytic kernels like Gaussian, inverse multiquadric, and sinc, target KT admits maximum mean discrepancy ( MMD ) guarantees comparable to or better than those of square - root KT without making explicit use of square root kernel.

This paper presents an open - source benchmark suite for the MAXIMUM INDEPENDENT SET problem, in both its weighted and unweighted variants. The suite offers a unified interface to various state - of - the - art traditional and machine learning - based solvers. The authors also conduct an in - depth analysis of the popular guided tree search algorithm by Li et al. ( NeurIPS 2018 ) by testing various configurations on small and large synthetic and real - world graphs. The analysis shows that the graph convolution network used in the tree search does not learn a meaningful representation of the solution structure, and can in fact be replaced by random values.

This paper proposes Wavelet Compressed Convolutional Neural Networks ( WCC ), a novel approach for activation maps compression for 1 - 1 convolutions ( the workhorse of modern CNNs ). The authors propose compression ratios and computational savings that are equivalent to low - bit quantization rates at a relatively minimal loss of accuracy. To this end, they use a hardware - friendly Haar - Wavelet transform, known for its effectiveness in image compression, to define the convolution on the compressed activation map. The experimental results show that the proposed WCC achieves compression rates equal to 2 - bit and 1 - bit with minimal degradation.

This paper studies the problem of learning the correlated and coarse correlated equilibria in extensive form games. The authors propose a method to accelerate the learning dynamics for extensive form correlated equilibrium ( EFCE ) in multiplayer general - sum imperfect - information extensive - form games, which can capture sequential and simultaneous moves, as well as imperfect information. The main contribution of the paper is the development of a faster no - regret learning dynamics to learn the correlated distribution of play is an O(T 3/4)-approximate EFCEs, which significantly improves over the best prior rate of O ( T 1/2 ).   The authors also propose a refined perturbation analysis of a structured Markov chain.

This paper proposes a novel method to learn a discretization of continuous action spaces by leveraging the priors of demonstrations. The proposed method is evaluated on three different scenarios : RL with demonstrations, RL with play data, and RL with human data. The results show that the proposed method outperforms the state - of - the - art continuous control methods in terms of performance and sample efficiency on a variety of hard manipulation tasks.

This paper studies the problem of generalization in semantic segmentation. The authors propose a novel adversarial style augmentation ( AdvStyle ) approach, which can dynamically generate hard stylized images during training and thus can effectively prevent the model from overfitting on the source domain. Experiments on two synthetic - to - real datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a neuromorphic gesture recognition system that encodes event - based gesture data at high temporal resolution into a latent space representation suitable to compute the similarity of mid - air gesture data. The proposed method is based on the Variational Autoencoder ( VAE ) and the Dynamic Vision Sensor ( DVS ) dataset. The VAE achieves 87 % classification accuracy on the DVSGesture dataset and it can encode the sparse, noisy inputs into an interpretable latent representation, visualized through T - SNE plots.

This paper proposes a method for deep learning for tabular data. The method is based on sparse hierarchical table ensembles ( S - HTE ), where the nodes of the tree are sparse at the beginning of the training process and gradually sparse using an annealing mechanism, leading to an efficient final predictor. Unlike previous work with ferns, S -HTE learns useful internal representations and it earns from increasing depth, while having an order of magnitude lower computational complexity. Experiments are conducted on a standard classification and regression benchmark.

This paper studies the problem of learning value functions from state - only experience. The authors first theoretically characterize the applicability of tabular Q - learning in discrete Markov decision processes ( MDPs ). This theoretical result motivates the design of Latent Action Q - Learning ( LAQ ), an offline RL method that can learn effective value functions. The experiments in 5 environments demonstrate the benefits of LAQ over simpler alternatives, imitation learning oracles, and competing methods.

This paper studies the problem of training large models with billions of parameters. The authors propose SWARM Parallelism1 — a model - parallel training algorithm designed for swarms of poorly connected, heterogeneous, unreliable devices. The proposed method trains a large Transformer language model with 1.1B shared parameters ( < 13B before sharing ) on a swarm of preemptible T4 GPUs with less than 400 Mb / s network throughput. The paper also proposes several compression - aware architecture modifications to further reduce the network usage of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of online fine - tuning in multi - agent reinforcement learning ( MARL ). The authors claim that the transition dynamics in offline MARL do not match the dynamics in online MARL due to the discrepancy between the behavior policy and learned policy. To address this discrepancy, the authors introduce online transition correction ( OTC ) to implicitly correct the biased transition dynamics by modifying sampling probabilities. They also propose an adaptive rank - based prioritization to sample transitions according to the transition similarity between transitions. Empirically, they show that OTC outperforms baselines in a variety of tasks.

This paper proposes a method to quantize the forward phase of neural network training from 4 bits to 4 bits. The proposed method is based on the logarithmic quantization of the gradients with respect to the outputs of intermediate neural layers. The authors also propose a method that exploits the low precision format by avoiding multiplications during two - thirds of the training process, thus reducing by 5x the area used by the multiplier. The experimental results show that the proposed method achieves state - of - the - art results in 4 - bit training.

This paper studies the problem of polythetic classifications, which are common in the natural world and greatly outnumber monothetic classifications over a set of features. The authors show that threshold meta - learners, such as Prototypical Networks, require an embedding dimension that is exponential in the number of task - relevant features to emulate these functions. In contrast, attentional classifiers such as Matching Networks are poly - thetic by default and are able to solve these problems with linear embedding dimensions. To address this challenge, the authors propose a self - attention feature - selection mechanism that adaptively dilutes non - discriminative features, and synthetic and real - world few - shot learning tasks.

This paper studies the emergence of language between agents using a continuous communication channel trained through reinforcement learning. The authors propose an environment and training methodology to carry out an initial exploration of these questions. They use a simple messaging environment where a “ speaker ” agent needs to convey a concept to a listener. The speaker is equipped with a vocoder that maps symbols to a continuous waveform, and the listener needs to map the continuous signal to the concept. They show that basic compositionality emerges in the learned language representations. They also show that noise is essential in the communication channel when conveying unseen concept combinations.

This paper studies the problem of backdoor attacks against pre - trained natural language processing ( NLP ) models. The authors propose BadPre, a task - agnostic backdoor attack that can be applied to a wide range of downstream NLP tasks. The key feature of the attack is that the adversary does not need prior information about the downstream tasks when implanting the backdoor to the model. When this malicious model is released, any downstream models transferred from it will also inherit the backdoor. Experimental results indicate that the proposed approach can compromise a range of tasks in an effective way.

This paper proposes a new framework for skill discovery, where skills are learned one after another in an incremental fashion. This framework allows newly learned skills to adapt to new environment or agent dynamics, while the fixed old skills are fixed. Experiments are conducted in both evolving and static environments, incremental skills are significantly outperform current state - of - the - art skill discovery methods.

This paper proposes a novel log - polar space convolution ( LPSC ) layer, where the convolution kernel is elliptical and adaptively divides its local receptive field into different regions according to the relative directions and logarithmic distances. Experiments on different tasks and datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed layer.

This paper studies the generalization ability of neural networks ( NNs ). The authors propose an algorithm for the efficient approximation of the information bottleneck ( i.e., the compression of information stored in weights ( IIW ), which is proved to play a key role in NNs generalization based on the PAC - Bayes theorem. They also propose an MCMC - based algorithm to sample from the optimal weight posterior characterized by PIB, which fulfills the potential of IIW in enhancing NNs in practice.

Data poisoning attacks are attacks that add imperceptible perturbations to training data to maximize the test error. In this paper, the authors investigate why these attacks work in principle. They find that the perturbation of advanced attacks are almost linear separable when assigned with the target labels of the corresponding samples. They further confirm that linear separability is indeed the workhorse for recent attacks. The authors synthesize linear - separable data as perturbated data as well as synthetic perturbants are as powerful as the deliberately crafted attacks.

This paper studies the problem of importance sampling in offline policy optimization. The authors identify an important overfitting phenomenon in the importance weighted return estimator, and propose an algorithm to avoid this overfitting. They provide a theoretical justification of the proposed algorithm through a better per - state - neighbor normalization condition, and show the limitation of previous attempts to this approach through an illustrative example. They further test the proposed method in a healthcare - inspired simulator and a logged dataset collected from real hospitals.

This paper presents a simple yet effective model for continual learning of how language is grounded in vision. Given a pre - trained multimodal embedding model, where language and images are projected in the same semantic space ( CLIP by OpenAI ), CoLLIE learns a transformation function that adjusts the language embeddings when needed to accommodate new language use. Unlike traditional few - shot learning, the model does not just learn new classes and labels, but can also generalize to similar language uses. The model is evaluated on two different tasks of continual learning and show that it can efficiently learn and generalize from only a few examples, with little interference with the model's original zero - shot performance.

This paper studies the problem of novel object captioning, i.e., the task of generating novel object captions in the absence of the training image captioning models. The authors propose a novel method, VLAF2, for learning visual information of images with novel objects. They evaluate the effectiveness of their method on the nocaps dataset on the following metrics : fluency, fidelity, and adequacy. They also perform quantitative and qualitative analysis to demonstrate how their model generates novel captions with improved fluency and fidelity.

This paper studies the problem of transfer learning in the few - shot setting. The authors study the phenomenon of neural collapse, where the features learned by overparameterized classification networks show an interesting clustering property, called neural collapse. They demonstrate both theoretically and empirically that neural collapse generalizes to new samples from the training classes and – more importantly – to new classes as well, allowing foundation models to provide feature maps that work well in transfer learning.

This paper proposes a deep point cloud reconstruction network consisting of two stages : 1 ) a 3D sparse stacked - hourglass network as for the initial densification and denoising, and 2 ) a refinement via transformers converting the discrete voxels into 3D points. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed network achieves state - of - the - art performance among the recent studies in the ScanNet, ICL - NUIM, and ShapeNetPart datasets. The paper also proposes a module called amplified positional encoding to amplify the magnitude of positional encoding vectors based on the points ’ distances for adaptive refinements.

This paper studies the problem of distributed GCN training. The authors propose PipeGCN, a simple - yet - effective scheme that hides the communication overhead by pipelining inter - partition communication with intra - party computation. The paper also proposes a smoothing method to further improve the convergence rate of the proposed method. Extensive experiments are conducted to validate the effectiveness of the method.

This paper studies the problem of test - time robustification, i.e., using the test input to improve model robustness. The authors propose a simple approach that can be used in any test setting where the model is probabilistic and adaptable. They evaluate two baseline ResNet models, two robust ResNet - 50 models, and a robust vision transformer model, and demonstrate that this approach achieves accuracy gains of 1 - 8 % over standard model evaluation and also generally outperforms prior augmentation and adaptation strategies.

This paper proposes a single objective for jointly training the model and the policy, such that updates to either component increase a lower bound on expected return, and this bound becomes tight under certain assumptions. The resulting algorithm ( MnM ) is conceptually similar to a GAN : a classifier distinguishes between real and fake transitions, the model is updated to produce transitions that look realistic, and the policies are updated to avoid states where the model predictions are unrealistic. The paper is well - written and easy to follow.

This paper proposes a simple model combination approach inspired by human decision making : first compute a coarse action based on the instantaneous observation, and then refine it into a final action using historical information. The experiments show that this outperforms all baselines on CARLA autonomous driving from images and various MuJoCo continuous control tasks. The paper also proposes a “ coarse - to - fine ” imitator that combines advantages of each method and outperforms both.

This paper proposes a model - based meta - learning method called DyAd to generalize across heterogeneous domains by partitioning them into different tasks. DyAd has two parts : an encoder which infers the time - invariant hidden features of the task with weak supervision, and a forecaster which learns the shared dynamics of the entire domain. The encoder adapts and controls the forecaster during inference using adaptive instance normalization and adaptive padding. Theoretically, the generalization error of such procedure is related to the task relatedness in the source domain, as well as the domain differences between source and target domains.

This paper studies the problem of weakly supervised monocular 3D object detection. The authors first detect 2D boxes on the image and then adopt the generated 2D box to select corresponding RoI LiDAR points as the weak supervision. The network is learned by minimizing the newly proposed 3D box alignment loss between the newly - Proposed 3D boxes and the corresponding corresponding RoDAR point clouds. The proposed method outperforms many prior fully - supervised methods.

This paper proposes a new model inductive bias that learns a subword tokenization end - to - end as part of the state - of - the - art NLP models. The proposed method is based on a soft gradient - based sub - word tokenization module ( GBST ) that automatically learns latent subword representations from characters in a data - driven fashion. Experiments on English GLUE, multilingual, and noisy text datasets are conducted to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a method to detect backdoors in black - box deep neural networks ( DNNs ) under the hard - label scenario where only the final output label of the DNN is accessible. The proposed method is based on an adversarial analysis of the adversarial map of the backdoors. The authors show that the objective of backdoor detection is bounded by a singularity that is often observed in the map of a backdoorinfected example, which they refer to as the “ adversarial singularity ”. The method is evaluated on several tasks and backdoor attacks and is shown to be effective in detecting backdoor attacks.

This paper proposes a new measure for estimating in - distribution and out - of - distribution ( OOD ) uncertainty. The proposed measure is based on a Kullback - Leibler divergence criterion defined on the class - probability simplex, which captures class confusion and lack of evidence in a single score. The paper also proposes an auxiliary neural network, KLoSNet, to learn a refined criterion directly aligned with the evidential training objective in the realistic context where no OOD data is available during training. The experiments show that the proposed measure outperforms first - order and second - order uncertainty measures to simultaneously detect misclassifications and OOD samples.

This paper studies the problem of semi - supervised learning of linear networks ( CNNs ) from unlabeled data. The authors propose an algorithm that learns a linear classifier over datadependent features which are obtained from unlabelled data. They show that the algorithm provably learns CNNs, under some natural distributional assumptions. They also provide a lower bound on the dependence of their algorithm on the dimension of the patch distribution is essentially optimal.

This paper proposes to cluster faces by constructing clean graphs for Graph Convolutional Networks ( GCN ). The paper proposes a new algorithm named Ada - NETS to convert faces to a new structure space, obtaining robust features by considering face features of the neighbour images. Experiments on multiple public clustering datasets show that Ada -NETS significantly outperforms current state - of - the - art methods, proving its superiority and generalization.

This paper studies the problem of distributionally robust optimization ( DRO ) for learning ready - to - use cross - domain representations for direct cross - data evaluation. The authors propose a simple yet efficient approach, Unit DRO, to learn robust models that are able to perform well on a collection of possible data distributions ( the “uncertainty set ” ) without demographics. Empirical results show that unit DRO achieves superior performance on large - scale DG ReID benchmarks compared to standard baselines.    The main contribution of this paper is the application of the change - of - technique technique and the analytical solution of KL DRO.

This paper proposes a simple technique to improve training of graph neural networks ( GNNs ) by adding noise to the input graph and a noise correcting node - level loss. The paper claims that the noise correction loss helps ameliorate oversmoothing by encouraging diverse node latents. Experiments are conducted on the Open Graph Benchmark ( OGB ) dataset and on the OGB for 3D molecular property prediction dataset.

This paper studies the set2vec problem, which is the task of extracting a vector representation from an input set comprised of a variable number of feature vectors. The authors propose a method to solve this problem based on the maximum - a - posterior ( MAP - EM ) steps. The proposed method is evaluated on various tasks and is shown to be competitive with the state - of - the - art.

This paper studies the problem of feature selection in the contrastive analysis ( CA ) setting, where the goal is to select a small number of informative features for use in unknown downstream tasks. The authors propose a method, CFS ( Contrastive Feature Selection ), to perform feature selection for the CA setting. They evaluate their method on a semi - synthetic dataset and four real - world biomedical datasets, and they find that it consistently outperforms previous state - of - the - art methods designed for standard unsupervised feature selection scenarios.

This paper studies the relationship between optimal early stopping time and model dimension as well as sample size of the dataset for certain linear regression models. Theoretical results are provided to show that in common deep learning tasks, the dimension of the model often exceeds the number of features arising from data. The paper also provides theoretical results on the effect of early stopping on generalization.

This paper proposes a quasi - Newton method for the policy gradient algorithm with entropy regularization for the Shannon entropy. The authors provide a simple proof that all these algorithms enjoy the Newton - type quadratic convergence near the optimal policy. They demonstrate that the proposed quasi - Newton method typically converges in single - digit iterations, often orders of magnitude faster than other state - of - the - art algorithms.

This paper proposes a general method to generalize out of the training distribution for text - based games ( TBGs ). The method is based on the use of case - based reasoning to train agents and generalize. The proposed method collects instances of positive experiences from the agent ’s interaction with the world in the past and later reuses the collected experiences to act efficiently. Experiments show that the proposed approach consistently improves existing methods, especially under distributional shifts.

This paper proposes a two - stage method to distill multiple word senses from a pre - trained contextual language model ( BERT ) by using attention over the senses of a word in a context and transferring this sense information to fit multi - sense embeddings in a skip - gram - like framework. The paper demonstrates an effective approach to training the sense disambiguation mechanism in BERT with a distribution over word senses extracted from the output layers of BERT. Experiments on the contextual word similarity and sense induction tasks show that this method is effective.

This paper proposes to use the same architecture and pretrained weights of a neural net model to understand both images and point - clouds. Specifically, they transfer the image - pretrained model to a 3D point cloud model by inflating 2D convolutional filters and finetuning the inflated imagepretrained models ( FIP ). They find that FIP improves data efficiency, reaching up to 10.0 points top - 1 accuracy gain on few - shot classification, and speeds up training of point cloud models by up to 11.1x.

This paper proposes a method for training the autoregressive generative model that takes advantage of the energy - based learning objective. The proposed method is capable of alleviating the exposure bias problem and increase temporal coherence by imposing a constraint which fits joint distributions at each time step. Extensive empirical results are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

This paper presents a unified framework that connects Wasserstein distributional robustness with current state - of - the - art AT - based methods. In particular, the authors introduce a new series of risk functions, with which they show that standard AT methods are special cases of their counterparts in their framework. Extensive experiments show that the proposed algorithms robustify further their standard AT counterparts in various settings.

This paper proposes a novel method for unsupervised representation learning for multivariate time series. The proposed method is based on bilinear feature representation learning. The authors propose to apply dropout on the entire time series for better preserving global context and capturing long - term dependencies. Extensive experiments are conducted on three major practical tasks for time series such as classification, forecasting and anomaly detection. Results shows that the proposed method achieves the superiority over the state - of - the - art methods and surpasses them by a large margin across downstream tasks.

This paper proposes to train the learning rate along with the model weights, akin to line - search. Learning rate is optimized via a simple extra gradient descent step, justified by an analysis that exploits the structure of neural networks. Extensive experimental evaluation is conducted, validating the effectiveness of the proposed method for a plethora of different settings.

This paper proposes a meta - learning method for sequential multi - task learning, where the goal is to achieve high reward over any sequence of tasks quickly. The authors propose a method, continual meta - policy search ( CoMPS ), that removes this limitation by meta - training in an incremental fashion, over each task in a sequence, without revisiting prior tasks. Experiments are conducted on several sequences of challenging continuous control tasks. Results show that the proposed method outperforms prior continual learning and off - policy meta - RL methods.

This paper proposes a new threat model for poisoned classifiers, where one without the knowledge of the original trigger would want to control the poisoned classifier. The authors propose a test - time, human - in - the - loop attack method to generate multiple effective alternative triggers without access to the initial backdoor and the training data. They demonstrate the effectiveness of their attack through extensive experiments on high - resolution datasets : ImageNet and TrojAI. They also compare their method to previous work on modeling trigger distributions and find that their method are more scalable and efficient in generating effective triggers.

This paper proposes a new method for distilling unconditional GANs. The main challenge lies in the output discrepancy issue, where the teacher and student models yield different outputs given the same input latent code. The authors conduct thorough analysis about the reasons and effects of this discrepancy issue and identify that the style module plays a vital role in determining semantic information of generated images. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper presents a general methodology for approximating offline algorithms in an online setting. The main contribution of the paper is to train a multi - task learning model to simultaneously detect behavioral structures which have already occurred and predict those that may come next. The methodology is demonstrated on both synthetic data and historical stock market data, where the contrast between explanation and prediction is particularly stark.

This paper proposes a method for sparse Gaussian Processes ( GPs ). The main idea is to use sparse GP approximations to reduce the number of inducing points introduced during training. The inducing points are chosen by considering them as parameters of an approximate posterior distribution q. The paper proposes to use a neural network that receives the observed data as an input and outputs the inducing points locations and the parameters of q. Experiments are conducted on several datasets to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a protocol for secure ( Byzantinetolerant ) decentralized training that emphasizes communication efficiency. The authors provide theoretical bounds for its resistance against Byzantine and Sybil attacks and conduct large - scale experiments on image classification and language modeling in presence of Byzantine attackers. The paper is well - written and easy to follow.

This paper proposes a method for learning SPH - informed fluid simulators using physics - informed parameters and Neural Networks as universal function approximators. The authors propose a mixed - mode approach, mixing forward and reverse mode automatic differentiation with forward and adjoint based sensitivity analyses to efficiently perform gradient based optimization. The proposed method is capable of solving inverse problems over the physically interpretable parameter space, as well as over the space of Neural Network parameters.

This paper proposes an approach to regularize a single deterministic neural network to obtain improved accuracy and reliable uncertainty estimates. The proposed approach is based on an entropy maximization regularizer corresponding to the predictive distribution in the regions of the embedding space between the class clusters. This is achieved by synthetically generating between - cluster samples via the convex combination of two images from different classes and maximizing the entropy on these samples. Experiments are conducted on two real - world datasets ( CIFAR-10 and CifAR-100 ) using ResNet and Wide - ResNet architectures to demonstrate that the proposed approach consistently provides much improved classification accuracy and better calibrated probabilities for in - distribution data.

This paper proposes a new method for image - to - image animating based on linear navigation in the latent space. The key idea is to use a linear navigation network to map the image to a latent space of interest in the source image. The proposed method is evaluated on three datasets ( VoxCeleb, Taichi and TED - Talk ) and achieves state - of - the - art results.   The paper is well - written and easy to follow.

This paper proposes a method for meta - learning with task interpolation ( MLTI ) to generate additional tasks by randomly sampling a pair of tasks and interpolating the corresponding features and labels in the task space. The proposed method is generalizable to a data - adaptive meta - regularization setting under both gradient - based and metric - based settings. Experiments are conducted on eight datasets from diverse domains including image recognition, prediction, and medical image classification.

This paper proposes a new approach for fair representation learning ( FRL ). The proposed approach is based on normalizing flows that are trained to minimize the statistical distance between the latent representations of different groups. The main advantage of FNF is that its exact likelihood computation allows us to obtain guarantees on the maximum unfairness of any potentially adversarial downstream predictor. Experiments are conducted on a variety of datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

This paper proposes a novel graph neural network ( GNN ) based method for subgraph isomorphism counting. The main idea is to use edge - centric message passing mechanism, where edges are treated as first - class citizens. The proposed method is evaluated on a number of benchmark datasets and is shown to be competitive with the state - of - the - art baselines.

This paper studies the problem of federated learning where each client may have their own personalized labels, which might not be compatible with others ( even for the same class ). The authors propose a novel method, Agnostic Personalized Federated Learning ( APFL ), where any clients, regardless of what they have learned with their personalized labels can collaboratively learn while benefiting each other. The method measures task - level similarity based on locally learned knowledge and matches the relevant ones for personalized knowledge reflection and factorizes parameters into two basis vectors and the highly sparse masks to significantly reduce the dimensionlaity of parameter space for alleviating knowledge collapse and information loss when reflecting the heterogeneous knowledge. Experiments are conducted on both single and multi - domain datasets.

This paper proposes a method to learn object - centric representations of scenes with multiple objects in a video. The method is based on object dynamics and distills explicit object dynamic representations ( e.g. velocity ) from raw video input.
