The authors also build a relation module that calculates object - pair interactions and applies it to the corresponding dynamic representations of objects. Experiments are conducted on tasks of video events reasoning and video prediction, which are two important evaluations for video understanding.

Graph neural networks ( GNN ) have shown great advantages in many graph - based learning tasks but often fail to predict accurately for a task based on sets of nodes such as link / Motif prediction and so on. Many works have recently proposed to address this problem by using random node features or node distance features. However, they suffer from either slow convergence, inaccurate prediction or high complexity. In this work, the authors propose a class of GNN layers termed PEG with rigorous mathematical analysis. Extensive link prediction experiments over 8 real - world networks demonstrate the advantages of PEG in generalization and scalability.

This paper proposes a method for text style transfer based on large - scale language models. The key idea is to train the model on the parallel expressions in the non - parallel datasets with scene graphs, and then employ MLE training, followed by imitation learning refinement, to leverage the intrinsic parallelism within the data. Experiments on two benchmark tasks (sentiment & formality transfer ) and a newly proposed challenging task ( political stance transfer ) demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of multi - hop logical reasoning on knowledge graphs ( KGs ). In particular, the authors study how to embed and answer hyper - relational queries on KGs. The authors propose a method to answer such queries and demonstrate in their experiments that qualifiers improve QA on a diverse set of query patterns. The paper is well - written and easy to follow. However, there are a few concerns :

This paper proposes a method for hyperparameter optimization in the gray - box setting. The main contribution of the paper is to propose a new surrogate for Gaussian Processes that embeds the learning curve dynamics and a new acquisition function that incorporates multi - budget information. The proposed method is evaluated on large - scale experiments against state - of - the - art baselines on 50 datasets ( Tabular, Image, NLP ).

This paper proposes a method to improve the performance of learned image compression. The main contribution of this paper is to introduce post - training quantization and make the model inference integer - arithmetic - only, which is much simpler than the existing training and fine - tuning - based approaches. Based on that, the authors further improve the discretization of the entropy parameters and extend the deterministic inference to fit Gaussian mixture models.

This paper proposes a network for denoising scanning electron microscopy images by synthesizing the sequential data from the FIB - SEM data set. The architecture is inspired by gated recurrent units, which reconstructs and removes the noise by reconstructing and removing the noise. The network is fully unsupervised and achieves comparable or even better results than supervised approaches on 3D electron microscope data sets.

This paper studies the label trick in graph neural networks ( GNNs ). The authors propose to use a randomly - selected portion of the training labels as GNN inputs, concatenated with the original node features for making predictions on the remaining labels. They prove that under certain simplifying assumptions, the stochastic label trick can be reduced to an interpretable, deterministic training objective composed of two factors. The first is a data - fitting term that naturally resolves potential label leakage issues, while the second is a regularization factor conditioned on graph structure that adapts to graph size and connectivity. They leverage this perspective to motivate a broader range of label trick use cases, and provide experiments to verify the efficacy of these extensions.

This paper studies the problem of modeling the theory of mind ( ToM ) in a multi - agent environment where agents are able to speak, listen, see other agents, and move freely through a grid world. The authors propose to model the ToM problem in a more flexible and symmetric scenario, where all agents can talk, listen and see each other agents'mental states. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new multiagent environment SymmToM, where agents can speak, see, and interact with each other in an open - ended way. Experiments are conducted on a number of tasks, and the authors show that the proposed model is able to improve the performance of agents with no ToM.

This paper studies the problem of zero - shot object detection in the context of industrial manufacturing. The authors propose a method to detect objects in an indoor scene from a dataset of 21 objects. The method is based on the knowledge learned from and only from seen objects. To train the system, the authors use the YCB Video Dataset, which contains 21 objects in various categories. The dataset is also used for training the system.

This paper proposes a method to train an autoregressive latent video prediction model capable of predicting high - fidelity future frames with minimal modification to existing models, and produce high - resolution ( 256x256 ) videos. The proposed method is based on an image generator model with a causal transformer model, which is combined with a high - fidelity image generator ( VQ - GAN ). The authors evaluate the proposed method on standard video prediction benchmarks with fewer parameters, and enables high resolution video prediction.

This paper studies the problem of training generative adversarial networks ( GANs ) with vision transformers ( ViTs ). The authors claim that existing methods for GAN training interact poorly with self - attention, causing instability during training. To resolve this issue, the authors introduce several novel regularization techniques for training GAN - based ViTs with ViTs. Experiments are conducted on three datasets : CIFAR-10, CelebA, and LSUN.

This paper proposes to decompose the task of generative modeling explicitly into two steps : first prioritize the modeling of visually perceptible information to achieve good sample quality, and then subsequently model the imperceptible information — the bulk of the likelihood signal — to achieve a good likelihood signal. The paper is well - written and easy to follow, and the results are convincing. However, there are a few issues with the paper that need to be addressed.

This paper proposes a training - free inference framework for estimating the optimal reverse variance and optimal KL divergence of Diffusion Probabilistic Models ( DPMs ). The main idea is to use the Monte Carlo method and a score - based model to estimate the analytic forms of the variance and KL divergence using the score function of a DPM. The authors also derive both the lower and upper bounds of the optimal variance and the optimal KL divergences using the proposed framework. The proposed framework is evaluated on the log - likelihood of various DPM models.

This paper studies the performance of vision transformers ( ViTs ) on medical image classification tasks. The authors consider the question of whether it is feasible to switch to transformer - based models for medical image classifying as well, or if we should keep working with CNNs – can we trivially replace CNNs with transformers? The authors conduct a series of experiments on several standard medical image benchmark datasets and tasks and show that while CNNs perform better if trained from scratch, ViTs perform better when pretrained on ImageNet, both in supervised and self - supervised setting.

This paper studies the problem of pretraining neural language models ( NLMs ) over a large corpus of text. The authors show that the pretrained NLM can model much stronger dependencies between text segments that appeared in the same training example, than it can between different training examples. This intuitive result has twofold role. First, it formalizes the motivation behind a broad line of recent successful NLM training heuristics, proposed for the pretraining and fine - tuning stages, which do not necessarily appear related at first glance. Second, it clearly indicates further improvements to be made in NLM pretraining for the benefit of natural language understanding tasks.

This paper studies the problem of learning to optimize ( L2O ). The authors propose a lightweight model that can be meta - trained on large - scale problems and outperformed human - designed and tuned optimizers. The paper also proposes a new tool of symbolic regression to improve the interpretability of the existing models.   The paper is well - written and easy to follow, and the proposed method is easy to implement. However, the paper suffers from a lack of novelty and is difficult to follow.

This paper studies the robustness of deep neural networks against adversarial attacks in reinforcement learning ( RL ). In particular, the authors consider the setting where the adversary can observe the states, actions, etc. from previous time - steps and adapt itself to produce stronger attacks in future steps ( e.g., by focusing more on states critical to the agent ’s performance ). The authors propose a policy smoothing method to add Gaussian noise to its observation at each time - step before passing it through the policy function. The proposed robustness certificates guarantee that the final total reward obtained by the proposed method remains above a certain threshold, even though the actions at intermediate time - stages may change under the attack.

This paper proposes a method to predict the target domain accuracy using only labeled source data and unlabeled target data. The proposed method is based on a threshold on the model ’s confidence and predicts the accuracy as the fraction of unlabelled examples for which model confidence exceeds that threshold. The method outperforms previous methods across several model architectures, types of distribution shifts ( e.g., due to synthetic corruptions, dataset reproduction, or novel subpopulations ), and datasets ( WILDS, ImageNet, BREEDS, CIFAR, and MNIST ). The paper also explores the theoretical foundations of the problem.

This paper considers the problem of partial distribution matching ( PDM ) registration, where the goal is to recover a transformation that matches one set to the other. The authors propose a method for large scale PDM problem by utilizing the partial Wasserstein - 1 ( PW ) discrepancy, which they show can be efficiently optimized. They theoretically derive the Kantorovich - Rubinstein duality for the PW discrepancy, and show its gradient can be explicitly computed. They evaluate the proposed method on practical point set registration tasks and show that the proposed PWAN is robust, scalable and performs more favorably than the state - of - the - art methods.

This paper proposes a novel method for hyperparameter optimization ( HPO ) based on Deep Kernel Gaussian Process ( DKGP ). The main idea is to use a meta - feature network to capture the similarity between hyper - parameter configurations with an end - to - end meta - Feature network that embeds the set of evaluated configurations and their respective performance. Experiments are conducted to validate the performance of DKLM in a wide range of HPO meta - datasets.

This paper proposes a new method for deep fake detection and attribution based on the fingerprinting mechanism of deep generative models. The key idea is to generate a large population of models with distinct fingerprints, which can be used to identify the source of the generated data. The proposed method is evaluated on the synthetic and real datasets and is shown to be effective in detecting deep fakes and attribution.

This paper studies post - hoc explanations for black box models that output similarity between two inputs. In particular, the authors propose two approaches to explain similarities between sentences as predicted by a state - of - the - art sentence encoder, and between patients in a healthcare utilization application. They first propose a method that provides feature attributions to explain the similarity between a pair of inputs as determined by a black box similarity learner. They then propose analogies as a new form of explanation in machine learning. The goal is to identify diverse analogous pairs of examples that share the same level of similarity as the input pair and provide insight into (latent ) factors underlying the model ’s prediction.

This paper studies the certified robustness of ensemble deep neural networks ( DNNs ) against adversarial attacks. The authors provide the sufficient and necessary conditions of robustness for ensemble ML models, together with the ensemble - before - Smoothing strategy. They also prove that an ensemble model can always achieve higher certified L2 - robustness than a single base model under mild conditions. Based on the theoretical findings, the authors propose a lightweight ensemble - enhanced DRT enhanced ensembles. Extensive experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed ensemble model.

This paper studies the expressive power of Graph Neural Networks ( GNNs ). The authors propose a new pooling technique of local neighborhoods that allows different trade - offs of computational cost and expressive power. They prove that this model can count subgraphs of size k, and thereby overcomes a known limitation of low - order GNN. They also show how to exploit sparsity to reduce the computational complexity of higher - order graph neural networks.

This paper studies the knowledge integration ( KI ) in pre - trained language models ( LMs ) from an information - theoretic point of view. The authors propose a simple probe model called Graph Convolution Simulator ( GCS ) for interpreting knowledge - enhanced LMs and expose what kind of knowledge is integrated into these models. They find that only a small amount of factual knowledge is captured in these models during integration. They also find that while K - Adapter struggles to integrate time - related knowledge, it successfully integrates knowledge of unpopular entities and relations.

This paper studies the effect of the adaptation learning rate in meta - learning with mixed linear regression. The authors provide a principled way to estimate the optimal adaptation learning rates that minimize the population risk of MAML. They also prove that compared with empirical risk minimization ( ERM ), the optimal learning rate is a smaller average distance to the task optima, consistent with previous practical findings.

This paper studies the problem of source - free domain adaptation ( SFDA ), which aims to adapt a model trained on labelled data in a source domain to unlabelled data in the target domain without access to the source - domain data during adaptation. Existing methods for SFDA leverage entropy - minimization techniques which : ( i ) apply only to classification ; ( ii ) destroy model calibration ; and ( iii ) rely on the source model achieving a good level of feature - space class - separation. The authors propose a bottom - up training scheme for FR which boosts performance by preserving learnt structure in the later layers of a network. The proposed method outperforms existing SFDA methods on real and synthetic data in terms of accuracy and calibration.

This paper studies the problem of distributed adversarial robustness in federated learning ( FL ). The authors propose a novel learning setting that propagates robustness from high - resource users that can afford AT, to those low -resource users that cannot afford it, and propose a simple yet effective propagation approach that transfers robustness through carefully designed batch - normalization statistics. Extensive experiments are conducted to demonstrate the rationality and effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper considers the problem of modeling network games, where a player ’s payoff depends not only on their actions but also on those of their neighbors. The authors propose a transformer - like architecture which correctly accounts for the symmetries of the problem and learns a mapping from the equilibrium actions to the network structure of the game without explicit knowledge of the utility function. They test their method on three different types of network games using both synthetic and real - world data, and demonstrate its effectiveness.

This paper proposes a method for relation prediction in heterogeneous graphs. The main contribution of the paper is a novel relation prediction framework that predicts relations between each node pair by checking whether the subgraphs containing the pair are similar to other sub - graphs containing the considered relation. Each graph pattern explicitly represents a specific logical rule, which contributes to an inductive bias that facilitates generalization to unseen relation types and leads to more explainable predictive models. The proposed method outperforms existing models in terms of heterogeneous graph based recommendation as well as knowledge graph completion.

This paper studies the problem of few - shot learning in histology images, which is of high clinical value since well - labeled datasets and rare abnormal samples are expensive to collect. To enable label - efficient learning and better generalizability, this paper proposes to incorporate contrastive learning ( CL ) with latent augmentation ( LA ) to build a few -shot system. The CL learns useful representations without manual labels, while the latent augmentations transfer semantic variations of the base dataset in an unsupervised way. The experiments show that the CL over supervised learning is superior in terms of generalization for such data and provide empirical understanding for this observation.

This paper studies the problem of learning continuous - time hidden state neural networks ( RNNs ) with long - term dependencies in irregularly sampled time series. The authors show that the underlying reason for this issue is the vanishing or exploding of the gradient during training, which is expressed by the ordinary differential equation ( ODE ) representation of the hidden state, regardless of the ODE solver ’s choice. They then propose a solution by equipping arbitrary continuous time networks with a memory compartment separated from its time - continuous state. This way, they encode a continuous time dynamical flow within the RNN, allowing it to respond to inputs arriving at arbitrary time - lags while ensuring a constant error propagation through the memory path.

This paper studies the binarization of BERT, which is one of the powerful compression approaches to reduce the computation and memory consumption by utilizing 1 - bit parameters and bitwise operations. The authors propose BiBERT, an accurate fully binarized BERT model to eliminate the performance bottlenecks. Extensive experiments show that the proposed method yields impressive 56.3× and 31.2× saving on FLOPs and model size.

This paper proposes a novel approach of supervising self - attention for multi - person keypoint detection and instance association. Specifically, the authors propose to use instance masks to supervise self - attentions to be instance - aware, and assign the detected keypoints to their instances. The experiments on the COCO multi - Person Keypoint detection challenge and instance segmentation task demonstrate the effectiveness and simplicity of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a method to train an agent to maximize the expected quadratic utility function, which is the Pareto efficient policy. The proposed method is based on gradient estimation of the variance term of the mean - variance trade - off. The method is evaluated on a number of RL tasks, including reinforcement learning, decision making, and decision making under uncertainty.

This paper studies the problem of test - time domain adaptation for an autoencoder system whose channel is generatively - modeled using a mixture density network ( MDN ). The authors propose a fast and sample - efficient method for adapting the channel model without modifying the encoder and decoder neural networks, and adapting only the MDN channel model model. The method utilizes feature transformations at the decoder to compensate for changes in the channel distribution, and effectively present to the decoders samples close to the source distribution. Experimental evaluation on simulated datasets and real mmWave wireless channels demonstrate that the proposed method can adapt the channel using very limited number of samples, and improve or maintain the error rate of the auto - encoder.

This paper studies the problem of abductive natural language inference, where the task is to infer the most plausible explanation between the cause and the event given two observations. The authors argue that it is unnecessary to distinguish the reasoning abilities among correct hypotheses and similarly, all wrong hypotheses contribute the same when explaining the reasons of the observations. Therefore, they propose to group the hypotheses and design a structural loss called Joint Softmax Focal Loss ( JSL ). The experimental results show that the proposed method achieves the highest performance on the RoBERTa - Large pretrained model, with joint softmax focal loss.

This paper proposes a method to detect out - of - distribution ( OOD ) data. The key idea is to use a standard classifier with a certified OOD detector to detect OOD data. This is an interesting idea, but the paper is not very well written. The paper is hard to follow, and the experiments are not convincing enough.

This paper studies the generalized transferable attack ( GTA ) problem where the attacker has a set of surrogate models trained on different datasets ( with different label sets and image sizes ) and none of them is equal to the dataset used by the victim model. The paper proposes a novel method called Image Classification Eraser ( ICE ) to erase classification information for any encountered images from arbitrary dataset. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed ICE on the GTA problem.

This paper studies the problem of discriminative pre - trained language models ( PrLMs ), where the model is trained to predict original texts from intentionally corrupted ones. The authors propose two methods to address the issue of false negative predictions. The first method is to train the model on the wrong data, which leads to the model to suffer from the false negative issue where training is carried out on wrong data and leads to less efficiency and less robustness in the resulting PrLM models. The second method is a modification of the standard pre - training method, which is based on the idea that the model should be able to discriminate between positive and negative samples. Experiments on GLUE and SQuAD benchmarks show the effectiveness of the proposed methods.

This paper proposes a novel open - world semi - supervised learning setting where novel classes may appear in the unlabeled test data. The authors propose ORCA, an end - to - end approach that assigns instances to previously seen classes or novel classes by grouping similar instances without assuming any prior knowledge. Extensive experiments on image classification datasets and a single - cell dataset demonstrate that ORCA consistently outperforms alternative baselines.

This paper proposes SLIM - QN, a light stochastic quasi - Newton optimizer for training large - scale deep neural networks ( DNNs ). It addresses two key barriers in existing second - order methods : 1 ) the high computational cost of obtaining the Hessian matrix and its inverse in every iteration ( e.g. KFAC ) and 2 ) convergence instability due to stochastically training ( L - BFGS ). To tackle the first challenge, it uses the BFGS update rule that directly approximates the Hessians inverse using past parameters and gradients, without explicitly constructing the Hessia matrix and then computing its inverse. To achieve stable convergence, it introduces momentum in Hessian updates together with an adaptive damping mechanism. The authors evaluate its performance on various datasets and network architectures.

Graph Neural Networks ( GNNs ) have emerged as highly successful tools for graph - related tasks. However, real - world problems involve very large graphs, and the compute resources needed to fit GNN to those problems grow rapidly. This paper proposes a systematic method called Locality - Sensitive Pruning ( LSP ) for graph pruning based on local graph properties. Extensive experiments are conducted to demonstrate the superiority of LSP over other pruning strategies.

This paper studies the problem of data augmentation for contrastive self - supervised learning. The authors propose a simple adversarial augmentation method that can modify training data to be hard positives / negatives without distorting the key information about their original identities. The proposed method is based on variational auto - encoder reconstruction ( VAE ) reconstruction ( G(x ) plus the residual R(x) = x ), where the residual retains most of the information about the original data. The method is evaluated on multiple benchmark datasets and is shown to improve the efficiency and generalization performance of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new method to detect distributional shifts in machine learning models. The proposed method is based on the observation that the performance of a model can be affected by the distribution of the data used to train the model. The authors propose to detect the distributional shift by monitoring the difference between the training distribution and the test distribution. The method is evaluated on both simulated and real - world datasets.

This paper proposes to combine neural implicit representations for appearance modeling with neural ordinary differential equations ( ODEs ) in order to obtain interpretable physical models directly from visual observations. The proposed model is able to identify physical parameters from only a single video. The use of neural implicit representation enables the processing of high - resolution videos and the synthesis of photo - realistic imagery.   The proposed method can precisely recover the metric length of pendulum from a monocular video ( relative error to true length is less than 2.5 % ).

This paper considers the context - dependent reinforcement learning ( RL ) setting, which is characterized by an unknown finite number of not - observable contexts, abrupt context changes occurring during an episode, and Markovian context evolution. The authors tackle this challenging setting using a Bayesian approach and variational inference. They adapt a Hierarchical Dirichlet Process ( HDP ) prior for model learning and derive a context distillation procedure, which identifies and removes spurious contexts in an unsupervised fashion. They then find the representation of the optimal policy enabling efficient policy learning using off - the - shelf RL algorithms.

This paper presents a framework to pretrain knowledge - based multilingual language models ( KMLMs ). The authors generate a large amount of code - switched synthetic sentences and reasoning - based training data using the Wikidata knowledge graphs. They design pretraining tasks to facilitate knowledge learning, which allows the language models to not only memorize the factual knowledge but also learn useful logical patterns. They demonstrate significant performance improvements on a wide range of knowledge - intensive cross - lingual NLP tasks, including named entity recognition, factual knowledge retrieval, and a number of other tasks.

This paper studies the problem of learning to help other agents achieve their goals without knowing what their goals are. The authors propose to learn the other agents “ preferences ” by increasing the number of states that the other agent can reach in its future. They evaluate their approach on three different multi - agent environments where the success depends on the altruistic agent ’s behaviour. They show that their unsupervised agents can perform comparably to agents explicitly trained to work cooperatively, in some cases even outperforming them.

This paper studies the phenomenon of double descent in neural networks. The main contribution of this paper is to study the generalization behavior of neural networks under or over parametrized regimes. The authors first derive the upper bound of the Hessian of a neural network in the regime of underparameterization and then derive the lower bound of its lower bound. The upper bound bears an intimate connection with the spectrum of Hessian at the optimum, and importantly, exhibit a double descent behaviour at the interpolation threshold. The lower bound is derived by leveraging influence functions in order to derive suitable expressions of the population loss and its upper bound.

Graph convolutional networks ( GCNs ) and their variants have achieved great success in dealing with graph - structured data. However, it is well known that deep GCNs suffer from the over - smoothing problem, where node representations tend to be indistinguishable as more layers are stacked up. This work fills this gap by exploiting the Graph Neural Tangent Kernel ( GNTK ), which governs the optimization trajectory under gradient descent for wide GCNs. Theoretical insights on the asymptotic behaviors of G NTK in the large depth are provided, which enables the authors to reveal the dropping trainability of wide and deep GCN at an exponential rate in the optimization process. The authors also extend their theoretical framework to analyze residual connection - based techniques, which are found to be only able to mildly mitigate the exponential decay of trainability.

This paper studies the problem of estimating the second derivative of the cardiac pulse waveform, which can be used as an indicator of blood pressure and arterial disease. In particular, the authors propose to optimize the model for the second - order dynamics of the waveform in order to better estimate the first - order properties of the pulse. The authors show that their model is better able to estimate this second derivative when explicitly optimized for in the loss function. They also show that adding second - derivative inputs also improves the performance of the model.

This paper proposes to use symbolic mapping to help agents learn a compositional and symmetric language in complex settings like dialog games. The authors propose a novel architecture called symbolic mapping as a basic component of the communication system of agent. They show that symbolic mapping learned in simple referential games can notably promote language learning in difficult tasks. Further, the authors explore vocabulary expansion, and show that with the help of symbolic mapping, agents can easily learn to use new symbols when the environment becomes more complex.

This paper proposes a hierarchical modular approach to learn agents that navigate and manipulate objects in a divide - and - conquer manner for the diverse nature of the entailing tasks. Specifically, the policy operates at three levels of hierarchy. The first is to infer a sequence of subgoals to be executed based on language instructions by high - level policy composition controller ( PCC ). The second is to control the agent ’s navigation by a master policy by alternating between navigation policy and various independent interaction policies. Finally, the third is to manipulate the corresponding object masks using the appropriate interaction policy. The proposed method is evaluated on the task of domestic chores and achieves the state - of - the - art performance on the challenging ALFRED benchmark.

This paper proposes a method for training models that are independent of the relationship between the label and the nuisance variable. The proposed method is called Nuisance - randomized distilled distillation ( NURD ). The authors define a set of distributions that differ only in the nuisance - label relationship, and then introduce a new distribution called nuisance - independent distribution where the nuisance and the label are independent. They show that under this distribution, the representations in this set always perform better than those in the other distributions. They also show that the representation that is most informative of the label under the independent distribution is the one that achieves the highest performance within the set on every distribution.

This paper proposes a method to train a model to predict the pairing between images and text captions for contrastive learning. The method is based on the observation that natural language is a broader and richer source of supervision that provides finer descriptions to visual concepts than supervised " gold " labels. The authors propose to use online entropic optimal transport to find a soft image - text match as labels to train the model. The proposed method achieves strong performance with only 3 M image text pairs compared to the 400 M pairs required for CLIP training.

This paper presents a simple and generic framework for object detection. It casts object detection as a language modeling task conditioned on the observed pixel inputs. Object descriptions ( e.g. bounding boxes and class labels ) are expressed as sequences of discrete tokens, and a neural net is trained to perceive the image and generate the desired sequence. The proposed method achieves competitive results on the challenging COCO dataset, compared to highly specialized and well optimized detection algorithms.

This paper proposes a method for distilling visual reinforcement learning ( RL ) policies into interpretable symbolic policies. The proposed method is based on distillation of the CNN policy network into a symbolic policy composed from geometric and numerical symbols and operators. The symbolic policy can be treated as discrete and abstracted representations of the policy network, but are found to be more interpretable, robust and transferable than the original CNN policy. Experiments are conducted on four environments to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new method for image - to - image translation with the goal of disentangling the coarse - level object arrangements ( posture ) and the fine - grained level styling ( identity ) of the generated image from two exemplar sources. The authors propose a joint - training scheme with self - supervision methods for the GANInversion encoder and the generator. The VQSN module automatically learns to encode the shaping and composition information from the commonly shared objects inside the training - set images. Experiments conducted on various datasets show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a multi - layer perceptron ( MLP ) architecture to extract information from speech signals. The model splits feature channels into non - overlapped chunks and processes each chunk individually. These chunks are then merged together and further processed to consolidate the output. The proposed model is evaluated on two tasks : keyword spotting and speech enhancement. The results indicate that more complex models, such as transformers, are not necessary for speech processing tasks.

This paper studies the generalization error bound of transfer learning algorithms for binary classification problems. The authors provide a novel lower bound on the generalisation error that can be achieved by any transfer learning algorithm ( regardless of its computational complexity ). The lower bound is based on a natural notion of distance that is easily computed on real world data sets and requires minimal assumptions that enables it application to a broad range of problems. Experiments are conducted on real image classification and action recognition data sets to verify the theoretical findings.

This paper proposes a probabilistic shape completion method for large - scale 3D scenes. The proposed method learns the multi - modal distribution and transform the formulation to process the continuous geometry. The local continuous shape is incrementally generated as a sparse voxel embedding, which contains the latent code for each occupied cell. Experiments show that the proposed method successfully generates diverse plausible scenes faithful to the input.

This paper proposes to use temporal priors as a non - Markovian generalization of behavioral priors for guiding exploration in reinforcement learning. The authors propose to use a probabilistic mixture of policy and temporal prior to accelerate off - policy reinforcement learning in unseen downstream tasks. They provide empirical evidence that their approach improves upon strong baselines in long - horizon continuous control tasks under sparse reward settings.

This paper proposes a Graph - Network - based Scheduler ( GNS ) to learn a scheduling mechanism for stochastic optimization in training deep neural networks. By constructing a directed graph for the underlying neural network of the target problem, GNS encodes current dynamics with a graph message passing network and trains an agent to control the learning rate accordingly via reinforcement learning. The proposed scheduler can capture the intermediate layer information while being able to generalize to problems of varying scales. Besides, an efficient reward collection procedure is leveraged to speed up training.

This paper proposes a method for deep object - centric learning from a point cloud. The main idea is to factorize a 3D point cloud into a spatial mixture model where each component corresponds to one object. The authors also introduce an object - specification scheme that describes each object ’s location relative to its local voxel grid cell. The proposed method is evaluated on the task of unsupervised scene decomposition.

This paper studies the problem of grounding high - level tasks, expressed in natural language, to a chosen set of actionable steps ( i.e. “ open fridge ” ). The authors propose a procedure that conditions on existing demonstrations and semantically translates the plans to admissible actions. Their evaluation in the recent VirtualHome environment shows that the resulting method substantially improves executability over the baseline.

This paper proposes a geometrical interpretation of the Variational Autoencoders ( VAEs ) framework. The authors show that VAEs naturally unveil a Riemannian structure of the learned latent space. They then propose a new way to generate samples consisting in sampling from the uniform distribution deriving intrinsically from the Riemanian manifold learned by a VAE. They validate the method on a complex neuroimaging dataset combining both high dimensional data and low sample sizes.

This paper proposes to replace redundant heads in transformers with a mixture of Gaussian keys at each head. These mixtures of keys follow a Gaussian mixture model and allow each attention head to focus on different parts of the input sequence efficiently. Compared to its conventional transformer counterpart, Transformer - MGK accelerates training and inference, has fewer parameters, and requires less FLOPs to compute while achieving comparable or better accuracy across tasks.

This paper proposes a new two - dimensional continuous environment for spatial navigation. The authors propose a new model of environment dynamics to fuse image and action related signals, allowing reconstruction of the action relating the two successive images, as well as prediction of the new image from its current value and the action. The proposed model is compared to off - the - shelf LSTM networks on identical tasks and consistently shows better performance while also offering more interpretable internal dynamics and higher - quality representations.

This paper studies the problem of feature learning in neural networks. The authors consider learning problems motivated by practical data, where the labels are determined by a set of class relevant patterns and the inputs are generated from these along with some background patterns. They prove that neural networks trained by gradient descent can succeed on these problems. The success relies on the emergence and improvement of effective features, which are learned among exponentially many candidates efficiently by exploiting the data ( in particular, the structure of the input distribution ).

This paper studies the robustness of machine learning models to adversarial examples generated by test - time adversaries. The authors provide a methodology to analyze the robusts of fixed feature extractors, which in turn provides bounds on the robustnesses of any classifier trained on top of it. The tightness of these bounds relies on the effectiveness of the method used to find collisions between pairs of perturbed examples at deeper layers. The paper also identifies the layers of robustly trained models that contribute the most to a lack of robustness, as well as compare the same layer across different training methods.

This paper proposes a value - based reinforcement learning method for offline reinforcement learning. The main idea is to learn the V - function instead of the Q - function to naturally keep the learning procedure within the offline dataset. The paper proposes Expectile V - Learning ( EVL ), which smoothly interpolates between the optimal value learning and behavior cloning to enhance learned V - values and accelerate convergence. Theoretical analysis for the convergence properties of the proposed VEM method is provided.

This paper proposes a novel adversarial training framework that learns to reweight the loss associated with individual training samples based on a notion of class - conditioned margin, with the goal of improving robust generalization. The proposed method is inspired by MAML - based approaches and is formulated as a bilevel optimization problem, where the upper - level task corresponds to learning a robust classifier, and the lower - level is to learn a parametric function that maps from a sample ’s multi - class margin to an importance weight. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed approach improves both clean and robust accuracy.

This paper proposes a method for equivariant graph neural networks ( SEGNNs ) based on steerable graph neural network ( E(3 ) Equivariant Graph Neural Networks ). The main contribution of this paper is the definition of steerable node attributes ( steerable MLPs ), which is a new class of activation functions for general use with steerable feature fields. The proposed method is evaluated on several tasks in computational physics and chemistry and provide extensive ablation studies.

This paper proposes a new differentiable physics model for composite materials such as cloths, where it dives into the granularity of yarns and model individual yarn physics and yarn - to - yarn interactions with gradient - based learning. To this end, the authors propose several differentiable forces, whose counterparts in empirical physics are ubiquitous in various physical systems, are applied to cloths. The authors demonstrate their model ’s explicability in learning meaningful physical parameters, versatility in incorporating complex physical structures and heterogeneous materials, data - efficiency in learning, and high - fidelity in capturing subtle dynamics.

This paper studies the problem of transfer learning in reinforcement learning. The authors propose a framework that enables an agent to autonomously determine whether a new task with possibly many desirable goals can be immediately solved using its existing abilities, or whether a task - specific skill should be learned. In the latter case, the proposed algorithm also enables the agent to learn the new task faster by generating an estimate of the optimal policy.   The authors provide two main theoretical results : ( 1 ) the performance of the transferred policy on new task, and ( 2 ) the necessary and sufficient number of tasks that need to be learned throughout an agent ’s lifetime to generalise over a distribution. They verify their approach in a series of experiments, where they perform transfer learning both after learning a set of base tasks and after learning an arbitrary set of tasks.

This paper studies the multivariate time series classification ( MTSC ) problem and proposes a distributed solution to solve it. The main contribution of this paper is to propose a solution that scales well with the number of time series nodes and channels. The proposed method is based on the idea of distributed feature selection ( DSP ). The authors propose three versions of the proposed method, which are evaluated on three datasets.   The main contributions of the paper are the following :   1. A new multi - channel DSP method is proposed to reduce the input size of the model, which is fast both during training and inference. 2. An inference speedup of up to 9x to 65x is achieved compared to the previous state - of - the - art method ( ROCKET ). 3. A scalability analysis is provided to evaluate the effectiveness of the method.

This paper proposes to train a discriminator to detect replaced tokens generated by auxiliary masked language models ( MLMs ). The main idea is to train multiple MLMs of different sizes to provide training signals at various levels of difficulty. The discriminator is trained with mixture weights over the auxiliary MLMs ’ outputs to maximize the discriminator loss. For better pretraining efficiency, the authors propose a way to assemble multiple auxiliary models into one unified auxiliary model.

This paper studies the problem of extracting relational knowledge from large pre - trained language models by a clozestyle sentence serving as a query. The authors propose to train a language model on the standard fill - mask task using a small training dataset of existing facts from a knowledge graph. They also analyze the transfer learning capabilities of this adapted language model by training on a restricted set of relations to show that even fewer training relations are needed to achieve high knowledge extraction quality.

This paper studies the problem of learning knowledge base embeddings for multi - relation relations in the context of knowledge graph learning. The authors propose to learn the embedding of the relation properties in different geometric spaces and apply manifold alignment to align the shared entities. The proposed approach is evaluated on the out - of - taxonomy entity typing task, where the authors aim to predict the types of the entities from the knowledge graph. Experimental results on two datasets based on YAGO3 demonstrate that the approach has significantly good performances.

This paper proposes a one - shot learning framework for link prediction in temporal knowledge graphs. The proposed method employs a self - attention mechanism to effectively encode temporal interactions between entities, and a network to compute a similarity score between a given query and a ( one - shots ) example. The experiments show that the proposed algorithm outperforms the baselines for two well - studied benchmarks while achieving significantly better performance for sparse relations.

This paper proposes a method for learning reasoning tasks. The main idea is to represent a solver for each task as a neural module that calls existing modules ( solvers for simpler tasks ) in a functional program - like manner. The lower modules are a black box to the calling module and communicate only via a query and an output. A module for a new task learns to query existing modules and composes their outputs in order to produce its own output. The authors test their model in learning a set of visual reasoning tasks, and demonstrate improved performances in all tasks by learning progressively.

This paper proposes a method to improve the efficiency of deep convolutional neural networks ( CNNs ) with bottlenecks. The key idea is to use the identity connection ( e.g., residual connection ) between the input and output channels to select the most important channels in each layer of the network. Experiments are conducted on three different CNNs with different architectures. The results show that the proposed method improves the parameter efficiency of the CNNs.

This paper considers the problem of learning a binary classifier only from positive data and unlabeled data ( PU learning ). The authors propose a method to partially identify the classifier. The proposed algorithm learns a scoring function that preserves the order induced by the class posterior under mild assumptions, which can be used as a classifier by setting an appropriate threshold. The experiments show that the method outperforms previous methods for PU learning on various real - world datasets.

This paper proposes to use the cosine similarity between gradients of tasks as an adaptive weight to detect when an auxiliary loss is helpful to the main loss. The authors show that their approach is guaranteed to converge to critical points of the main task and demonstrate the practical usefulness of the proposed algorithm in a few domains : multi - task supervised learning on subsets of ImageNet, reinforcement learning on gridworld, and reinforcement learning   on Atari games.   The main contribution of this paper is to propose a new approach to deal with the statistical inefficiency of neural networks.

This paper studies the geometry of adversarial examples in the context of machine learning. The authors propose a geometric framework to analyze the high - dimensional geometry of the adversarial geometry of data manifolds. In particular, the authors highlight the importance of codimension for the manifold reconstruction literature. They prove a trade - off between robustness under different norms, and show that adversarial training in balls around the data is sample inefficient, and that robustness in ball - based training is robust.

This paper proposes a new representation learning method for discrete time series data. The authors propose to learn discrete representations of time series that are smooth and interpretable embeddings with superior clustering performance. The proposed method is a gradient - based version of the traditional self - organizing map algorithm that is more performant than the original. The method is evaluated on static ( Fashion - MNIST ) time series, a chaotic Lorenz attractor system with two macro states, a challenging real world medical time series application on the eICU data set, as well as on the real world data set.

This paper studies the properties of multidimensional probability distributions in the context of latent space prior distributions of implicit generative models. The authors show that the distribution mismatch can be eliminated completely by a proper choice of the latent probability distribution or by using non - linear interpolations. They prove that there is a trade - off between the interpolation being linear and the latent distribution having even the most basic properties required for stable training, such as finite mean.

This paper proposes to use hyperbolic embedding space to learn attention mechanisms for neural networks. The authors propose to learn the parameters of shallow neural networks in hyper - bolic space, which is a space where the number of objects grows exponentially for any semantic distance from the query. They show that this space is more efficient than Euclidean space and can encode objects without having any interference. The method is evaluated on neural machine translation on WMT’14 ( English to German ), learning on graphs ( synthetic and real - world graph tasks ) and visual question answering ( CLEVR ) tasks while keeping the neural representations compact.

This paper presents an empirical security analysis of deep neural network ( DNN ) network fingerprinting attacks that exploit cache side - channel attacks. The authors define the threat model for these attacks : the adversary does not need the ability to query the victim model but instead, she runs a co - located process on the host machine where the victim ’s deep learning ( DL ) system is running and passively monitors the accesses of the target functions in the shared framework.   The authors introduce DeepRecon, an attack that reconstructs the architecture of the victim network using the internal information extracted via Flush+Reload, a cache side channel technique. They also demonstrate that an attacker can build a meta - model that accurately fingerprints the architecture and family of the pretrained model in a transfer learning setting. Finally, the authors propose and evaluate new framework - level defense techniques that obfuscate the attacker's observations.

This paper presents a hierarchical network model for video sequence prediction. The model is inspired by the feedforward, feedback and lateral recurrent circuits in the mammalian hierarchical visual system. It assumes that spatiotemporal memories are encoded in the recurrent connections within each level and between different levels of the hierarchy. The network learns relationships among movement patterns, yielding state - of - the - art performance in long range video sequence predictions in benchmark datasets.

This paper proposes a method to compute continuous embeddings for kmers from raw RNA -seq data, in a reference - free fashion. The model captures information of both DNA sequence similarity as well as DNA sequence abundance in the embedding latent space. The latent space is also used to detect genomic abnormalities such as translocations and patient - specific mutations, making this representation space both useful for visualization and analysis.

This paper proposes a novel approach to model compression termed “ Architecture Compression ”. The proposed method first encodes the network and then performs gradient descent in continuous space to optimize a compression objective function that maximizes accuracy and minimizes parameter count. The final continuous feature is then mapped to a discrete architecture using the decoder. Experiments are conducted on visual recognition tasks such as CIFAR-10/100, FMNIST and SVHN and achieve a greater than 20x compression.

This paper proposes a new framework for value function learning that combines local model - based control, value function approximation, and exploration. The main idea is to use trajectory optimization to accelerate and stabilize the learning of the value function, and to reduce the planning horizon and allow for better policies beyond local solutions. Experiments are conducted on humanoid locomotion and dexterous in - hand manipulation tasks.

This paper proposes a zero - shot and dual machine translation ( ZMT ) system for low - resource languages. The ZMT system is based on reinforcement learning and is trained on a UN corpus. The authors evaluate the performance of the proposed system on two tasks : zero shot translation on SpanishFrench ( both directions ) and zero shot / dual translation on English - French and English - Spanish. The results show that the proposed method outperforms the LSTM - based unsupervised NMT system on the zero shot task, while on the other tasks it outperforms both the Transformers - based and the standard NMT systems.

This paper proposes a generative adversarial generator ( IRGAN ) based on the framework for Information - Retrieval ( IR ). The authors claim that optimizing their minimax loss function will result in a generator which can learn the correct conditional probability distribution p(d|q ) over the documents ( d, q ) given the query ( q ). However, their setup and baseline term steer the model away from an exact adversarial formulation, and this work attempts to point out certain inaccuracies in their formulation. The proposed method is based on a co - training setup, where two models are trained in a co-operative rather than an adversarial fashion.

This paper proposes a new approach for approximate inference of variational auto - encoders ( VAEs ). The authors propose to explicitly model sparsity in the latent space of a VAE with a Spike and Slab prior distribution. They derive the evidence lower bound using a discrete mixture recognition function thereby making approximate posterior inference as computational efficient as in the standard VAE case. They show that these sparse representations are advantageous over standard VAEs representations on two benchmark classification tasks ( MNIST and Fashion - MNIST ).

This paper proposes a feature matching - based approach to train generative models. The proposed approach, Generative Feature Matching Networks ( GMN ), leverages pretrained neural networks such as autoencoders and ConvNet classifiers to perform feature extraction. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach can achieve state - of - the - art results for challenging benchmarks such as CIFAR10 and STL10.

Graph Neural Networks ( GNNs ) are an effective framework for representation learning of graphs. Many GNN variants have been proposed and have achieved state - of - the - art results on both node and graph classification tasks. However, there is limited understanding of their representational properties and limitations. This paper presents a theoretical framework for analyzing the expressive power of GNN to capture different graph structures. The results characterize the discriminative power of popular GNN variant, such as Graph Convolutional Networks and GraphSAGE, and show that they can not learn to distinguish certain simple graphs structures.

This paper proposes a framework for interpretable continual learning ( ICL ) based on variational continual learning. The main idea is to use saliency maps to provide explanations of performed tasks and propose a new metric to assess their quality. Experiments show that ICL achieves state - of - the - art results in terms of overall continual learning performance as measured by average classification accuracy and qualitatively and quantitatively using its explanations.

This paper proposes a new evaluation framework for adversarial attacks on neural sequence - to - sequence ( seq2seq ) models taking meaning preservation into account. The authors propose new constraints for attacks on word - based machine translation ( MT ) systems and show, via human and automatic evaluation, that they produce more semantically similar adversarial inputs. They also show that performing adversarial training with the proposed framework is beneficial to the model in terms of adversarial robustness.

This paper proposes a new method for reinforcement learning that combines the policies using original rewards and inverse ( negative ) rewards. The proposed method is based on deep Q - learning, double - Q - Learning, and on - policy actor - critic. The experiments for some games in OpenAI gym show that the hybrid polices obtain rewards up to 63.8, 97.8 % and 54.7 % more than the original algorithms. The improved polices are more stable than original policies as well.

This paper presents a method for learning hierarchical object representation and dynamics models from unlabeled videos. The key idea is to learn a hierarchical, disentangled object representation, and a dynamics model for object parts and their hierarchical structure by watching how they move in the video. Experiments on multiple real and synthetic datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a novel inference method, Deep Determinantal generative classifier ( DDGC ), which can obtain a more robust decision boundary under any softmax neural classifier pre - trained on noisy datasets. The main idea is to use the minimum covariance determinant estimator to estimate the parameters of the classifier using the latent feature space of the discriminative deep model. The proposed method significantly improves the classification accuracy, with neither re - training of the deep model nor changing its architectures.

This paper presents a method for discovering subgoals in Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning ( HRL ) using incremental unsupervised learning ( IRL ). The method is based on an intrinsic motivation learning mechanism, which learns subgoal and skills together, based on the most recent experiences in the environment. Experiments are conducted on the ATARI 2600 game with sparse delayed feedback and a variant of the rooms environment. Results show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines.

This paper proposes a neural framework to solve the Circuit Satisfiability problem. The framework is built upon two fundamental contributions : a rich embedding architecture that encodes the problem structure and an end - to - end differentiable training procedure that mimics Reinforcement Learning. The experimental results show the superior out - of - sample generalization performance of the proposed framework compared to the recently developed NeuroSAT method.

This paper proposes a new deep reinforcement learning ( RL ) algorithm based on the simple cross - entropy method ( CEM ). CEM - RL is a combination of two existing RL algorithms : DDPG and Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient. The authors evaluate the proposed method on a set of benchmarks classically used in deep RL. The proposed method achieves a satisfactory trade - off between performance and sample efficiency.

This paper proposes an interpretable multi - variable recurrent neural network ( IMV - LSTM ) that is capable of providing accurate forecasting as well as both temporal and variable level importance interpretation. The proposed model is equipped with hidden state matrix and update process, so as to learn variableswise hidden states. Extensive experiments using real datasets demonstrate the prediction performance and interpretability of the proposed model in comparison to a variety of baselines.

This paper proposes a data augmentation method for adversarial defense. The proposed method is based on feature smoothing, which is an interpolation of features from a pair of samples, with the new label remaining the same as the dominant data point. The paper also proposes a unified framework to understand the connections and differences among different efficient methods by analyzing the biases and variances of various efficient methods. The experiments on MNIST and CIFAR10 datasets explore different combinations of known regularization and data augmentation methods and show that the proposed methods are stable when the assumptions no longer hold.

This paper proposes a theoretical framework for deep convolutional neural networks with ReLU nonlinearity. The framework bridges data distribution with gradient descent rules, favors disentangled representations and is compatible with common regularization techniques such as Batch Norm. The proposed framework is built upon teacher - student setting, by projecting the student ’s forward / backward pass onto the teacher’s computational graph. This framework could help facilitate theoretical analysis of many practical issues in deep networks.

This paper proposes a modular architecture of neural networks with a Behavioral Module ( BM ) and corresponding end - to - end training strategy to learn behaviors and preferences representation. The proposed method is inspired by PFC functionality and connectivity, as well as human behavior formation process. Experiments on video games playing show that the proposed method allows separation of main task ’s objectives and behaviors between different BMs.

This paper proposes a differentiable formulation for the neuromodulation of plasticity, which is the ability of neurons to self - modulate their connections during training. This formulation is based on the well - known Hebbian plasticity of neurons. The paper proposes to use this formulation to train neural networks using gradient descent. Experiments show that the proposed formulation improves the performance of neural networks on both reinforcement learning and supervised learning tasks.

This paper proposes a novel quantization method for deep neural network training. The proposed method is based on re - training the full precision model, followed by directly optimizing the corresponding binary model. The authors also propose a new loss function to regularize the weights, resulting in reduced quantization error. Experiments are conducted on CIFAR dataset using binary quantization and WikiText-2 dataset using 2 bit quantization.

This paper presents a method for the open - ended recombination of style and content from one image to another. The method is based on a VAE - style encoder - content encoder architecture with an auxiliary loss, leakage filtering, to ensure that no style information remains in the content representation when the style representation is used for reconstruction and vice versa. The proposed method achieves state - of - the - art performance on few - shot learning tasks.

This paper proposes a new method to drastically speed up deep reinforcement learning ( deep RL ) training for problems that have the property of state - action permissibility ( SAP ). The first type of SAP is defined after an action at is performed in a state and the agent reaches the new state st+1. The second type says that even without performing the action at in state st, the agent can already decide whether at is permissible or not in st. The proposed method incorporates the proposed SAP property into two state - of - the - art deep RL algorithms to guide their state -action exploration.

This paper studies the behavior of weight - tied multilayer vanilla autoencoders under the assumption of random weights. The authors provide quantitative answers and insights to three questions that were not yet fully understood in the literature. They also provide insights on pitfalls in training initialization practice, and demonstrate experimentally that it is possible to train a deep autoencoder with the tanh activation and a depth as large as 200 layers, without resorting to layer - wise pre - training or batch normalization.

This paper studies the problem of adversarial image construction in the black box setting, where the goal is to find an imperceptibly modified image that is misclassified by a target model. The authors propose a new algorithm based on the discrete cosine transform ( DCT ) and randomly pick a low frequency component of the DCT and either add or subtract it to the target image. The proposed method can be used for both targeted and untargeted attacks, resulting in previously unprecedented query efficiency in both settings.

This paper proposes a method to learn a set of sub - states of well - connected regions of a grid world. The key idea is to use an option discovery approach to discover “ sub - goal sub - goals ”, which are points from which a densely connected set of states are easily accessible. The paper also proposes a new model called Successor options that leverages the existing options framework to achieve the same. Experiments are conducted on a collection of grid worlds and on complex high dimensional environments like Deepmind - Lab.

This paper studies the problem of domain division which aims to segment instances drawn from different probabilistic distributions. The authors propose a domain division algorithm to split the testing instances into known, unknown and uncertain domains, and then conduct recognition tasks in each domain. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves the state - of - the - art performance on OSL and G - ZSL benchmarks.

This paper proposes a neural network architecture for classification and regression. The architecture is based on polar prototypes, which are points on the hypersphere of the output space of the neural network. For classification, each class is described by a single polar prototype and they are a priori distributed with maximal separation and equal shares. For regression, training can be performed as a polar interpolation between two prototypes, arriving at a regression with higher - dimensional outputs, while only requiring a minimal amount of output dimensions. While the structure is simple, the performance is on par or better than standard network methods.

This paper proposes an RL algorithm based on Maximum Causal Entropy IRL ( MAEIRL ) to infer both side effects that should be avoided as well as preferences for how the environment should be organized. The main idea is that when a robot is deployed in an environment that humans act in, the state of the environment is already optimized for what humans want, and we can use this implicit preference information from the initial state to fill in the blanks. The authors evaluate the idea in a suite of proof - of - concept environments designed to show its properties.

This paper proposes a method for learning the dependency structure between latent variables in deep latent variable models. The proposed method combines the complementary strengths of deep generative models and probabilistic graphical models. Inference is formulated via a sampling procedure that produces expectations over latent variable structures and incorporates top - down and bottom - up reasoning over latent variables values. Extensive experiments on MNIST, Omniglot, and CIFAR-10 show improvements in terms of the expressiveness of the learned model.

This paper studies the problem of generating gradients for a dynamical neural network ( DNN ), which is a neural network consisting of a set of neurons that interact over time continuously. The authors present a learning process, its rigorous mathematical analysis, and numerical results on several dictionary learning problems. They show that by combining ideas of top - down feedback and contrastive learning, a DNN for solving the $ \mathbb{R}^d$-minimizing dictionary learning problem can be constructed, and the true gradients are provably obtained.

This paper proposes a novel network for lane detection based on encoder - decoder neural networks ( CNNs ). The main contribution of the paper is the proposed network is to combine the multi - scale context with a pixel - level accuracy because of the weak visual appearance and strong prior information. Experiments are conducted on two datasets ( CIFAR-10 and ImageNet ) to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of learning a surrogate policy for bandit learning from logged bandit feedback. The paper proposes a new approach named Maximum Likelihood Inverse Propensity Scoring ( MLIPS ) for batch learning. The proposed approach is based on estimating a maximum likelihood surrogate policy based on the logged action - context pairs, and then use this surrogate policy as the proposal to learn the bandit policy from the logged feedback.   The paper provides a theoretical analysis to show that the proposed method is unbiased and has a smaller mean squared error than previous approaches based on inverse propensity weights. Experiments are conducted on a large - scale ad placement dataset and a multi - label classification dataset.

This paper proposes to use a kernel generator as meta - learner to learn to construct feature embedding for query images. The kernel generator acquires meta - knowledge of generating adequate convolutional kernels for different query images during training, which can generalize to unseen categories without fine - tuning. Experiments are conducted on two standard few - shot classification data sets, i.e., Omniglot, and miniImageNet. The proposed method shows highly competitive performance.

This paper presents a population - based evolutionary algorithm for deep reinforcement learning ( RL ). The main idea is to evolve the weights of a DNN with a simple, gradient - free, population - - based genetic algorithm ( GA ) and it performs well on hard deep RL problems, including Atari and humanoid locomotion. The proposed method is faster than existing evolutionary strategies ( ES, A3C, and DQN ), and enables a state - of - the - art compact encoding technique.

This paper proposes a curiosity module for reinforcement learning. The proposed method is based on the episodic memory to form the novelty bonus. The novelty bonus is determined based on how many environment steps it takes to reach the current observation from those in memory, which incorporates rich information about environment dynamics. This allows the agent to overcome the known “ ” “couch - potato ” problem where the agent finds a way to instantly gratify itself by exploiting actions which lead to hardly predictable consequences.

This paper studies the problem of learning transition models in uncertain domains using relational rules. For any action, a rule selects a set of relevant objects and computes a distribution over properties of just those objects in the resulting state given their properties in the previous state. Feed - forward neural networks are used to learn the transition distribution on the relevant objects ’ properties. This strategy is demonstrated to be both more versatile and more sample efficient than learning a monolithic transition model in a simulated domain in which a robot pushes stacks of objects on a cluttered table.

This paper proposes a new instance - wise feature selection method, which is based on the actor - critic methodology. The proposed method consists of 3 neural networks, a selector network, a predictor network, and a baseline network, which are used to train the selector network using the Actor - Critic methodology. Experiments are conducted on synthetic and real data to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a domain adaptation method to adapt the source data to the unlabeled target domain. To this end, the authors propose to learn discriminative feature representations of patches based on label histograms in the source domain, through the construction of a disentangled space. The authors also use an adversarial learning scheme to push the feature representations in target patches to the closer distributions in source ones. Extensive ablation studies and experiments are conducted on numerous benchmark datasets with various settings, such as synthetic - to - real and cross - city scenarios.

This paper proposes two new optimistic algorithms for AMSGrad and Adam, respectively, by exploiting the predictability of gradients. The new algorithms combine the idea of momentum method, adaptive gradient method, and algorithms in OPTIMISTIC ONLINE LEARNING, which leads to speed up in training deep neural nets in practice. The proposed algorithms are based on the observation that the mini - batch of stochastic gradients in consecutive iterations do not change drastically and consequently may be predictable.

This paper presents a new benchmark for robustness of image classifiers to common perturbations. The benchmark is based on ImageNet - C, which is a set of images from the ImageNet dataset that are perturbed by common corruptions and adversarial attacks. The paper also proposes a new dataset, IMAGENET - P, to evaluate the classifier ’s robustness to adversarial perturbation.   The paper is well - written and easy to follow. The results are interesting, and the paper is clearly written.

This paper studies dropout training for conditional language modelling. The authors show that the dropout objective can be understood as performing MAP estimation for an entire family of conditional models whose objectives are lower bounded by dropout objectives. This discovery allows them to pick any model from this family after training, which leads to a substantial improvement on regularisation - heavy language modeling. The deterministic subvariant ’s bound is equal to its objective, and the highest amongst these models.

This paper proposes a cumulative saliency based global soft filter pruning ( GSFP ) scheme to prune redundant filters of Convolutional Neural Networks ( CNNs ). Specifically, the GSFP adopts a robust pruning method, which measures the global redundancy of the filter in the whole model by using the soft pruning strategy. In addition, in the model recovery process after pruning, the proposed GSFP improves the accuracy of pruning. Experiments show that GSFP is effective on many CNN architectures and different data sets.

This paper proposes a cross - lingual document classification framework ( CACO ) between related language pairs. The key idea is to jointly train a character - based embedder and a word - based classifier to transfer knowledge about source language words to target language words with similar forms. The paper also proposes a multi - task objective that can further improve the model if additional cross - langual or monolingual resources are available.

This paper proposes a method to find dense and integral regions for each action in weakly supervised action localization. The authors propose a marginalized average attentional network ( MAAN ) to suppress the dominant response of the most salient regions in a principled manner. The MAAN employs a novel marginalized average aggregation ( MAA ) module and learns a set of latent discriminative probabilities in an end - to - end fashion. Extensive experiments on two large - scale video datasets show that the proposed MAAN achieves a superior performance on weakly - supervised temporal action localization tasks.

This paper proposes to use the reduced representation framework of Holographic Reduced Representation ( HRR ) to improve the representation of natural language processing models. The proposed method is based on the reduction of the word - level representation of a sentence into a lower - level embedding, which is then used to construct a representation of the sentence at the chunk - level. The authors show that the proposed model is able to identify the role of semantics and syntax in the sentence, which roughly resembles a classic division between syntax and semantics in the literature. The paper is well written and easy to follow.

This paper proposes a greedy strategy for observation selection that aims to minimize the uncertainty in state - action space of POMDPs. The authors propose a novel point - based value iteration algorithm that incorporates the greedy strategy to achieve near - optimal uncertainty reduction for sampled belief points. Experiments are conducted on a range of robotic scenarios where the robot simultaneously performs active perception and planning.

This paper proposes a curriculum loss for deep neural networks ( DNNs ). The main idea is to train top layers on “ good ” samples to reduce large shifting, and encourage “ bad samples to learn from ” good samples. The authors also propose a representation loss for low - weighted samples to encourage their training. Experiments are conducted on several benchmark datasets to show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of learning heuristics for combinatorial optimization problems. The authors propose a model based on attention layers with benefits over the Pointer Network and train this model using REINFORCE with a simple baseline based on a deterministic greedy rollout, which they find is more efficient than using a value function.
