This paper proposes a constrained backpropagation ( CBP ) algorithm based on the pseudo - range multiplier method to obtain the optimal set of weights that satisfy a given set of constraints. The defining characteristic of the proposed CBP algorithm is the utilization of a Lagrangian function ( loss function plus constraint function ) as its objective function. The proposed algorithm outperforms the state - of - the - art methods on ImageNet, e.g., 66.6, 74.4, and 64.0 % top - 1 accuracy for ResNet-18, ResNet50, and GoogLeNet with binary weights, respectively. The code for CBP is publicly available at GitHub.

This paper studies the problem of active learning for Gaussian process classification ( GPC ). The authors propose two active learning strategies that maximize the Estimated Error Reduction ( EER ) to reduce the classification error after training with the new acquired instance in a onestep - look - ahead manner. They also derive the gradient chain rule to efficiently calculate the gradient of the acquisition function, which leads to the first query synthesis active learning algorithm implementing EER - based strategies. The experiments clearly demonstrate the computational efficiency of the proposed algorithms.

This paper studies the effect of unbounded gradients on the regularization of autoencoder - based architectures, including VAE models, as applied to data lying on or near a low - dimensional manifold ( e.g., natural images ). The main finding is that if the ultimate goal is to simultaneously avoid over - regularization ( excessive latent dimensions are not pruned from the model ) and underregularization, then an autoencoders - based energy function with infinite gradients around optimal representations is provably required per a certain technical sense which the authors carefully detail. This result suggests that heuristic modifications to or constraints on the VAE energy function may at times be ill - advised, and large gradients should be accommodated to the extent possible.

This paper studies the bandit problem with graph feedback in the setting where a directed graph G = ( V, E ) where V is the collection of bandit arms, and once an arm is triggered, all its incident arms are observed. A fundamental question is how the structure of the graph affects the min - max regret. The paper proposes notions of the fractional weak domination number $ \delta$ and the k - packing independence number $ k$ to capture upper bound and lower bound for the regret respectively. The two notions are inherently connected via aligning them with the linear program of the weakly dominating set and its dual - fractional vertex packing set respectively. Based on this connection, the paper proves a general regret upper bound O ( ( ( log | log |V | ), log | V ) ) and a lower bound O(\log | V | ) 3 factor on graphs with bounded integrality gap of the dual linear program.

This paper proposes to use the Nadaraya - Watson kernel estimator as a self - normalised importance sampling estimator to improve the local interpretability of Shapley values. The authors show that the proposed method can identify meaningful sparse feature relevance attributions that provide insight into local model behaviour. They also show that adversarial classifiers are more explainable and robust to the construction of classifiers.

This paper proposes a novel method, PlayVirtual, to generate cycle - consistent virtual trajectories to enhance the data efficiency for deep reinforcement learning ( RL ). PlayVirtual predicts future states in a latent space based on the current state and action by a dynamics model and then predicts the previous states by a backward dynamics model, which forms a trajectory cycle. The authors validate the effectiveness of their designs on the Atari and DeepMind Control benchmarks.

This paper studies the robustness of neural networks to noisy labels. The authors propose a framework to connect the network ’s robustness to the alignments between its architecture and target / noise functions. The framework is based on the test performance of a linear model trained on the learned representations using a small set of clean labels. They hypothesize that a network is more robust if its architecture is more aligned with the target function than the noise. They provide both theoretical and empirical evidence across various neural network architectures and different domains to support their hypothesis.

This paper studies the problem of data - driven reinforcement learning ( DRL ), where examples of successful outcomes are provided in place of reward functions. The authors propose a control algorithm that maximizes the future probability of these successful outcome examples. They show that their method satisfies the Bellman equation, where the examples take the place of the typical reward function.

This paper studies differentially private stochastic optimization in convex and non - convex settings for generalized linear losses ( GLLs ). In the convex case, the authors propose a new algorithm for the l2 - case setting that achieves optimal excess population risk in near - linear time while the best known algorithms for general convex losses run in superlinear time. For the l1 - case with smooth losses and polyhedral constraint, they provide a linear - time algorithm with rate Á ( 1 n1/4 + d 1/6 ( n = O(n^1/6 ) ), which matches the best existing non - private algorithm when d = O(\sqrt(n)$. In the non - smooth weakly convex setting, they also provide the first method for non - smoothed non - symplectic optimization with rate   O(1 n1 / 4 + d1 / 6 ).

This paper studies cooperative bandit learning under three scenarios : stochastic time - varying networks, instantaneous reward sharing networks, and adversarially corrupted rewards. The authors propose decentralized algorithms that achieve competitive performance, along with near - optimal guarantees on the incurred group regret as well as in the setting with perfect communication. The proposed algorithms are straightforward to implement and obtain competitive empirical performance.

This paper proposes a post - training quantization algorithm for vision transformer for reducing the memory storage and computational costs of vision transformers. To preserve the functionality of the attention mechanism, the authors introduce a ranking loss into the conventional quantization objective that aims to keep the relative order of the self - attention results after quantization. The effectiveness of the proposed method is verified on several benchmark models and datasets, which outperforms the state - of - the - art quantization algorithms.

This paper studies the convergence rate of double - Q - learning in the setting where the learning rate is constant. The main contribution of this paper is the development of a new finite - time analysis of the convergence of the double - q - learning algorithm. The analysis is based on the assumption that the state - action space of the Q - learner is bounded by the discount factor. The authors show that synchronous double Q - Learning attains an - accurate global optimum with a time complexity of $ \Omega(\frac{1}{\sqrt{D}\leq \mathbb{R}^{1/\epsilon}^{7}$, and that the asynchronous algorithm achieves a $ \mathcal{O}(\log\left ( \frac{D\right)$ complexity with the same global optimum.   The authors also show that the synchronous and asynchronous algorithms converge to the global optimum in the same time steps.

This paper studies semi - supervised learning ( SSL ) for OOD detection, where the goal is to detect unlabeled and test data from the same distribution as labeled data. The main challenge is the lack of labeled data and in - distribution data, and the OOD samples could be unseen during training. The paper proposes a new technique, Structure - Keep - Unzipping ( STEP ), to detect OOD data from an unknown distribution. Experiments are conducted on several benchmark datasets to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a simple one - stage multi - task framework for visual grounding tasks. Two modalities are fused in a visual - lingual encoder. In the decoder, the model learns to generate contextualized lingual queries which are then decoded and used to directly regress the bounding box and produce a segmentation mask for the corresponding referred regions. Extensive experiments and ablations illustrate that the model benefits greatly from contextualized information and multi -task training.

This paper studies the problem of multi - class boosting, where the base class is assumed to belong to an easy - to - learn base class, and the weak learner is an agnostic PAC learner for that class with respect to the standard classification loss. The goal of the overall boosting algorithm is to learn a combination of weak hypotheses by repeatedly calling the weak learners. The paper shows that the number of samples required by a weak learners is at least polynomial in k, exponentially more than that of a strong learner.   The paper also proves a trade - off between number of oracle calls and the resources required of the weak Learner.

This paper proposes an embedding - based approach for unsupervised object segmentation and object - centric scene generation using a stochastic stick - breaking process. The proposed method is based on clustering object embeddings of pixels in a differentiable fashion, which is similar to iterative refinement. Experiments are conducted on two synthetic datasets and two real - world datasets. The results show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods on both synthetic datasets as well as more complex real world datasets with limited visual complexity.

This paper proposes a framework for forming prediction sets in an online setting where the data generating distribution is allowed to vary over time in an unknown fashion. The framework builds on ideas from conformal inference to provide a general wrapper that can be combined with any black box method that produces point predictions of the unseen label or estimated quantiles of its distribution. The authors test their method on two real world datasets and find that its predictions are robust to visible and significant distribution shifts.

This paper proposes a Pose - Level Inference Network ( PINet ) for multi - person pose estimation in crowded scenes. The proposed method is based on the Part - based Pose Generation ( PPG ) to infer multiple coarse poses for each person from his / her body parts. Those coarse poses are refined by the Pose Refinement module through incorporating pose priors, and finally are fused in the Pose Fusion module. Experiments on several crowded scenes pose estimation benchmarks demonstrate the superiority of PINet.

This paper proposes a fast exact algorithm for computing the Bellman operator for S - rectangular robust Markov decision processes with L∞ - unconstrained rectangular ambiguity sets. The algorithm combines a novel homotopy continuation method with a bisection method to solve S - Rectangular ambiguity in quasi - linear time in the number of states and actions. The experimental results confirm the practical viability of the proposed method and show that it outperforms a leading commercial optimization package by several orders of magnitude.

This paper studies the online knapsack problem with very weak predictions. The paper systematically derive online algorithms that attain the best possible competitive ratio for any fixed prediction. The results extend the results to more general settings such as generalized one - way trading and two - stage Online Knapsack.

This paper proposes a new model - based episodic memory of trajectories to address the limitations of episodic control. The memory estimates trajectory values, guiding the agent towards good policies. Experiments demonstrate that the proposed model allows significantly faster and better learning than other strong reinforcement learning agents across a variety of environments.

This paper proposes a method for semi - supervised learning ( SSL ) when the number of labeled data is very small ( say a few labeled samples per class ). The proposed method is based on a data programming ( DP ) scheme to generate probabilistic labels for unlabeled data. The authors propose a multiple - choice learning ( MCL ) based approach to automatically generate initial labeling functions ( LFs ) from scratch in SSL style. Extensive experiments on four standard SSL benchmarks show that the proposed method achieves better classification performance on test sets than existing SSL methods.

This paper presents a multi - view pose transformer ( MVPT ) method for estimating multi - person 3D poses from multi view images. The main contribution of the paper is a hierarchical pipeline to represent query embeddings of multi person skeleton joints and introduces an input - dependent query adaptation approach to improve the accuracy of the proposed method. The proposed method achieves 92.3 % AP25 on the challenging Panoptic dataset, improving upon the previous best approach [ 40 ] by 9.8 %. The method is general and also extendable to recovering human mesh represented by the SMPL model.

This paper considers the problem of learning the supports of a family of sparse vectors from a fixed set of known sparse vectors, where each vector has at most k non - zero elements. The authors propose two learning algorithms for this problem, one for the first problem and the other for the second problem. The main contribution of the paper is to prove the existence of the first learning algorithm, which is well - studied under the framework of 1 - bit compressed sensing. Under a mild structural assumption on the unknown vectors, the authors also show the existence   of the second learning algorithm for this second problem and rigorously analyze their query complexity.

This paper considers the bandit quickest changepoint detection problem. The authors propose a computationally efficient online sensing scheme, which seamlessly balances the need for exploration of different sensing options with exploitation of querying informative actions. They derive expected delay bounds for the proposed scheme and show that these bounds match the information - theoretic lower bounds at low false alarm rates. They also perform a number of experiments on synthetic and real datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies stochastic nested optimization in the context of bilevel, min - max, and compositional optimization. It unifies several SGD - type updates into a single SGD approach that the authors term ALternating Stochastic Gradient Descent Enthusiasts ( ALSET ) method. The main contribution of the paper is to provide a tighter analysis of the convergence rate of the proposed method. It is based on the observation that SGD updates for nested problems tend to have a slower convergence rate than non - nested problems. The authors also provide a set of experiments to support their claim.

This paper proposes a method for video question answering ( VQA ) based on siamese sampling to generate sparse and similar clips from the same video, and a novel reasoning strategy for integrating the interdependent knowledge between contextual clips into the network inference. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed method achieves state - of - the - art performance on five VideoQA benchmarks, e.g., a significant +2.1 % gain on MSRVTT - QA, -2.9 % on MSVD -QA, +1.8 % on How2QA and -4.3 % ( action ) on TGIF-QA. The paper is well - written and easy to follow.

This paper proposes a simple approach to reduce the computational and memory complexity of a large class of structured models. The proposed approach is to view the central inference step as a matrix - vector product and using a low - rank constraint. Experiments with neural parameterized structured models for language modeling, polyphonic music modeling, unsupervised grammar induction, and video modeling show that the approach matches the accuracy of standard models at large state spaces while providing practical speedups.

This paper proposes Sample Average Uncertainty ( SAU ), a simple and efficient uncertainty measure for Bayesian Bayesian Bandit exploration. The main contribution of the paper is to introduce a new uncertainty measure that directly estimates the uncertainty of the outcomes based on the value predictions of the bandit action - value function. The authors show theoretically that the uncertainty measure estimated by SAU asymptotically matches the uncertainty provided by Thompson Sampling, as well as its regret bounds. Experiments on several real - world datasets show that SAU - based exploration outperforms current state - of - the - art deep Bayesian bandit methods.

This paper presents a method for learning behavior embeddings from video of animals performing a repeated task. The method is based on disentangling the dynamic behavioral factors ( pose ) from time - to - time. The authors propose a stochastic temporal model for disentangled behavior embedding ( DBE ) and a variant of DBE called Variational Disentangled Behavior Embedding ( VDBE ). The proposed method is evaluated on a number of downstream tasks such as fine - grained behavioral motif generation and behavior decoding.

This paper presents a deep 3D conditional generative model that synthesizes high - resolution 3D shapes using simple user guides such as coarse voxels. The core of DMTET is a deformable tetrahedral grid that encodes a discretized signed distance function and a differentiable marching tetrahedra layer that converts the implicit signed distance representation to the explicit surface mesh representation. This combination allows joint optimization of the surface geometry and topology. Experiments are conducted on a dataset of complex 3D animal shapes.

This paper proposes sliced mutual information ( SMI ) as a surrogate measure of statistical dependence. SMI is defined as an average of mutual information terms between one - dimensional random projections. The authors show that it preserves many of the structural properties of classic MI, while gaining scalable computation and efficient estimation from samples. This enables leveraging SMI for feature extraction by optimizing it over processing functions of raw data to identify useful representations thereof.

This paper proposes a computationally efficient two - step lookahead constrained Bayesian optimization acquisition function ( 2 - OPT - C ) supporting both sequential and batch settings. The authors argue that being non - myopic is even more important in constrained problems because fear of violating constraints pushes myopic methods away from sampling the feasible and infeasible regions, slowing the discovery of optimal solutions with tight constraints.   In numerical experiments, 2 - OPT - C typically improves query efficiency by 2x or more over previous methods, and in some cases by some orders of magnitude.

This paper proposes a multi - dimensional distributional reinforcement learning ( MD3QN ) algorithm to model the joint return distribution from multiple reward sources in reinforcement learning. The main contribution of this paper is to extend distributional RL to model multi - dimensional reward functions. The proposed method can capture not only randomness in returns for each source of reward but also the rich reward correlation between the randomness of different sources in the control setting. Extensive experiments are conducted to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper presents a new geometric deep - learning model that learns to deform a reference template towards a targeted object. To conserve the template mesh ’s topological properties, the model trains its model over a set of diffeomorphic transformations. This new implementation of a flow Ordinary Differential Equation ( ODE ) framework benefits from a small GPU memory footprint, allowing the generation of surfaces with several hundred thousand vertices. To reduce topological errors introduced by its discrete resolution, the paper derives numeric conditions which improve the manifoldness of the predicted triangle mesh. The paper demonstrates its performance for the challenging task of brain cortical surface reconstruction.

This paper studies the problem of data deletion in the non - convex setting. In this setting, data deletion algorithms aim to remove the influence of deleted data points from trained models at a cheaper computational cost than fully retraining those models. Most prior work in this setting gives valid guarantees only for sequences of deletions that are chosen independently of the models that are published. If people choose to delete their data as a function of the published models ( because they don’t like what the models reveal about them, for example ), then the update sequence is adaptive. This paper gives a general reduction from deletion guarantee against adaptive sequences to deletion guarantees against non - adaptive sequences.

This paper studies the problem of optimising the conditional value at risk ( CVaR ) of the total return in Bayes - Adaptive Markov decision processes ( MDPs ). The authors reformulate the problem as a two - player stochastic game and propose an approximate algorithm based on Monte Carlo tree search and Bayesian optimisation. The experiments demonstrate that the proposed algorithm significantly outperforms baseline approaches for this problem.

This paper studies the behavior of shallow ReLU networks trained with the logistic loss via gradient descent on binary classification data where the underlying data distribution is general and the ( optimal ) Bayes risk is not necessarily zero. In this setting, it is shown that gradient descent with early stopping achieves population risk arbitrarily close to optimal in terms of logistic and misclassification losses, and calibration. The paper also shows that the necessary iteration, sample, and architectural complexities of this analysis all scale naturally with a certain complexity measure of the true conditional model.

This paper proposes a coordination detection framework incorporating neural temporal point process with prior knowledge such as temporal logic or pre - defined filtering functions. The authors jointly learn a Gibbs distribution of group assignment based on how consistent an assignment is to ( 1 ) the account embedding space and ( 2 ) the distribution of the distribution is. The proposed method is applied on a COVID - 19 Vaccine Tweets dataset to detect coordinated efforts to spread misinformation about COVID-19 vaccines. The detection result suggests presence of suspicious coordinated efforts on spreading misinformation.

This paper studies the problem of binary classification with low - dimensional non - linear structure, where the data is drawn from two disjoint smooth curves on the unit sphere. The authors prove that when the network depth is sufficiently deep relative to certain geometric properties that set the difficulty of the problem, and the network width and number of samples are polynomial in the depth, randomly - initialized gradient descent quickly learns to correctly classify all points on the two curves with high probability.   This is the first generalization guarantee for deep networks with nonlinear data that depends only on intrinsic data properties. In particular, via fine - grained control of the decay properties of the NTK, the authors show that the network can be locally approximated by a translationally invariant operator on the manifolds and stably inverted over smooth functions.

This paper studies the problem of training a GAN with softmax cross - entropy loss ( ACGAN ). In particular, the authors identify that gradient exploding in the classifier can cause an undesirable collapse in early training, and propose projecting input vectors onto a unit hypersphere to resolve the problem. They also propose a Data - to - Data Cross - Entropy loss ( D2D - CE ) to exploit relational information in class - labeled dataset. The experimental results show that ReACGAN achieves state - of - the - art generation results on CIFAR10, Tiny - ImageNet, CUB200, and ImageNet datasets.

This paper proposes an extensive - form double - oracle algorithm for two - player zero - sum games that is guaranteed to converge to an approximate Nash equilibrium linearly in the number of infostates. The authors also introduce Neural XDO ( NXDO ) where the best response is learned through deep RL. Experiments show that XDO achieves a lower exploitability than CFR with the same amount of computation.

This paper proposes a permutation - invariant variational autoencoder for graph structured data. The main contribution of the paper is to propose a model for graph - level unsupervised representation learning. The proposed model indirectly learns to match the node order of input and output graph, without imposing a particular node order or performing expensive graph matching. Experiments are conducted to evaluate the expressive power of extracted representations for downstream graph classification and regression tasks.

This paper proposes a method to decouple the depth and scope of graph neural networks ( GNNs ). Specifically, to generate representation of a target entity ( i.e., a node or an edge ), the authors first extract a localized subgraph as the bounded - size scope, and then apply a GNN of arbitrary depth on top of the subgraph. A properly extracted subgraph consists of a small number of critical neighbors, while excluding irrelevant ones. Experiments are conducted on seven graphs ( with up to 110 M nodes ) and six backbone GNN architectures. The proposed method achieves significant accuracy improvement with orders of magnitude reduction in computation and hardware cost.

This paper studies the problem of training Affine - couplings for normalizing flows, a class of latent - variable generative models with a tractable likelihood. The authors show that any log - concavity distribution can be approximated using well - conditioned affine - coupling flows. They also provide theoretical evidence for the benefits of Gaussian padding when training affine couplings.

This paper studies the problem of coupons allocation policy learning in the context of e - commerce. The authors propose a Lagrangian generalization method to solve the problem. They also propose a novel offline reinforcement learning method and an off - policy evaluation algorithm for policy learning and policy evaluation, respectively. The experiments on the simulation platform and real - world e -commerce market validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

This paper proposes a domain adaptation method for the source - free domain adaptation ( SFDA ) problem, where the source pretrained model is adapted to the target domain in the absence of source data. The method is based on the observation that target data, which might no longer align with the source domain classifier, still forms clear clusters by defining local affinity of the target data and encourage label consistency among data with high local affinity. The authors also propose a self - regularization loss to decrease the negative impact of noisy neighbors. The experimental results verify that the inherent structure of target features is an important source of information for domain adaptation.

This paper proposes a method for learning representations from set - structured data. The key idea is to treat elements of a set as samples from a probability distribution and propose an end - to - end trainable Euclidean embedding for sliced - Wasserstein distance to learn representation learning from data effectively. The proposed method is evaluated on a range of tasks including point - cloud, graph, and image classification tasks and shows superior performance over existing set representation learning approaches.

This paper considers the training stability of recurrent neural networks ( RNNs ) and proposes a family of RNN models that can be formulated using stochastic bilevel optimization ( SBO ). The authors prove that under mild conditions there is no vanishing or exploding gradient in training SBO - RNN. Empirically, the proposed model achieves superior performance on several benchmark datasets with fewer parameters, less training data, and much faster convergence.

This paper studies the problem of minimizing power consumption in systems with multiple power - saving states of different energy consumption and wake - up costs during idle periods of unknown lengths. The authors develop a learning - augmented online algorithm that makes decisions based on ( potentially inaccurate ) predicted lengths of the idle periods. The algorithm ’s performance is near - optimal when predictions are accurate and degrades gracefully with increasing prediction error, with a worst - case guarantee almost identical to the optimal classical online algorithm for the problem.

This paper proposes a transferability measure for multi - source transfer learning problems that takes into account both the task similarities and the sample complexity of learning models taken into account. In particular, the authors consider the setup where the models learned from different tasks are linearly combined for learning the target task, and use the optimal combining coefficients to measure the transferability. The authors demonstrate the analytical expression of this transferable measure, characterized by the sample sizes, model complexity, and the similarities between source and target tasks, and provide fundamental insights of the knowledge transferring mechanism and the guidance for algorithm designs.

This paper proposes a neural network - based model for visual search. The proposed model is based on the observation that some classical search tasks ( e.g. looking for car keys in a crowd or finding a target among distractors ) can be easier than other tasks. The authors propose a model that takes a target and a search image as inputs and produces a sequence of eye movements until the target is found. The model integrates eccentricity - dependent visual recognition with target - dependent top - down cues and is evaluated on six paradigmatic search tasks that show asymmetry in humans.

This paper studies the problem of training robust models against adversarial examples. The authors claim that the smoothness of the loss landscape is a key factor that influences the performance of certifiable training. They find significant differences in the loss landscapes across many linear relaxation - based methods, and that the current state - of - the - art method often has a landscape with favorable optimization properties. The proposed method achieves a decent performance under a wide range of perturbations, while others with only one of the two factors can perform well only for a specific range of samples.

This paper studies the problem of online linear regression in the stochastic setting. The authors derive high probability regret bounds for online ridge regression and the forward algorithm in lieu of ridge regression. This enables them to compare online regression algorithms more accurately and eliminate assumptions of bounded observations and predictions. Numerical experiments are provided to illustrate their results and endorse their intuitions.

This paper studies two variants of the extragradient ( EG ) method for nonconvex - nonconcave minimax problems. In particular, a two - time - scale variant of the EG, named EG+, is proposed under a smooth structured non - convex non - concave setting, with a slow O(1 / k ) rate on the squared gradient norm, where k denotes the number of iterations. Another variant of EG with an anchoring technique, named extra - anchored gradient ( EAG ), is studied under a smoother convex - concave setting and yields a fast O(\sqrt{O}(1/k) rate on squared gradients norm. The stochastic analysis of FEG is also provided.

This paper studies uniformity testing for ranking data, where the alternative class is restricted to Mallows models. The dataset consists of rankings over $ m$ items, and the test data is a uniform distribution over m items. The authors propose two algorithms to test uniformity of the ranking data. The first algorithm is based on a simple pairwise statistic, the second algorithm has a central and local differential privacy ( DP ) constraint. The experiments show that the proposed algorithm can be used to detect uniform distribution with O(m 1 / m 1 / 2 ) samples.

This paper studies a score - based greedy algorithm for learning directed acyclic graphs ( DAGs ). The main contribution of this paper is to provide a general definition of the score based algorithm for DAG learning. This definition is based on the fact that the greedy algorithm requires at most a polynomial number of score evaluations. The paper also provides an analysis of the polynomials of the order - based algorithms for learning DAG models. The authors also provide extensive experiments suggesting that this algorithm indeed optimizes the score in a variety of settings.

This paper studies the problem of adversarial robustness of convolutional neural networks ( CNNs ). The authors propose a new architecture for the backbone CNNs that is designed to be more robust to adversarial attacks. The proposed architecture is based on the Dilation architecture, which is a modification of the standard CNN architecture. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of the new architecture to improve the accuracy and robustness trade - off between the standard accuracy and the adversarial accuracy.

This paper studies the problem of reward - free reinforcement learning with linear function approximation for episodic Markov decision processes ( MDPs ). In this setting, in the exploration phase, the agent interacts with the environment and collects samples without the reward. The planning phase is in the planning phase, where the agent is given a reward function and uses the samples collected in exploration phase to learn a good policy. The authors propose a new provably efficient algorithm UCRL - RFE under the Linear Mixture MDP assumption where the transition probability kernel of the MDP can be parameterized by a linear function over feature mappings defined on the triplet of state, action, and next state. They show that to obtain an $ \epsilon$-optimal policy for arbitrary reward function, UCRL-RFE needs to sample at most $ \tilde{H}(H^2 d^{2 } episodes during exploration phase ). The upper bound matches the lower bound in terms of the dependence on $ H$ and $ d$.

This paper proposes a method for forecasting future events based on a data stream of events with seasonal patterns that innovate over time. The authors propose Shifting Seasonal Matrix Factorization ( SSMF ), which can adaptively learn multiple seasonal patterns ( called regimes ), as well as switching between them. The proposed method has the following properties : ( a ) it accurately forecasts future events by detecting regime shifts in seasonal patterns as the data stream evolves ; ( b ) it works in an online setting, i.e., processes each observation in constant time and memory ; and ( c ) it effectively realizes regime shifts without human intervention by using a lossless data compression scheme.

This paper proposes a neural network architecture for solving non - linear assignment problems. The main idea is to use a feature - weaving layer to solve the problem of matching a set of elements with a limited number of elements. The paper also proposes an algorithm for solving the assignment problem. The proposed method is evaluated on two real - world assignment problems, where it is shown to achieve better performance than the state - of - the - art algorithmic method.

This paper studies the impact of various self - supervised learning proxy tasks on different architectures and threat models for 3D point clouds with adversarial training. Specifically, the authors study MLP - based ( PointNet ), convolution ( DGCNN ) and transformer ( PCT ) 3D architectures. Extensive experimentation is conducted to demonstrate that appropriate applications of self - supervision can significantly enhance the robustness of the models against adversarial attacks.

This paper studies the problem of computing projections in online optimization algorithms. The authors propose a method to improve the runtime of computing certain Bregman projections by a factor of $ \mathcal{O}(n / log(n)/log(n)$.   The main contribution of the paper is a method for computing the projection of an online mirror - descent algorithm. The main idea is to use the away - step - -Wolfe algorithm to compute the projection in each iteration of the algorithm, which is computationally efficient. The method is evaluated on a number of synthetic and real - world datasets.

This paper considers the problem of learning the natural parameters of a k - parameter minimal exponential family from i.i.d. samples in a computationally and statistically efficient manner. The authors focus on the setting where the support as well as natural parameters are appropriately bounded. They provide finite sample guarantees to achieve an ( `2 ) error of $ \alpha$ in the parameter estimation with sample complexity $ O(poly(k / \alpha)$ and computational complexity $ \mathcal{O}(k/\alpha)$. They show that, at the population level, their method can be viewed as the maximum likelihood estimation of a re - parametrized distribution belonging to the same class of exponential family.

This paper proposes a method to predict intrinsic object properties from a single image by exploiting differentiable renderers. The method is a hybrid differentiable - rasterization - based renderer that combines the strengths of their respective strengths -- speed and realism. The proposed method is evaluated on synthetic and real data, and is compared to existing learning - based approaches.

This paper proposes a differentiable training method for soft - max localization. The proposed method is based on a continuous formulation of the output distribution and a sampling process to approximate the expectation of the localization error. Experiments show the effectiveness and flexibility of the proposed method on various localization tasks.

Graph Contrastive Learning ( GCL ) has emerged to learn generalizable representations from contrastive views. However, it is still in its infancy with two concerns : 1 ) changing the graph structure through data augmentation may mislead the message passing scheme, as such graph changing action deprives the intrinsic graph structural information, especially the directional structure in directed graphs ; 2 ) since GCL usually uses predefined contrastive view with hand - picked parameters, it does not take full advantage of the contrastive information provided by data augmentation, resulting in incomplete structure information for models learning. To address these concerns, this paper proposes a directed graph data - augmentation method called Laplacian perturbation and theoretically analyze how it provides contrastive info without changing the directed graph structure. Experiments on various benchmarks reveal its dominance over the state - of - the - art approaches.

This paper proposes a benchmark for language grounding that unifies a collection of diverse grounded language learning environments under a common interface. The benchmark consists of grid - world environments that require generalization to new dynamics, entities, and partially observed worlds ( RTFM, Messenger, NetHack ) as well as symbolic counterparts of visual worlds that require interpreting rich natural language with respect to complex scenes ( ALFWorld, Touchdown ). In addition, the authors propose the first shared model architecture for RL on these environments, and evaluate recent advances such as egocentric local convolution, recurrent state - tracking, entity - centric attention, and pretrained LM using the benchmark.

This paper presents a sparse version of the Vision Transformer network that is scalable and competitive with the largest dense networks. The authors propose an extension to the routing algorithm that can prioritize subsets of each input across the entire batch, leading to adaptive per - image compute. This allows V - MoE to trade - off performance and compute smoothly at test - time. Experiments are conducted on image recognition and text recognition datasets.

This paper studies the expressivity of narrow neural networks. The authors show that as long as the width m > 2n / d ( where d is the input dimension ), its expressivity is strong, i.e., there exists at least one global minimizer with zero training loss. They also identify a nice local region with no local - min or saddle points for training narrow neural nets, and prove that every KKT point is a nearly global minimizor. Finally, numerical results show that projected gradient methods on this constrained formulation significantly outperform SGD for training narrower neural nets.

This paper studies the problem of risk - aware multi - armed bandit learning. The authors propose a novel Continuous - Covariance Bandit ( CMCB ) model to explicitly take into account option correlation. The paper considers three feedback settings, i.e. full - information, semi - bandit and full bandit feedback, to capture different reward observation scenarios in practice.   The authors also propose novel algorithms with optimal regrets to validate their optimalities.

This paper studies the problem of computing positive semidefinite matrix factorization ( PSD factorization ). The authors propose a matrix multiplicative update ( MMU ) algorithm, which ensures that updates remain PSD by congruence scaling with the matrix geometric mean of appropriate PSD matrices. The squared loss objective is non - increasing and fixed points correspond to critical points. The analysis relies on Lieb ’s Concavity Theorem. Experiments are conducted on real and synthetic data.

This paper proposes a meta - learning framework for domain generalization ( DG ). The key insight is to disentangle features in the latent space while jointly learning both domain - invariant and domains - specific features in a unified framework. The domain - specific representation is optimized through the meta - Learning framework to adapt from source domains, targeting a robust generalization on unseen domains. The paper empirically show that mDSDI provides competitive results with state - of - the - art techniques in DG. A further ablation study with the generated dataset, Background -Colored - MNIST, confirms the hypothesis that domain-specific is essential, leading to better results when compared with only using domain -invariant.

This paper presents a new method for unconditional image synthesis and conditional image synthesis. The proposed method is based on ablations to improve the sample quality of the generated images. The authors also propose a classifier guidance method to further improve the performance of the proposed method. Experiments are conducted on three image datasets ( ImageNet 128, ImageNet 256 and ImageNet 512 ) to demonstrate the effectiveness of the method.

This paper proposes to leverage out - of - distribution samples, i.e., unlabeled samples coming from outside target classes, for improving few - shot learning. The proposed method is simple to implement, agnostic to feature extractors, lightweight without any additional cost for pre - training, and applicable to both inductive and transductive settings. Extensive experiments on various standard benchmarks demonstrate that the proposed method consistently improves the performance of pretrained networks with different architectures.

This paper studies the problem of prioritization in reinforcement learning. The authors propose two methods to compute the prioritization weight, namely ReMERN and ReMERT. Both methods outperform previous prioritized sampling algorithms in challenging RL benchmarks, including MuJoCo, Atari and Meta - World. The paper also provides theoretical justifications for previous criteria, including TD error, recentness and corrective feedback.

This paper considers the problem of sequential prediction with expert advice in a nonstationary environment with long - term memory guarantees in the sense of Bousquet and Warmuth [ 4 ]. The authors propose a linear - time algorithm that improves on the best known regret bounds [ 27 ] by incorporating a relative entropy projection step. This projection is advantageous over previous weight - sharing approaches in that weight updates may come with implicit costs.

This paper considers the problem of contextual linear bandits, where the learner wishes to learn a hidden d - dimensional value w∗. The learner is presented with a subset Xt ⊆ R of possible actions, and the goal is to decide which action to recommend to the user. The paper proposes two algorithms for this problem which achieve regret O(d log T ) and exp(O(D log d ). The authors also consider a variant of the problem where the user only learns the identity of an action that is better than the recommendation. The proposed algorithms are based on new algorithmic techniques in convex geometry.

This paper introduces a small set of orthogonal combinators for composing machine learning operators into pipelines. It describes a translation scheme from pipelines and associated hyperparameter schemas to search spaces for AutoML optimizers. The paper presents Lale, an open - source sklearn - compatible AutoML library, and evaluates it with a user study.

This paper studies the problem of finding neural network weights that generalize well from small datasets. The authors propose to learn a weight initialization such that a small number of weight changes results in low generalization error. They show that patterned sparsity emerges from this process, with the pattern of sparsity varying on a problem - by - problem basis. This selective sparsity results in better generalization and less interference in a range of few - shot and continual learning problems.

This paper studies the problem of shared response modeling, a multi - view learning problem where one wants to identify common components from multiple datasets or views. The authors introduce Shared Independent Component Analysis ( ShICA ) that models each view as a linear transform of shared independent components contaminated by additive Gaussian noise. They show that this model is identifiable if the components are either non - Gaussian or have enough diversity in noise variances. They then show that in some cases multi - set canonical correlation analysis can recover the correct unmixing matrices, but that even a small amount of sampling noise makes Multiset CCA fail. To solve this problem, the authors propose to use joint diagonalization after Multisets CCA, leading to a new approach called ShICA - J.

This paper studies a two - player collaborative cooking simulator that has recently been proposed as a challenge problem for coordination with humans. The authors propose to train agents that collaborate well with human partners without using human data first. They argue that the crux of the problem is to produce a diverse set of training partners and train agents to adapt to their individual strengths, weaknesses, and preferences. They propose a method called Fictitious Co - Play ( FCP ) that trains agents as the best response to a population of self - play agents and their past checkpoints taken throughout training. They show that FCP agents score significantly higher than SP, PP, and BCP when paired with novel agent and human partners over all baselines.

This paper proposes a new method for cooperative multi - agent reinforcement learning in both discrete and continuous action spaces. The key idea is to use a centralised but factored critic, which combines per - agent utilities into the joint action - value function via a non - linear monotonic function, as in QMIX. The proposed method is evaluated on MuJoJo benchmark and a challenging set of StarCraft II micromanagement tasks.

This paper presents a new neural network architecture for long - term memory that leverages biologically plausible three - factor plasticity rules to improve the performance of the classical Hopfield network on memory tasks. The proposed architecture is based on a combination of biologically plausible 3 - factor rules and a key - value mechanism. The network is evaluated on several memory tasks including continual recall, hetero - occlusion memory, and sequence learning. The results show that the proposed architecture outperforms the classical model on all tasks.

This paper studies the problem of pairwise learning, where the loss function depends on a pair of instances. The authors propose simple stochastic and online gradient descent methods for the problem. They also extend their algorithms and stability analysis to develop differentially private SGD algorithms which significantly improves the existing results. The paper is well - written and easy to follow.

This paper proposes a class - agnostic framework to reconstruct the Dynamic Objects from RGBD or calibrated videos. The proposed framework is based on a canonical 4D implicit function which is pixel - aligned with aggregated temporal visual cues. The authors also develop a 4D transformation module to capture object dynamics to support temporal propagation and aggregation. The experiments are conducted on synthetic datasets and real - world video data 3DPW.

This paper provides a non - asymptotic analysis of linear stochastic approximation ( LSA ) algorithms with fixed stepsize. The analysis is based on new results regarding moments and high probability bounds for products of matrices which are shown to be tight. High probability bounds are also derived on the performance of LSA under weaker conditions on the sequence { ( An,bn ) : n 2 N⇤ } than previous works. However, in contrast, polynomial concentration bounds with order depending on the stepsize are established.

This paper extends the options framework for temporal abstraction in reinforcement learning from discounted Markov decision processes ( MDPs ) to average - reward MDPS. The authors propose general convergent off - policy inter - option learning algorithms, intra - option algorithms for learning values and models, as well as sample - based planning variants of their learning algorithms. The proposed algorithms and convergence proofs extend those recently developed by Wan, Naik, and Sutton. They also extend the notion of option - interrupting behavior from the discounted to the average - reward formulation. The efficacy of the proposed algorithms is demonstrated on a continuing version of the Four - Room domain.

This paper studies the performance of visual transformers ( VTs ) trained on ImageNet. The authors show that their performance on smaller datasets can be largely different from ImageNet, and propose an auxiliary self - supervised task which can extract additional information from images with only a negligible computational overhead. The proposed task is used jointly with the standard ( supervised ) training and it does not depend on specific architectural choices, thus it can be easily plugged in the existing Visual Transformers ( VTs ). Experiments with different datasets are conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new method for label - free alignment of hierarchical datasets in hyperbolic spaces. The proposed method is based on the Riemannian geometry of the Lorentz model of hyperbola space. The method consists of three components : translation, scaling, and rotation. The authors analyze the proposed components, highlighting their useful properties for alignment. The efficacy of HPA, its theoretical properties, stability and computational efficiency are demonstrated in simulations.

This paper studies the trade - off between accuracy for a population of interest ( sum query ) and accuracy for its component sub - populations ( point queries ). The authors show that under certain assumptions, the accuracy can degrade by a logarithmic factor compared to differentially private query answering systems that are not required to produce microdata.   The authors present lower bounds for pure, approximate, and concentrated differential privacy, and create a collection of benchmark datasets that can be used for public study of this problem.

This paper proposes a method to train a path - planner and RL agent to jointly learn from each other on a curriculum of tree - structured sub - tasks. The planner decomposes a long - horizon task to a tree of sub - tasks in a top - down manner, whose layers construct coarse - to - fine sub - task sequences as plans to complete the original task. The planning policy is trained to minimize the RL agent ’s cost of completing the sequence in each layer from top to bottom layers, which gradually increases the sub - Tasks and thus forms an easy to - hard curriculum for the planner. Experiments are conducted on navigation and continuous control tasks, where the proposed method significantly improves the success rate and sample efficiency.

This paper presents a Bayesian framework for generating local explanations along with their associated uncertainty. The framework is based on Bayesian versions of LIME and KernelSHAP, which output credible intervals for the feature importances, capturing the associated uncertainty and local explanations. Experiments are conducted on multiple real world datasets and user studies demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed framework.

This paper studies the problem of heavy tails in Adder neural networks ( ANNs ). The authors argue that unordered heavy tails could be the key component which prevents ANNs from achieving superior classification performance since fatter tails tend to overlap in feature space. To address this problem, the authors propose to use an angle - based constraint on the distribution parameters to encourage high diversity of tails. Experiments are conducted on several benchmarks and comparison with other distributions demonstrate the effectiveness of proposed approach.

This paper studies the phenomenon of feature starvation in neural networks. The authors identify and formalize a fundamental gradient descent phenomenon leading to a learning proclivity in over - parametrized neural networks called Gradient Starvation. Gradient starvation arises when cross - entropy loss is minimized by capturing only a subset of features relevant for the task, despite the presence of other predictive features that fail to be discovered. This work provides a theoretical explanation for the emergence of such feature imbalances in neural network. Based on the proposed formalism, the authors develop a novel but simple regularization method aimed at decoupling feature learning dynamics, improving accuracy and robustness in cases hindered by gradient starvation.

This paper presents a single - blind evaluation of teams of humans and AI agents in the cooperative card game Hanabi, with both rule - based and learning - based agents. In addition to the game score, the authors also quantify subjective measures of the human ’s perceived performance, teamwork, interpretability, trust, and overall preference of AI teammate. They find that humans have a clear preference toward a rule - -based AI teammate ( SmartBot ) over a state - of - the - art learning - - based agent ( Other - Play ) across nearly all subjective metrics, despite no statistical difference in game score.

This paper presents a novel learning approach for visual question generation ( VQG ), which aims to generate human - like neural questions from an image and potentially other side information ( e.g., answer type or the answer itself ). The key rationale is that the predicted visual hints are not available naturally, and the proposed method can be cast as a weakly supervised learning problem with noises. The proposed method outperforms the state - of - the - art approaches by a large margin on a variety of metrics, including both automatic machine metrics and human evaluation.

This paper proposes a method to mitigate label noise and class imbalance by manipulating gradients at the class level. The proposed method unrolls the loss gradient to class - level gradients by the chain rule and reweights the flow of each gradient separately. Extensive experiments in various settings verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper presents a novel task of grounding language grounded in spatio - temporal language. The task is to learn the meaning of spatio    descriptions of behavioral traces of an embodied agent. The descriptions involve time - extended predicates in past and present as well as spatio _ temporal _ references to objects in the scene. The authors train several models including multimodal Transformers on two classes of generalization : 1 ) generalization to randomly held - out - of - distribution ( HOD ) sentences ; 2 ) generalisation to grammar primitives. They show that maintaining object identity in the attention is instrumental to achieving good performance on generalization overall, and that summarizing object traces in a single token has little influence on performance. They also discuss how this opens new perspectives for language - guided autonomous embodied agents.

This paper proposes a method for online multiple object tracking and segmentation. The proposed method first distills a space - time memory into a set of prototypes and then employs cross - attention to retrieve rich information from the past frames. To segment each object, the proposed method adopts a prototypical appearance module to learn contrastive foreground and background prototypes, which are then propagated over time. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the method.

This paper studies the degree to which gradient flow is equivalent to gradient descent in deep learning optimization. The authors first show that the degree of approximation depends on the curvature around the gradient flow trajectory. Then they show that over deep neural networks with homogeneous activations, gradient flow trajectories enjoy favorable curvature, suggesting they are well approximated by gradient descent. This finding allows them to translate an analysis of gradient flow over deep linear neural networks into a guarantee that gradient descent efficiently converges to gradient flow.

This paper considers a stochastic multi - armed bandit ( MAB ) problem with delayed impact of actions. In this setting, actions taken in the past impact the arm rewards in the subsequent future. The paper proposes an algorithm that achieves a regret of KT(KT 2/3 ) and shows a matching regret lower bound of KT2/3.    The paper considers the bandit setting where K is the number of arms and T is the learning horizon. The goal is to maximize the collected utilities over time while taking into account the dynamics created by the delayed impacts of historical actions.

This paper proposes a method for video instance segmentation ( VIM ) based on transformers. The key idea is to use memory tokens as a means of conveying information as well as summarizing each frame scene. The features of each frame are enriched and correlated with other frames through exchange of information between the precisely encoded memory tokens. The method is evaluated on the latest benchmark sets and achieves state - of - the - art performance.

Graph embedding maps a graph into a convenient vector - space representation for graph analysis and machine learning applications. Many graph embedding methods hinge on a sampling of context nodes based on random walks. The random walks can be a biased sampler due to the structural properties of graphs. Most notably, random walks are biased by the degree of each node, where a node is sampled proportionally to its degree. The implication of such biases has not been clear, particularly in the context of graph representation learning. This paper investigates the impact of the random walks ’ bias on graph embeddings and propose residual2vec, a general graph embeddedding method that can debias various structural biases in graphs by using random graphs.

This paper studies the problem of estimating non - linear functionals of discrete distributions in the context of local differential privacy. In this setting, the initial data x1,..., xn \in [ K ] are supposed i.i.d. and distributed according to an unknown discrete distribution p = ( p1,..., pK ), but only α - locally differentially private ( LDP ) samples z1,..., zn are publicly available, where the term ’ local ’ means that each zi is produced using one individual attribute xi. The paper studies two mechanisms : ( i ) sequentially interactive ( i.e., they are allowed to use already published confidential data ) or ( ii ) non - inter - active ( they are not ). In the interactive case, the paper proposes a two - step procedure which attains the parametric rate ( nα2 - 1 / 2 when $ \mathbb{R}^2 $ when $ K \geq 2 $ for all $ \gamma$. In the non - interactive case the paper presents lower bounds over all α - LDP mechanisms and all estimators using the private samples.

This paper studies the problem of online multiclass classification in a setting where the learner ’s feedback is determined by an arbitrary directed graph. The paper introduces GAPPLETRON, a new algorithm that works with arbitrary feedback graphs. For this new algorithm, the authors prove surrogate regret bounds that hold, both in expectation and with high probability, for a large class of surrogate losses.

This paper studies the problem of explainable clustering in the setting first formalized by Dasgupta, Frost, Moshkovitz, and Rashtchian ( ICML 2020 ). A k - clustering is said to be explainable if it is given by a decision tree where each internal node splits data points with a threshold cut in a single dimension ( feature ), and each of the k leaves corresponds to a cluster. The authors give an algorithm that outputs an explainable cluster that loses at most a factor of O(log k ) compared to an optimal ( not necessarily explainable ) clustering for the k - medians objective, and a factor O(k log k ) for the   k - means objective. This improves over the previous best upper bounds and generalize to objectives given by higher   p - norms.

This paper proposes a multilingual pre - trained language model ( PrLM ) that supports both explicit universal dependency parsing and implicit language modeling. Syntax in terms of universal dependency parse serves as not only pre - training objective but also learned representation in the model. The proposed model outperforms two popular multilingual PrLM benchmarks and two linguistic structure parsing datasets, demonstrating the effectiveness and stronger cross - lingual modeling capabilities of the proposed model.

This paper presents a Dual - Aspect Collaborative Transformer ( DACT ) to learn embeddings for node and positional features separately, instead of fusing them together as done in existing ones, to avoid potential noises and incompatible correlations. The positional features are embedded through a novel cyclic positional encoding ( CPE ) method to allow Transformer to effectively capture the circularity and symmetry of VRP solutions ( i.e., cyclic sequences ). The authors train DACT using Proximal Policy Optimization and design a curriculum learning strategy for better sample efficiency.

This paper studies the Bayes error, which measures the optimal classification error theoretically achievable for a given data distribution. The authors show that they can compute the exact Bayes errors of generative models learned using normalizing flows. They also show that by varying the temperature of the learned flow models, they can generate synthetic datasets that closely resemble standard benchmark datasets. Finally, they use their method to evaluate the intrinsic hardness of standard benchmark dataset.

This paper proposes a method for initializing neural network parameters. The method is based on a simple heuristic that adjusts the norm of each network layer so that a single step of SGD or Adam with prescribed hyperparameters results in the smallest possible loss value. This adjustment is done by introducing a scalar multiplier variable in front of each parameter block, and then optimizing these variables using a simple numerical scheme. Experiments show that the proposed method accelerates the convergence and test performance of many convolutional architectures.

This paper presents a method for estimating the progression of Alzheimer's disease using longitudinal data. The proposed method is based on the linear mixed - effect models. The authors propose to learn the metric as the push - forward of the Euclidean metric by a diffeomorphism. This metric is estimated iteratively as the composition of radial basis functions belonging to a reproducible kernel Hilbert space. The method is evaluated on the ADNI dataset and the results show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods.

This paper proposes a routing - by - memory mechanism for existing CNN architectures. In each stage of the network, it introduces parallel Procedural Units ( PUs ). The memory head maintains a summary of a type of features. For an intermediate feature, it searches its closest memory and forward it to the corresponding procedure in both training and testing. Experimental results show that the proposed mechanism can be trained efficiently using a four - step training strategy.

This paper studies equivariance of polynomial functions in classical physics. The authors show that equivariant polynomials can be expressed in terms of a lightweight collection of scalar - scalar products and scalar contractions of the scalar, vector, tensor, and tensor - tensor inputs.    The main contribution of this paper is to prove that scalar functions are equivariants under the Euclidean, Lorentz, and Poincaré symmetries of classical physics, and that the method is simple, efficient, and scalable. The paper also provides some numerical experiments to support their claims.

This paper proposes a new loss function for bounding box regression. The loss function is a generalization of the Intersection over Union ( IoU ) loss and its variants. The main idea is to generalize existing IoU - based losses to a new family of power IoU losses that have a power IoUs term and an additional power regularization term with a single power parameter. Experiments on multiple object detection benchmarks and models demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed loss function.

This paper studies Distributionally Robust Imitation Learning ( DROIL ) and establishes a close connection between DROIL and Maximum Entropy Inverse Reinforcement Learning. DROIL can be seen as a framework that maximizes a generalized concept of entropy. The authors develop a novel approach to transform the objective function into a convex optimization problem for a class of loss functions that are additive over state and action spaces. Experiments on synthetic data and a highway driving environment show the significant benefits of DROIL.

This paper proposes a post - processing algorithm for individual fairness ( individual fairness ) in the setting where the learner only has access to the predictions of the original model and a similarity graph between individuals guiding the desired fairness constraints. They cast the individual fairness problem as a graph smoothing problem corresponding to graph Laplacian regularization that preserves the desired “ similar individuals similarly ” interpretation. Theoretical results demonstrate the connection of the new objective function to a local relaxation of individual fairness. Empirically, the proposed algorithm correct individual biases in large - scale NLP models such as BERT, while preserving accuracy.

This paper proposes a structure - aware dual graph aggregation network ( SADGA ) for cross - domain Text - to - SQL task. The proposed method is based on the graph structure to provide a unified encoding model for both the natural language question and the database schema, and a question - linking method to learn the mapping between words in the question and tables / columns in the database schemas. The performance of the proposed model is evaluated on the challenging Text - To - SQL benchmark Spider.

This paper studies the behavior of stochastic computations graphs with multiple sequential discrete components. The authors show that it is challenging to optimize the parameters of these models, mainly due to small gradients and local minima. They propose two new strategies to overcome these challenges. They also show that increasing the scale parameter of the Gumbel noise perturbations during training improves the learning behavior.

This paper studies Bayesian inference with Bayesian neural networks ( BNNs ) with high - fidelity approximate inference via full - batch Hamiltonian Monte Carlo achieve poor generalization under covariate shift, even under classical estimation. The authors explain this surprising result, showing how a Bayesian model average can in fact be problematic under covariates shift. They additionally show why the same issue does not affect many approximate inference procedures, or classical maximum - a - posteriori ( MAP ) training. Finally, the authors propose novel priors that improve the robustness of BNN to many sources of covariate shifts.

This paper categorizes meta - learning evaluation into two settings : in - distribution [ ID ] and out - of - distribution ( OOD ). It identifies that most existing few - shot classification benchmarks instead reflect OOD evaluation, as they use disjoint sets of train ( base ) and test ( novel ) classes for task generation. This discrepancy is problematic because meta - learners that perform better on existing OOD datasets may perform significantly worse in the ID setting.

This paper studies the problem of rule induction in the context of open rule induction, which aims to induce open rules from the knowledge base without supervision of annotated rules. The authors argue that the existing knowledge base - based rule induction methods are “ learning rules from rules ”, while the language model - based methods are learning rules “ from rules. ” This limits these methods to only produce “canned ” rules whose patterns are constrained by the annotating rules, while discarding the rich expressive power of LMs for free text. To this end, the authors propose the Orion system to automatically induct open rules without supervision from LMs. Extensive experiments are conducted to verify the quality and quantity of the inducted open rules.

This paper proposes a novel offline RL algorithm named Implicit Constraint Q - learning ( ICQ ) to reduce the accumulated extrapolation error in multi - agent reinforcement learning ( RL ). The main idea of ICQ is to only trust the state - action pairs given in the dataset for value estimation. The paper also extends ICQ to extend the joint - policy learning to multi - agents tasks by decomposing the joint policy under the implicit constraint. The proposed method is evaluated on StarCraft II and StarCraft III datasets.

This paper proposes a method to train adversarial examples ( AEs ) that are more robust to real - world attacks. The key idea is to enable non - uniform perturbations that can adequately represent the feature dependencies during adversarial training. The proposed method is based on the empirical data distribution, both on correlations between the features and the importance of the features themselves. Experiments are conducted on several datasets for malware classification, credit risk prediction, and spam detection.

This paper extends the theory of Tikhonov regularization to generalized self - concordant loss functions ( GSC ), which contain the logistic loss. In particular, the authors show that the optimal rates of the excess risk can be obtained for GSC by using the iterated Tikh onov regularisation scheme, which is intrinsically related to the Tikh regularization scheme of Marteau - Ferey et al. ( 2002 ).   The paper is well - written and easy to follow, and the results are interesting. However, the paper suffers from a lack of novelty.

This paper introduces a new kind of linear transform named Deformable Butterfly ( DeBut ) that generalizes the conventional butterfly matrices and can be adapted to various input - output dimensions. The paper applies DeBut as a drop - in replacement of standard fully connected and convolutional layers and demonstrate its superiority in homogenizing a neural network and rendering it favorable properties such as light weight and low inference complexity, without compromising accuracy. The natural complexity - accuracy tradeoff arising from the myriad deformations of a DeBut layer also opens up new rooms for analytical and practical research.

This paper proposes a method to address the catastrophic forgetfulness ( CF ) problem, which is the problem of forgetting of old information during the training of a new task. The authors propose a method, called MetA Reusable Knowledge ( MARK ), to learn a common knowledge base ( KB ) that is not only used to learn new tasks, but also enriched with new knowledge as the model learns new tasks. An ablation study provides evidence that the proposed method is learning reusable knowledge that is selectively used by each task.

This paper proposes a data - driven framework for scheduling heuristics in an exact MIP solver. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of a problem - specific schedule for computing the optimal heuristic for a given MIP problem. The paper also proposes an efficient algorithm for computing such a schedule.   The main contributions of this paper are the following :   1. The authors propose an algorithm for scheduling the heuristic of an exact solver for MIP. 2. The proposed algorithm is able to reduce the average primal integral by up to 49 % on two classes of challenging instances. 3. The performance of the algorithm is evaluated on two sets of MIP problems. 4. The algorithm is compared to several baselines.

This paper studies the problem of reinforcement learning ( RL ) in which the learner receives binary feedback only once at the end of an episode. The authors study the case where trajectory labels are generated by an unknown parametric model, and provide a statistically and computationally efficient algorithm that achieves sublinear regret.   The main contribution of this paper is to provide an algorithm that is computationally and statistically efficient. The paper is well - written and easy to follow.

This paper proposes a novel edge representation learning framework based on Dual Hypergraph Transformation ( DHT ) that transforms the edges of a graph into the nodes of a hypergraph. This dual hypergraph construction allows to apply message - passing techniques for node representations to edges in graph representation learning. Experiments are conducted on two graph datasets for graph representation and generation performance, on which the proposed method largely outperforms existing graph representation methods.

This paper studies the sufficiency of a state representation for learning and representing the optimal policy, and study several popular mutual information ( MI ) based objectives through this lens. The authors find that two of these objectives can yield insufficient representations given mild and common assumptions on the structure of the MDP. The theoretical results are corroborated with empirical experiments on a simulated game environment with visual observations.

This paper proposes a novel steerable convolution method for the task of 3D object semantic analysis. The main idea is to use sparse tensors to accelerate the computations of the SE(3)-equivariant deep feature learning. The proposed method is evaluated on three tasks : pose estimation, pose estimation and pose refinement. The results show the superiority of the proposed method over the existing methods in terms of accuracy and efficiency.

This paper studies the problem of token sparsification in vision transformers. The authors observe that the final prediction in vision transformer is only based on a subset of most informative tokens, which is sufficient for accurate image recognition. Based on this observation, the authors propose to prune redundant tokens progressively and dynamically based on the input features. Specifically, they devise a lightweight prediction module to estimate the importance score of each token given the current features. They also propose an attention masking strategy to differentiably prune a token by blocking its interactions with other tokens. Experiments are conducted on ImageNet to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed framework.

This paper studies the problem of obtaining distribution - free guarantees for the conditional mean E [ Y | X ]. The authors study the problem in settings in between the finite setting and the continuous setting, where vanishing - width confidence intervals are achievable if and only if the effective support size of the distribution of X is smaller than the square of the sample size. They show that there are several distinct regimes in between these two extremes. The main contribution of this paper is to show that any confidence interval for E [Y | X] must have non - vanishing width.

This paper proposes Representation Neutralization Neutralization for Fairness ( RNF ) to reduce the discrimination of DNN models by only debiasing the classification head, even with biased representations as inputs. To this end, the authors leverage samples with the same ground - truth label but different sensitive attributes, and use their neutralized representations to train the class - specific classification head of the DNN model. Experimental results over several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed RNF framework.

This paper presents a new convolutional neural network ( CNN ) layer that is invariant to translations and rotations. The proposed method is based on the Bessel functions, which are well - known in physics. The authors propose to use these functions to build a CNN layer that can be applied to any continuous set of possible rotation angles by design.    The paper is well - written and easy to follow.

This paper proposes a new method for kernel ridge regression. The proposed method is based on partitioning the feature space of the kernel ridge data into a set of partitions, which are then used to estimate the effective dimension and bias of the data. The method is evaluated on a number of large - scale datasets and is shown to improve the performance of kernel ridge regressions.

This paper presents a method for learning to communicate among agents via discrete tokens. The authors propose a neural network architecture that enables agents to communicate using discrete tokens derived from a learned, continuous space. They show in a decision theoretic framework that their technique optimizes communication over a wide range of scenarios, whereas one - hot tokens are only optimal under restrictive assumptions.
