This paper introduces LiPopt, a polynomial optimization framework for computing increasingly tighter upper bounds on the Lipschitz constant of neural networks. The underlying optimization problems boil down to either linear ( LP ) or semidefinite ( SDP ) programming. The authors propose to use the sparse connectivity of a network to significantly reduce the complexity of computation. This is specially useful for convolutional as well as pruned neural network. The experiments on networks with random weights and networks trained on MNIST show the proposed approach yields superior estimates.

This paper proposes a self - supervised learning approach for video features that results in significantly improved performance on downstream tasks ( such as video classification, captioning and segmentation ) compared to existing methods. The proposed method extends the BERT model for text sequences to the case of sequences of real - valued feature vectors by replacing the softmax loss with noise contrastive estimation ( NCE ). The authors also show how to learn representations from sequences of visual features and sequences of words derived from automatic speech recognition ( ASR ).

This paper proposes a simple yet effective framework to select certain parts of the input data needed for the subsequent application of a given neural network. Both the associated selection masks as well as the neural network are trained simultaneously such that a good model performance is achieved while, at the same time, only a minimal amount of data is selected. During the inference phase, only the parts selected by the masks have to be transferred between the server and the client. The experiments indicate that it is often possible to significantly reduce the amounts of data needed to be moved without affecting the model performance much.

This paper proposes a method to detect out - of - distribution ( OOD ) examples using deep neural networks ( DNNs ). The method is based on the Outlier Exposure ( OE ) technique, which is used to detect samples from novel class distributions. The main contribution of this paper is to propose a novel loss function for OOD detection. Experiments on image and text classification tasks demonstrate the effectiveness of the method.

This paper proposes an end - to - end deep learning model, called E2Efold, for RNA secondary structure prediction. The key idea is to directly predict the RNA base - pairing matrix, and use an unrolled algorithm for constrained programming as the template for deep architectures to enforce constraints. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed model.

This paper proposes a new setting where agents internalise an environment and each agent asynchronously internalises their own predictive model of the environment and forms a virtual simulation within which the agent plays trials of the episodes in entirety. The key idea is to let agents imagine together ; make them take turns to host virtual episodes within which all agents participate and interact with their own biased representations. Since agents ’ biases vary, the collective policy developed while sequentially visiting the internal simulations complement one another ’s shortcomings. The experimental results show that the collective policies consistently achieve significantly higher returns than the best individually trained policies.

This paper proposes a new model for dialog generation that learns a semantic latent space, on which representations of semantically related sentences are close to each other. This latent space is learned by maximizing correlation between the features extracted from prompt and responses. An additional autoencoder is trained, for recovering the full sentence from the latent space. Experimental results show that the proposed model eliminates the generic response problem, while achieving comparable or better coherence compared to existing methods.

This paper proposes a novel notion of salient explanation, Gaussian light and shadow ( GLAS ), which estimates the spatial impact of deep models by the feature perturbation inspired by light - shadow in nature. GLAS provides a useful coarseto - fine control benefiting from scalability of Gaussian mask. The authors also devised the ability to identify multiple instances through recursive GLAS. Experiments are conducted on the fine - grained classification dataset using the ImageNet Large Scale Visual Recognition dataset.

This paper proposes a method to remove pixel - wise and channel - wise correlations before the data is fed into each layer of a convolutional neural network ( CNN ). The method is based on the center - round structure of biological neurons in the visual regions of the brain. Experiments show that the proposed method is able to improve the performance of CNNs on a range of datasets.

This paper studies the problem of quantizing the weight of GANs to 1 - bit or 2 - bit bits. The authors propose a novel quantization method named QGAN, which can quantize the weights of a GAN model to a very low bit. They also propose a multi - precision algorithm to help find an appropriate quantization precision of the GAN weights given image qualities requirements. Experiments on CIFAR-10 and CelebA show that QGAN can produce samples with a sample quality comparable to original models.

This paper studies the problem of last - iterate convergence in convex - concave min - max optimization. The main contribution of this paper is the development of a new algorithm, HGD, that achieves linear convergence in a variety of more general settings than the standard stochastic gradient descent algorithm. In particular, the authors show that HGD achieves convergence rates that satisfy a novel novel “ bilinear ” condition for the convex-concave setting, and also prove convergence rates for the more general “ convex strongly concave ” setting. The paper is well - written and easy to follow.

This paper studies the stability of ResNet block hl = φ(hl−1 + τ · g(hl+1 ) ), where hl is the number of residual blocks and g is the activation function. The authors show that for standard initialization used in practice, \tau = 1 / \sqrt{\sqrt{L}(\sqrt { L } ) is a sharp value in characterizing the stability in the forward / backward process of deep ResNet. They also demonstrate that the over - parameterization requirement of ResNets only weakly depends on the depth, which corroborates the advantage of Deep ResNet over vanilla feedforward network.

This paper proposes a method to train sparse neural networks with a fixed parameter count and a fixed computational cost throughout training, without sacrificing accuracy relative to existing dense - to - sparse training methods. The method updates the topology of the network during training by using parameter magnitudes and infrequent gradient calculations to achieve a given level of accuracy compared to prior techniques. Experiments are conducted on ImageNet-2012 dataset, WideResNets dataset, CIFAR-10 dataset, and WikiText-103 dataset.

This paper proposes a new method to find meaningful directions in the latent space of any generative model along which to control specific properties of the generated image like the position or scale of the object in the image. The proposed method does not require human annotations and is particularly well suited for the search of directions encoding simple transformations of generated images, such as translation, zoom or color variations. The method is evaluated on a set of images generated with a BigGAN model ( BOGAN ), showing that the position of an object can be controlled within the image and the scale of that object can also be controlled.

This paper proposes a physics - as - inverse - graphics - based model for unsupervised physical parameter estimation of systems from video, where the differential equations governing the scene dynamics are known, but the labeled states or objects are not available. This framework allows the model to perform long term extrapolative video prediction, as well as vision based model - predictive control. The controller ’s interpretability provides unique capabilities in goal - driven control and physical reasoning for zero - data adaptation.

This paper considers the problem of learning a classifier from noisy labels when only a few clean labeled examples are given. The authors propose a graph convolutional network based method to predict class relevance of noisy examples. The proposed method is evaluated on an extended version of a few - shot learning problem, where the few clean examples of novel classes are supplemented with additional noisy data. The results show that the proposed method significantly improves the classification accuracy.

This paper proposes a new objective for graph neural networks ( GNNs ) that maximizes the mutual information ( MI ) between edge features and message passing channels. The MI is reformulated as a differentiable objective via a variational approach. The paper theoretically shows that the newly introduced objective enables the model to preserve edge information, and empirically corroborates the enhanced performance of MI - maximized models across a broad range of learning tasks including regression on molecular graphs and relation prediction in knowledge graphs.

This paper proposes a new method to certify non - trivial properties of generative networks. The proposed method, called PROXLINE, is a combination of two existing methods, one for deterministic and one for probabilistic interpretation. The main contribution of the proposed method is the ability to capture sufficient non - convexity so to produce precise bounds on the output of a generative network. The method is evaluated on a number of datasets, including ImageNet, CIFAR-10, and TinyImageNet. The results show that the method can verify interesting interpolations in the network's latent space.

This paper studies the problem of " suspended animation " in graph neural networks ( GNNs ) based on the spectral graph convolutional operator. In this paper, the authors further identify the suspended animation problem with the existing graph neural network models and introduce the GRESNET framework to resolve the problem. The proposed framework creates extensively connected highways to involve nodes ’ raw features or intermediate representations throughout the graph for all the model layers. Extensive empirical experiments on real - world benchmark datasets are reported in the paper to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed framework.

This paper proposes a new method for 3D face reconstruction from unlabeled and labeled images. The proposed method is based on nonlinear parametric CNN neural networks and is trained on a dataset generated from a linear 3D morphable model ( 3DMM ). The paper claims that the proposed method can generalize well to a wide range of facial expressions, poses, lighting conditions, and lighting conditions. Experiments are conducted on a synthetic dataset as well as a real - world dataset to validate the effectiveness of the method.

This paper studies the problem of imitation learning in a setting where the transition kernel is unknown. The authors propose to replace the unknown transition kernel with a synthetic kernel that simulates the transition of state components for which the kernel is known ( s ) and extract from demonstrations the state components ( su ) for which it is unknown ( r ). The next state is then stitched from the two components ( s and su ).    The authors show that the eMDP model achieves superior performance compared to the simulation - free alternative. The main contribution of the paper is the formulation of the model for solving imitation problems using Reinforcement Learning.

This paper proposes a self - supervised reinforcement learning approach for learning to control states of interest without any external reward function. The authors formulate the intrinsic objective as rewarding the skills that maximize the mutual information between the context states and the states of the interest. They evaluate their approach for different simulated robotic manipulation tasks from OpenAI Gym and a navigation task in the Gazebo simulator. They show that their method is able to learn to manipulate the object purely based on the intrinsic mutual information rewards.

This paper studies the trojaning attack on Neural network ( NN ) models, which is an emerging and important attack that can broadly damage the system deployed with NN models. The attack is programmable that the malicious misclassification target is not fixed and can be generated on demand even after the victim ’s deployment. The proposed method outperforms existing studies in capability, generality, and stealthiness. The paper is well - written and easy to follow.

This paper presents a few - shot regression ( FSR ) algorithm for drug discovery. The main idea is to learn a kernel function and a differentiable kernel algorithm to find the appropriate kernel for each task during inference. The proposed algorithm outperforms existing state - of - the - art FSR algorithms on both toy and real - world drug discovery tasks. The paper is well - written and easy to follow.

This paper proposes a framework to characterize which reasoning tasks a network can learn well, by studying how well its computation structure aligns with the algorithmic structure of the relevant reasoning process. The authors define this algorithmic alignment and derive a sample complexity bound that decreases with better alignment. This framework offers an explanation for the empirical success of popular reasoning models, and suggests their limitations.

This paper proposes a new metric, the Fréchet joint distance ( FJD ), to benchmark GANs. The FJD is defined as the joint distance between joint distributions of images and conditioning distributions. The authors propose to use the FJD as a single metric to capture the desirable properties of image quality, conditional consistency, and intra - conditioning diversity. Experiments are conducted on a controllable synthetic dataset, which consistently highlight the benefits of FJD when compared to existing established metrics.

This paper studies the parsimonious set of decision states, i.e., the set of states where decisions meanfully affect the future states an agent can reach in an environment. The decision states are discovered without extrinsic rewards – simply by interacting with the world. The authors use the VIC framework ( Gregor et al., 2016 ) to identify ‘decision states ’ and formulate a sandwich bound on the empowerment objective that allows identification of the decision states. The results show that the decision state are interpretable, and lead to better exploration on downstream goal - driven tasks in partially observable environments.

This paper proposes a method to classify irregularly sampled time series with unaligned measurements, focusing on scalability and data efficiency. The method SEFT ( Set Functions for Time Series ) is based on recent advances in differentiable set function learning, is parallelizable, and scales well to very large datasets and online monitoring scenarios. The proposed method is evaluated on multiple healthcare time series datasets and show that it performs competitively whilst significantly reducing runtime.

This paper proposes a method to improve the performance of deep neural networks ( CNNs ) on unsupervised audio restoration. The method is based on the idea that convolutional kernels should be supported by sets of sets of harmonic series, instead of by local neighborhoods. The authors show that the proposed method can be used to train CNNs to model priors in audio signals by explicitly utilizing the harmonic structure. Experiments are conducted on both synthetic and real - world datasets.

This paper proposes a method to reduce the total computation used by earlier pipeline stages and speed up training whenever computation upstream from accelerators dominates the training time. Data echoing reuses ( or “echoes ” ) intermediate outputs from earlier pipeline stage in order to reclaim idle capacity. The paper investigates the behavior of different data echoing algorithms on various workloads, for various amounts of echoing, and for various batch sizes. They find that in all settings, at least one data echoing algorithm can match the baseline performance using less upstream computation.

This paper studies the problem of learning a policy that is distinguishable from other policies in a Markov decision process ( MDP ). The authors propose two approaches to solve this problem. First, they propose a novel algorithm that learns controllable features that can be leveraged to provide enhanced generalization and fast task inference through the successor features framework. Second, the authors propose a new reward function that defines the reward function as linear in some grounded feature space. Experiments are conducted on 12 games and show that the proposed approach outperforms the baselines.

This paper studies the generalization properties of deep neural networks ( DNNs ) from a functional point of view. In particular, the authors study the smoothness of the functional approximation of the network, which is a function of the number of units in the network. The authors show that a smooth functional approximation with a flat initial approximation leads to better generalization than a smooth approximation with multiple initializations. They also show that the network generalizes better with more units compared to a smooth initial approximation with fewer units.

This paper proposes a new GAN - based method for image - to - image translation. The proposed method is based on an attention mechanism that estimates the probability that the discriminator's input is real. The attention map is then used to guide the generator to produce more plausible and realistic images. Experiments are conducted on a number of image transfer tasks and quantitative results are provided.

This paper studies the role of multiplicative interaction layers in neural network architectures. The authors claim that such layers strictly enrich the representable function classes of neural networks. They conjecture that multiplicative interactions offer a powerful inductive bias when fusing multiple streams of information or when conditional computation is required. They argue that they should be considered in many situations where multiple compute or information paths need to be combined, in place of simple and oft - used concatenation operations.

This paper proposes a new algorithm for batch active learning with deep neural network models. The proposed algorithm, Batch Active Learning by Diverse Gradient Embeddings ( BADGE ) samples groups of points that are disparate and high magnitude when represented in a hallucinated gradient space. The algorithm is designed to incorporate both predictive uncertainty and sample diversity into every selected batch. Crucially, BADGE trades off between uncertainty and diversity without requiring any hand - tuned parameters.

This paper proposes a novel feature leveling architecture for self - explainable deep neural networks ( DNNs ). The proposed architecture is based on the general linear model ( GLM ), which is one of the most well - studied models in the field of self - explanation. The authors argue that the GLM layer is hard to interpret because each hidden layer carries a mix of low level features and high level features. To address this problem, the authors propose a feature leveled architecture that isolates low - level features from high - level feature on a per - layer basis to better utilize the GLMs layer in the proposed architecture for interpretation. Experiments are conducted on standard datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a simple training method for drastically enhancing the gradient signal by drawing negative samples from an adversarial model that mimics the data distribution. The authors also provide a mathematical proof that this adversarial sampling mechanism produces negative samples at a cost only logarithmic in C, thus still resulting in cheap gradient updates. Experimental results on large scale data sets also show a reduction of the training time by an order of magnitude relative to several competitive baselines.

This paper proposes a new approach for efficient exploration that leverages a low dimensional encoding of the environment learned with a combination of model - based and model - free objectives. The proposed approach uses intrinsic rewards that are based on a weighted distance of nearest neighbors in the low dimensional representational space to gauge novelty and leverage these intrinsic rewards for sample - efficient exploration. The authors test their approach on a number of maze tasks, as well as a control problem and show that their exploration approach is more sample -efficient compared to strong baselines.

This paper studies the problem of out - of - distribution detection in the few - shot setting. The authors propose two new methods for this task and investigate their performance. They also establish benchmark datasets based on four popular few shot classification datasets. The main contribution of this paper is to propose two methods for out of distribution detection. The proposed methods are evaluated on two new benchmark datasets and show improved results compared to existing methods.

This paper studies the problem of generating sequences directly from neural sequence models such as BERT ( Devlin et al. 2019 ). The authors propose a generalized model of sequence generation that unifies decoding in directed and undirected models. The proposed framework models the process of generation rather than a resulting sequence. This unification enables the authors to adapt decoding algorithms for a cross - lingual masked translation model ( Lample and Conneau, 2019 ), which is competitive with the state of the art on WMT’14 English - German translation.

This paper proposes a two - stage method for the recognition of mathematical expressions ( MEs ). The first stage uses object detection to identify the MEs in the input image and the second stage uses a seq2seq model to generate LaTeX sequences for MEs recognition. The proposed method is compared to the end - to - end method and is shown to outperform it. The main contribution of the paper is the use of two stages for ME recognition.

This paper proposes a vector quantization method to reduce the memory footprint of convolutional neural networks. The key idea is to focus on the quality of the reconstruction of the network outputs rather than its weights. The method only requires a set of unlabelled data at quantization time and allows for efficient inference on CPU by using bytealigned codebooks to store the compressed weights. Experiments are conducted on the ResNet-50 model to a memory size of 5 MB ( 20× compression factor ) while preserving a top - 1 accuracy of 76.1 % on ImageNet object classification and by compressing a Mask R - CNN with a 26× factor.

This paper proposes a novel attention mechanism, called TensorProduct Transformer ( TP - Transformer ), to encode the relations between each Transformer cell and the other cells from which values have been retrieved by attention. The proposed method is based on the recently introduced Mathematics Dataset containing 56 categories of free - form math wordproblems. The paper is well written and easy to follow. However, the paper suffers from a lack of novelty and novelty.

This paper studies the problem of generalization of deep neural networks ( DNNs ). The authors first derive a necessary and sufficient condition for generalization using a universal cognitive similarity metric, namely information distance, based on Kolmogorov complexity. Then, they formulate an optimization problem to learn a more general classification function, and train the classifier on the extended features, where they use channel codes on the input features as a systematic way to improve the degree to which the training and test sets are representative of the empirical sample set. Extensive experiments are conducted to demonstrate that a model trained on encoded input features is significantly more robust to common corruptions, e.g. Gaussian and shot noise, as well as adversarial perturbations, than models trained on uncoded input features.

Graph pooling is a critical ingredient by which GNNs adapt to input graphs of varying size and structure. This paper proposes a graph pooling operation based on compressive Haar transforms, called HaarPooling. The input of each pooling layer is transformed by the compressive haar basis of the corresponding clustering. The proposed method achieves state - of - the - art performance on graph classification problems.

This paper studies the problem of point cloud decoders that map a shape representation to a point feature distribution, allowing an arbitrary number of sampled features to be transformed into individual output points. The authors develop three sample - based decoder architectures and compare their performance to each other and show their improved effectiveness over feedforward architectures. The paper is well - written and easy to follow.

This paper presents a large - scale study on the generalization ability of deep neural networks ( DNNs ) to real - world noise. The authors conduct a benchmark study across a variety of noise levels and types, architectures, methods, and training settings. The main results of the paper are : ( 1 ) Deep Neural Networks generalize much better on real world noise compared to synthetic noise, and ( 2 ) when networks are fine - tuned, fine - tuned, ImageNet architectures generalize well on noisy data. ( 3 ) synthetic noise appears to be less harmful, yet it is more difficult for robust DNN methods to improve. ( 4 ) Robust learning methods that work well on synthetic noise may not work as well on real-world noise.

This paper proposes a rule - exemplar method for collecting human supervision to combine the efficiency of rules with the quality of instance labels. The supervision is coupled such that it is both natural for humans and synergistic for learning. The training algorithm jointly denoises rules via latent coverage variables, and trains the model through a soft implication loss over the coverage and label variables. The denoised rules and trained model are used jointly for inference. The proposed method is evaluated on five different tasks.

This paper proposes two graph neural networks ( GNNs ) based on graph memory networks ( GMNs ). The main idea is to add a memory layer to the GNN to store information about the nodes of the graph. The paper also introduces two new networks based on this memory layer : memory - based GNN ( MemGNN ) and graph memory network ( GMNN ) that can learn hierarchical graph representations. The experimental results show that the proposed models achieve state - of - the - art results in eight out of nine graph classification and regression benchmarks.

This paper studies the effect of initial parameter values for gradient - based optimization of deep neural networks. The authors provide a rigorous proof that the width needed for efficient convergence to a global minimum with orthogonal initializations is independent of the depth and scales linearly in the depth.   The authors also provide an explanation for the recent empirical successes found by initializing very deep non - linear networks according to the principle of dynamical isometry.

This paper studies the problem of how to optimize the bit allocation of weights and activations for deep CNNs compression. The authors propose a Lagrangian Formulation method to solve the optimization problem. The method obtains excellent results on deep neural networks with only 0.7 % accuracy loss.   The paper is well - written and easy to follow.

This paper proposes a new model for generative adversarial networks ( GANs ). The proposed model is based on the Wasserstein distance between the two - player WGANs and the auto - encoder network. The paper also proposes an iterative primal dual optimization process to improve the generalization error bound of the proposed iWGANs. Experiments are conducted on several datasets to evaluate the performance of the model.

This paper proposes a mention - pair model of anaphoric annotation ( MPA ) to alleviate the effects of sparsity inherent in some crowdsourcing environments. The proposed model uses a nonparametric partially pooled structure ( based on a stick breaking process ). The individual estimates can thus be improved using information about the community when the data is scarce. The model is also flexible enough to be used in standard annotation tasks for classification where it registers on par performance with the state of the art.

This paper proposes a new intrinsic reward called successor feature control ( SFC ), which is general and not task - specific. It takes into account statistics over complete trajectories and thus differs from previous methods that only use local information to evaluate intrinsic motivation. The proposed method is evaluated on three different environments with pure visual inputs. The results show a substantially improved exploration efficiency with SFC and the hierarchical usage of the intrinsic drives.

This paper proposes a method for weakly supervised video moment retrieval, where the goal is to locate the video segment which is described by the sentence without having access to temporal annotations during training. The proposed method is comprised of a frame - by - word interaction module as well as a novel Word - Conditioned Visual Graph ( WCVG ). Experiments on the DiDeMo and Charades - STA datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the learned representations.

This paper proposes a learned image - guided rendering technique that combines the benefits of image - based rendering and GAN - based image synthesis. The proposed method is able to generate photo - realistic re - renderings of reconstructed objects for virtual and augmented reality applications ( e.g., virtual showrooms, virtual tours & sightseeing, the digital inspection of historical artifacts ). The paper demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed method both qualitatively and quantitatively on synthetic as well as real data.

This paper presents a sparse representation of model uncertainty for deep neural networks ( DNNs ) that relies on an inverse formulation of Multivariate Normal Distribution ( MND ): an information form. The proposed method estimates the model uncertainty in this form using a scalable Laplace Approximation scheme, which involves a diagonal correction of the Kronecker - factored eigenbasis. The authors further devise a novel low - rank approximation of this eigen basis that exploits spectral sparsity of DNNS.

This paper studies the problem of load - balanced hashing ( OPH ), which is a fundamental method to compute set similarities and compact high - dimensional data for efficient learning and searching. The paper proposes a new method, AHash, which can generate as few empty bins as possible, without hurting runtime efficiency compared with OPH and densification strategies. The experiments on real datasets validate the claim and datasets are released on GitHub anonymously.

This paper proposes a method for extracting features from phase shift data by adding a graph structure to each data point and constructing a suitable machine learning architecture for graph data with cyclic permutation. The proposed method is based on the observation that there is a phase shift in the rotation of a rotating shaft. The authors propose a method to extract the features from the phase shift by adding the graph structure of the input vectors to the data points. The method is evaluated on a synthetic dataset and on a real - world dataset.

This paper proposes a new method for conditional conditional text generation. The main idea is to use a variational Bayes objective to learn a confidence score for each target position, which can be leveraged at inference time using a calibration technique to promote more faithful generation. Experiments on a structured data - to - text dataset show that the proposed approach is more faithful to the source than existing state - of - the - art approaches, according to both metrics and human evaluation.

This paper proposes a new method for pruning neural networks based on the observation that magnitude - based pruning minimizes the Frobenius distortion of a linear operator corresponding to a single layer. Based on this observation, the authors propose to extend the single layer optimization to a multi - layer optimization. The proposed method is evaluated on several networks, including VGG and ResNet, in the high - sparsity regime.

This paper proposes a method for decentralized stochastic gradient descent ( SGD ), where parallel workers are connected to form a graph and communicate adjacently. The authors prove in theory that Moniqua communicates a provably bounded number of bits per iteration, while converging at the same asymptotic rate as the original algorithm does with full - precision communication. They also demonstrate empirically that the proposed method converges faster with respect to wall clock time than other quantized decentralized algorithms.

This paper studies the problem of learning a model of future observations and rewards for reinforcement learning. The authors propose a general family of partial models that are provably causally correct, yet provably fast because they do not need to fully model future observations. The main contribution of this paper is to show that partial models can be causally incorrect : they are confounded by the observations they don’t model, and can therefore lead to incorrect planning. To address this, the authors introduce a new class of models that is provably correct.

This paper proposes a new variational autoencoder ( VAE ) model that decomposes a pair of correlated data variables into their common representation ( e.g., a shared concept ) and local representations that capture the remaining randomness ( texture and style ) in respective data variables by imposing the mutual information between the data variables and the common representation as a regularization term. Experiments are conducted for joint and conditional generation with and without style control using synthetic data and real images. The proposed model outperforms existing VAE variants and the variational information bottleneck method.
